questions.text: Which of the following best describes the purpose of the test shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Evaluating spatial neglect

 

  • This device is often used in the assessment of spatial neglect, particularly in patients with lesions in the parietal lobe. 
  • Patients with spatial neglect may fail to attend to one side of the visual field or fail to recognize shapes in certain quadrants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Assessing motor coordination: Tests for motor coordination involve tasks like finger-nose tests or gait assessments.

 

Option C. Testing visual field defects: This is done using perimetry or confrontation testing.

 

Option D. Identifying color blindness: Color blindness is tested with Ishihara plates or similar tools.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The test shown is used to evaluate spatial neglect, often seen in lesions of the parietal lobe, where patients fail to process or attend to one side of the visual field.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman, in her 28th week of gestation, presents to the emergency room with acute severe abdominal pain that started suddenly. She denies fever, vaginal bleeding, or regular uterine contractions. On examination, her abdomen is tense and tender. Laboratory investigations reveal a normal WBC count of 8000 cells/µl. There is no evidence of cervical dilatation or effacement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red degeneration of fibroid

 

  • Red degeneration (caverneous degeneration) is a common complication of fibroids during pregnancy, caused by thrombosis and venous obstruction in the capsular veins of the fibroid. 
  • It presents with acute severe pain and tenderness over the fibroid region without signs of fever or systemic infection. 
  • Red degeneration is particularly seen in the second or third trimester, when the fibroid undergoes ischemia due to the rapid growth of the uterus compressing its blood supply.
    • Symptoms: Sudden onset of abdominal pain, tense and tender uterus, no significant fever, and a normal WBC count.
    • Treatment: Management is supportive, including rest, hydration, and analgesia. Surgical intervention is typically avoided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Preterm labor: Preterm labor would present with rhythmic uterine contractions increasing in intensity and frequency, along with cervical changes like effacement and dilatation. In this case, the absence of such findings and the acute nature of pain make preterm labor unlikely.

 

Option C. Torsion of fibroid: Torsion occurs in pedunculated subserosal fibroids, causing severe pain, often accompanied by nausea and vomiting. It requires surgical intervention. This condition is rare and is not consistent with the patient's presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Red degeneration of fibroid is a common complication in pregnancy, presenting with acute abdominal pain and tenderness, usually in the second or third trimester. 
  • Management is supportive, and surgical intervention is avoided unless absolutely necessary.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of excessive preoccupation about having a serious illness for the past year. Despite normal investigations and repeated reassurance from multiple doctors, she is convinced that she has cancer. She spends hours daily researching symptoms online and frequently seeks medical opinions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Illness anxiety disorder

 

  • Illness anxiety disorder is characterized by excessive worry about having or acquiring a serious illness despite no significant somatic symptoms and normal medical evaluations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Somatic symptom disorder: Involves significant physical symptoms that cause distress, which are absent here.

 

Option C. Generalized anxiety disorder: Characterized by excessive worry about various life events, not limited to health.

 

Option D. Obsessive-compulsive disorder: Involves intrusive thoughts and compulsive behaviors unrelated to specific health concerns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Illness anxiety disorder (Hypochondriasis) is characterized by a preoccupation with having or acquiring a serious physical illness. 
  • The preoccupation persists despite normal investigations and medical reassurances. 
  • Management includes primarily psychotherapy (CBT), and pharmacotherapy for comorbid psychiatric disorders.
    • Preoccupation with illness- Illness anxiety disorder (Hypochondriasis)
    • Preoccupation with somatic symptoms- Somatic symptom disorder

questions.text: Which of the following approaches is categorized under "Safe Environments" in the strategies to eliminate violence against children?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reducing the spread of violence through urban planning initiatives

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delivered through home visits: Falls under "Parent and Caregiver Support," emphasizing family-focused interventions.

 

Option C. Treatment programs for juvenile offenders: Part of the "Response and Support Services" strategy, addressing rehabilitative needs.

 

Option D. Teaching self-defense strategies: Included in the "Education and Life Skills" strategy to empower children with knowledge and protective skills.

  • The "Safe Environments" strategy reduces violence by modifying environmental and structural factors, such as urban safety measures.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man with sickle cell disease (HbSS) presents to the emergency department with chest pain, shortness of breath, and diffuse pain. He stopped taking hydroxyurea 4 months ago due to stomach upset.

Clinical Findings:

  • Vitals:
    • Blood pressure: 122/72 mmHg
    • Pulse: 108/min
    • Respirations: 22/min
    • Oxygen saturation: 84% on room air
  • Physical exam:
    • Bilateral crackles on chest auscultation
    • 2/6 midsystolic murmur at the left upper sternal border
    • Abdominal tenderness without rebound or extremity swelling

Laboratory Results:

  • Leukocytes: 14,000/µL (elevated)
  • Hemoglobin: 8.5 g/dL (low)
  • Platelets: 435,000/µL (elevated)
  • Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL (normal)

Chest X-ray is shown below: 

 

 

Initial Management:

 

  • Intravenous fluids, supplemental oxygen, and antibiotics.

 

What is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Exchange transfusion

 

  • The patient is experiencing acute chest syndrome (ACS), a life-threatening complication of sickle cell disease.

 

Key Features of ACS:

 

  1. Pulmonary symptoms: Chest pain, shortness of breath, hypoxemia (O₂ saturation 84%).
  2. Chest x-ray: New pulmonary infiltrates involving multiple lobes.
  3. Systemic findings: Fever, leukocytosis, and elevated platelets due to inflammation and vaso-occlusive crisis.

 

Management of ACS:

 

  1. Exchange transfusion:
    • Rapidly reduces HbS levels, improves oxygenation, and alleviates vaso-occlusion.
    • Indicated for severe hypoxemia (O₂ saturation <90%), progressive infiltrates, or clinical deterioration.
  2. Supportive care:
    • Supplemental oxygen.
    • Pain management (e.g., opioids).
    • Empiric antibiotics to cover typical and atypical organisms (e.g., ceftriaxone and azithromycin).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucocorticoid therapy: Glucocorticoids are not routinely used in ACS due to risks of rebound vaso-occlusion.

 

Option C. Hydroxyurea: Hydroxyurea reduces the frequency of ACS by increasing HbF, but it is not a treatment for acute episodes.

 

Option D. Naloxone: The patient shows no evidence of opioid overdose (e.g., respiratory depression or altered mental status).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with acute chest syndrome and severe hypoxemia or progressive infiltrates, exchange transfusion is the definitive treatment to reduce HbS levels and prevent further complications.

The presenting diameter is sub-mento bregmatic, and vaginal delivery is possible if the mentum is anterior.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida woman is in active labor. On pelvic examination, the presenting part is identified as the face, and the mentum is anterior. Based on this presentation, which of the following is true about the presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The presenting diameter is sub-mento bregmatic, and vaginal delivery is possible if the mentum is anterior.

 

  • In face presentation, the presenting part is the face, and the denominator is the mentum (chin).
  • When the mentum is anterior, the presenting diameter is sub-mento bregmatic, which is compatible with vaginal delivery.
  • If the mentum is posterior, the diameter does not align well with the pelvic anatomy, making vaginal delivery impossible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The presenting diameter is sub-occipito bregmatic, and the labor is uneventful: This describes a vertex presentation with complete flexion, where the presenting diameter is sub-occipito bregmatic, and labor is typically uneventful. However, this does not apply to face presentation.

 

Option B. The presenting diameter is occipito-frontal, and the delivery will require a cesarean section: The occipito-frontal diameter is seen in a deflexed or military vertex presentation, where vaginal delivery may still be possible. This is not relevant to face presentation.

 

Option D. The presenting diameter is vertico-mental, and labor will always require a cesarean section: The vertico-mental diameter is seen in brow presentation, which usually results in obstructed labor and requires a cesarean section. It is not applicable to face presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Face presentation is characterized by the sub-mento bregmatic diameter when the mentum is anterior, allowing for vaginal delivery. 
  • In contrast, a posterior mentum orientation generally necessitates cesarean delivery due to obstructed labor.

Ureteral obstruction from a pelvic tumor

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios would GFR decrease, renal plasma flow remains constant, and filtration fraction decrease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ureteral obstruction from a pelvic tumor

 

Ureteral obstruction from a pelvic tumor leads to an increase in backpressure within the renal tubules. This increased pressure is transmitted backward into the glomerulus, reducing glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Renal plasma flow (RPF) typically remains constant in this situation, as the obstruction does not directly affect the blood flow to the kidneys. However, due to the decrease in GFR while RPF remains unchanged, the filtration fraction (FF) (which is the ratio of GFR to RPF) decreases.

 

  • GFR decreases because of the increased resistance to filtration caused by the backpressure in the renal tubules.
  • RPF remains constant as the obstruction does not interfere with blood flow to the kidneys.
  • FF decreases because GFR decreases while RPF remains constant, leading to a reduction in the ratio.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administration of a high-dose angiotensin II receptor blocker: Incorrect. Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) primarily work by dilating the efferent arteriole, which reduces glomerular pressure and decreases GFR. However, this also leads to a reduction in renal plasma flow (RPF), making the filtration fraction hard to maintain in the same manner. RPF does not remain constant, and this scenario doesn't match the question's description.

 

Option B. Dehydration causing increased plasma protein concentration: Incorrect. Dehydration increases plasma protein concentration, which raises the oncotic pressure in the glomerulus and reduces GFR. However, renal plasma flow would also decrease in dehydration due to hypovolemia (reduced circulating volume), making it not match the description where RPF remains constant. Additionally, the filtration fraction would likely increase due to a larger decrease in RPF than in GFR, not decrease.

 

Option C. Sympathetic activation leading to afferent arteriole constriction: Incorrect. Sympathetic activation causes vasoconstriction of the afferent arteriole, which reduces renal plasma flow (RPF) and GFR. The filtration fraction would not remain constant because both GFR and RPF would decrease in this situation. Hence, this scenario does not fit the question's parameters where RPF is constant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • PG: Glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure
  • πG: Glomerular capillary colloid osmotic pressure
  • PB: Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.text:
Which of the following features best distinguishes true Pelger-Huët cells from pseudo Pelger-Huët cells?

 

  1. Presence of coarse chromatin
  2. Presence of bilobed nuclei in neutrophils
  3. Not associated with hematologic malignancy
  4. Autosomal dominant inheritance
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3 and 4

 

Explanation:

 

True Pelger-Huët cells have no association with hematological malignancy and autosomal dominant inheritance

 

Pseudo-Pelger-Huët anomaly is typically observed in pathological conditions such as myelodysplastic syndromes, acute myeloid leukemia, or other hematologic malignancies.

 

Other Options:

 

1 and 2: Incorrect. Both true and pseudo-Pelger-Huët cells can exhibit bilobed nuclei and coarse chromatin. These morphological features alone cannot distinguish between the two conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of marasmus in an infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Severe muscle wasting

 

  • Severe muscle wasting is a hallmark feature of marasmus, a condition caused by a total calorie deficit. It is commonly seen in infants less than 1 year of age and is characterized by the absence of subcutaneous fat, prominent ribs, and wrinkled skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of edema: Edema is a characteristic of kwashiorkor, not marasmus.

 

Option C. Fatty liver: Fatty liver is also seen in kwashiorkor due to protein deficiency and impaired fat metabolism.

 

Option D. Apathy: Apathy is more typical of kwashiorkor, whereas children with marasmus are usually alert and have a voracious appetite.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Marasmus is caused by a total calorie deficit and presents with severe muscle wasting, absence of subcutaneous fat, and no edema. 
  • It typically affects infants under 1 year of age, and early nutritional intervention is crucial for recovery.

choices.text: Mortality in the occupational group is 50% lower than expected based on the general population.
Mortality in the occupational group is 50% higher than expected based on the general population.
The occupational group’s mortality is equivalent to the general population after adjustment for confounders.
The SMR represents a direct standardization approach using the general population's age-specific mortality rates.

questions.text: A study evaluates the mortality outcomes of a specific occupational group compared to the general population. The Standardized Mortality Ratio (SMR) is used to adjust for differences in the age distribution of the two populations. Which of the following is the most accurate interpretation of an SMR of 1.5?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mortality in the occupational group is 50% higher than expected based on the general population.

 

  • An SMR of 1.5 indicates that the mortality in the occupational group is 1.5 times or 50% higher than the expected number of deaths in the general population after accounting for age differences.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mortality in the occupational group is 50% lower than expected based on the general population: This would correspond to an SMR of 0.5, not 1.5.

 

Option C. The occupational group’s mortality is equivalent to the general population after adjustment for confounders: An SMR of 1.0 would indicate equivalence, not 1.5.

 

Option D. The SMR represents a direct standardization approach using the general population's age-specific mortality rates: The SMR is based on indirect standardization, not direct standardization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The SMR is an indirect standardization method used to compare observed and expected mortality, accounting for confounding variables like age.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis of this placental pathology?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Placenta succenturiata

 

  • Placenta succenturiata is characterized by the presence of one or more small accessory lobes connected to the main placenta by fetal blood vessels. 
  • Retention of these accessory lobes after delivery can lead to postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) and other complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Battledore placenta: In battledore placenta, the umbilical cord is attached at the edge of the placenta, resembling a badminton racket. It does not involve accessory lobes.

 

Option B. Circumvallate placenta: Circumvallate placenta presents as a raised, thickened ridge on the maternal side of the placenta due to a double fold of chorion and amnion. It does not feature accessory lobes.

 

Option D. Velamentous placenta: Velamentous placenta involves insertion of the umbilical cord into the membranes rather than the placental disk, with exposed vessels traversing the membranes. This condition does not involve accessory lobes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Placenta succenturiata involves the presence of accessory lobes, which may lead to postpartum hemorrhage if retained after delivery. 
  • Prompt ultrasound evaluation is critical to confirm retained tissue in such cases.

choices.text: Terminate the pregnancy at 34 weeks of gestation

questions.text: A 33-year-old pregnant woman presents for a routine antenatal checkup. She is at 33 weeks of gestation. An umbilical artery Doppler ultrasound is performed, as shown in the image. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immediate termination of pregnancy

 

  • The Doppler ultrasound shows absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery, which indicates severe placental insufficiency and is a hallmark of imminent fetal compromise.
  • This finding reflects increased resistance in the placental circulation, leading to significant impairment of oxygen and nutrient transfer to the fetus.
  • Immediate delivery is recommended in such cases to prevent fetal demise, especially when gestational age is ≥32 weeks.
  • Administration of steroids for fetal lung maturity would have been considered earlier if gestational age was <32 weeks and fetal well-being was not critically compromised.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue pregnancy till term: Continuing the pregnancy in the presence of absent or reversed end-diastolic flow is contraindicated due to the high risk of intrauterine fetal demise (IUFD).

 

Option C. Terminate the pregnancy at 34 weeks of gestation: Waiting until 34 weeks in a fetus with absent or reversed end-diastolic flow can lead to significant fetal hypoxia and IUFD. Immediate action is necessary.

 

Option D. Continue steroids until term: Steroid therapy for lung maturity is recommended in pregnancies <34 weeks; however, this is not applicable when the fetus is critically compromised. Immediate delivery is warranted.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Absent or reversed end-diastolic flow on umbilical artery Doppler is a sign of severe placental insufficiency, necessitating immediate delivery to prevent fetal demise, especially when the gestational age is ≥32 weeks.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with severe pain in his gums, foul breath, and bleeding during brushing for the past week. On examination, his gingivae are red, edematous, and covered with ulcers and a necrotic membrane. The patient reports poor oral hygiene and stress due to a recent workload increase. Which of the following organisms is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fusiform bacilli 

 

  • Vincent’s angina, also known as acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis (ANUG), is caused by a synergistic infection of Fusiform bacilli and Borrelia vincenti. 
  • It is characterized by painful, ulcerative lesions on the gingivae with necrotic membrane formation. 
  • Risk factors include poor oral hygiene, stress, and immunosuppression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus mutans: This organism is primarily associated with dental caries and not necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis.

 

Option C. Actinomyces israelii: This bacterium is the causative agent of actinomycosis, which typically presents as chronic, suppurative infections, often with draining sinuses.

 

Option D. Treponema pallidum: This organism causes syphilis, characterized by painless chancres and systemic manifestations, but not gingival necrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vincent's angina (acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis) is caused by Fusiform bacilli and Borrelia vincenti and presents with painful gingival ulcers, necrotic membranes, and foul breath.

questions.text: A neonate with Down syndrome presents with hepatosplenomegaly, severe anemia, and thrombocytopenia. Bone marrow biopsy shows megakaryoblasts. Which of the following best describes the leukemia most likely to develop in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) AML with megakaryoblastic differentiation

 

  • Down syndrome increases the risk of AML, particularly acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (AMKL), during infancy. 
  • Transient abnormal myelopoiesis (TAM) often precedes the development of AMKL in these patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ALL with B-cell phenotype: Common in older children with Down syndrome but less likely in neonates.

 

Option C. CML with t(9;22): Not associated with Down syndrome.

 

Option D. AML with monocytic differentiation: Less commonly associated with Down syndrome compared to AMKL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neonates with Down syndrome are at a high risk of developing AML with megakaryoblastic differentiation, particularly following transient abnormal myelopoiesis.

choices.text: Both the assertion and reason are true, and the reason correctly explains the assertion.
Both the assertion and reason are true, but the reason does not explain the assertion.
The assertion is true, but the reason is false.
Both the assertion and reason are false.

questions.text:
Assertion: Glucocorticoids inhibit fibroblast proliferation and extracellular matrix production.

Reason: Glucocorticoids suppress prostaglandin and leukotriene synthesis through inhibition of cyclooxygenase (COX).
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The assertion is true, but the reason is false.

 

  • Glucocorticoids inhibit fibroblast proliferation and extracellular matrix production, leading to delayed wound healing. 
  • The reason is false because glucocorticoids primarily act by inhibiting phospholipase A2, not cyclooxygenase (COX). 
  • This inhibits the synthesis of arachidonic acid and its downstream metabolites, including prostaglandins and leukotrienes.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Understand that glucocorticoids inhibit phospholipase A2, suppress fibroblast proliferation, and reduce extracellular matrix production, delaying wound healing.

choices.text: Confirmatory MRI showing irreversible damage to the brainstem and cortex
Presence of apnea during an apnea test after appropriate oxygenation and CO₂ monitoring
Bilateral absence of pupillary light reflexes without pharmacological influence
Isoelectric EEG recorded for a continuous period of at least 24 hours

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is brought to the ICU after a severe traumatic brain injury following a road traffic accident. He is unresponsive, with no spontaneous movements or brainstem reflexes on examination. Mechanical ventilation is maintaining his respiratory status. A neurologist is consulted to assess for brain death. Which of the following tests is most crucial in confirming the diagnosis of brain death based on Harvard criteria?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Presence of apnea during an apnea test after appropriate oxygenation and CO₂ monitoring

 

  • The Harvard criteria for brain death emphasize the importance of apnea testing, which is performed to confirm the absence of spontaneous respiratory effort despite sufficient CO₂ stimulation (typically arterial PaCO₂ >60 mm Hg). 
  • This test, combined with unresponsiveness, absence of brainstem reflexes, and an isoelectric EEG, forms the basis for declaring brain death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Confirmatory MRI showing irreversible damage to the brainstem and cortex: Imaging findings (e.g., MRI) can support the diagnosis of brain injury but are not part of the mandatory confirmatory tests for brain death.

 

Option C. Bilateral absence of pupillary light reflexes without pharmacological influence: Absence of pupillary light reflexes is a brainstem finding but is insufficient alone to confirm brain death; all other criteria must be fulfilled.

 

Option D. Isoelectric EEG recorded for a continuous period of at least 24 hours: An isoelectric EEG supports the diagnosis but does not replace the clinical determination of apnea or brainstem reflex absence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Brain death is a clinical diagnosis that requires unresponsiveness, absence of brainstem reflexes, and apnea confirmed by the apnea test. 
  • Confirmatory tests like EEG provide additional evidence but are not substitutes for clinical evaluation.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman, Mrs. Seema, presents with 2 weeks of worsening bilateral headaches, blurry vision, dizziness, and tingling sensation in her feet. She denies fever, night sweats, weight loss, or jaw pain but has had episodes of epistaxis.

 

History and Examination:

 

  • Medical history: Hypertension on chlorthalidone.
  • Physical findings:
    • Visual changes: Decreased visual acuity with dilated, segmented, tortuous retinal veins on fundoscopic exam (sausage-link appearance).
    • Neurologic findings: Decreased pinprick sensation and loss of ankle reflexes bilaterally, suggesting peripheral neuropathy.
    • Normal strength and moist mucous membranes.

 

Laboratory Results:

 

  • Hemoglobin: 10.2 g/dL (low)
  • Platelets: 180,000/mm³ (normal)
  • Total protein: 10.8 g/dL (elevated)
  • Albumin: 3.5 g/dL (normal), indicating a high globulin gap.
  • ESR: 90 mm/h (elevated).

 

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serum protein electrophoresis

 

  • This patient likely has Waldenström macroglobulinemia (WM), a lymphoplasmacytic neoplasm characterized by excessive production of monoclonal IgM antibodies.

 

Key Features Supporting WM:

 

  1. Hyperviscosity syndrome:
    • Headaches, blurry vision, dizziness, and dilated, tortuous retinal veins (sausage-link appearance).
    • Symptoms are due to increased blood viscosity caused by monoclonal IgM.
  2. Peripheral neuropathy:
    • IgM antibodies can target myelin-associated antigens.
  3. Elevated protein with globulin gap:
    • High total protein with normal albumin indicates monoclonal protein production.
  4. Anemia and elevated ESR:
    • Monoclonal protein increases ESR and can cause normocytic anemia.

 

Next Step:

 

  • Serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP): Detects monoclonal IgM.
  • Confirmation: Immunofixation and bone marrow biopsy showing >10% clonal B cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors and loop diuretics: Used for acute angle-closure glaucoma, which presents with painful, unilateral vision loss, not bilateral blurry vision with hyperviscosity signs.

 

Option B. High-dose glucocorticoids: Appropriate for giant cell arteritis (GCA), but this patient lacks jaw claudication, temporal artery tenderness, or ischemic visual loss.

 

Option C. Intravenous antihypertensives: Although the patient is hypertensive, her symptoms are not due to a hypertensive emergency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with hyperviscosity syndrome, peripheral neuropathy, and elevated protein with a globulin gap, suspect Waldenström macroglobulinemia and confirm with serum protein electrophoresis.

questions.text: Respiratory distress in noticed in a newborn. On examination, the neonate appears cyanotic with increased work of breathing. Auscultation reveals bowel sounds in the left hemithorax. Chest x-ray showed multiple air fluid levels. Which of the following congenital anomalies is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital diaphragmatic hernia 

 

  • The clinical picture of a cyanotic newborn with respiratory distress and auscultation revealing bowel sounds in the left hemithorax, combined with chest X-ray showing multiple air-fluid levels, is suggestive of a congenital anomaly that allows abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity. 
  • CDH is a defect in the diaphragm that allows abdominal organs to herniate into the thoracic cavity, impairing lung development and causing respiratory distress and cyanosis after birth.
  • The presence of bowel sounds in the thorax and air-fluid levels on X-ray are indicative of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tetralogy of Fallot: This is a congenital heart defect that includes four abnormalities: ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, and an overriding aorta. It leads to cyanotic congenital heart disease but does not cause bowel sounds in the thorax or air-fluid levels on X-ray.

 

Option C. Transposition of the great vessels: This is another congenital heart defect where the major vessels (the aorta and the pulmonary artery) are switched. It results in cyanosis but would not cause bowel sounds in the chest or air-fluid levels on X-ray.

 

Option D. Tracheoesophageal fistula: This condition involves an abnormal connection between the trachea and esophagus, which can lead to respiratory distress due to aspiration, but it would not cause bowel sounds in the thorax or the radiographic appearance of air-fluid levels as seen with CDH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is most likely responsible for the clinical findings of cyanosis, respiratory distress, and bowel sounds in the chest of a newborn, along with air-fluid levels on chest X-ray.

choices.text: It reduces the excitability of postsynaptic neurons by increasing IPSP generation.
It increases the excitability of postsynaptic neurons by decreasing IPSP generation.
It reduces the excitability of postsynaptic neurons by increasing EPSP generation.
It increases the excitability of postsynaptic neurons by decreasing EPSP generation.

questions.text: A drug that increases the conductance of chloride ion channels in the postsynaptic membrane is administered to a patient with epilepsy. Which of the following best describes the drug’s mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It reduces the excitability of postsynaptic neurons by increasing IPSP generation.

 

  • The drug enhances the opening of chloride ion channels, leading to increased chloride influx and hyperpolarization. 
  • This inhibits postsynaptic neuron excitability by generating more IPSPs, reducing the risk of seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It increases the excitability of postsynaptic neurons by decreasing IPSP generation: Incorrect; decreasing IPSPs would increase excitability, which is not the drug’s intended effect.

 

Option C. It reduces the excitability of postsynaptic neurons by increasing EPSP generation: Incorrect; increasing EPSPs would increase excitability, potentially worsening seizures.

 

Option D. It increases the excitability of postsynaptic neurons by decreasing EPSP generation: Incorrect; this is not the drug’s mechanism.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Drugs that enhance chloride ion conductance reduce neuronal excitability by increasing IPSP generation, which is useful in epilepsy management.

questions.text: Identify the plane marked in the picture below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coronal plane

 

  • The coronal plane divides the body into anterior (front) and posterior (back) sections. 
  • It is commonly used in radiological imaging, particularly for frontal views.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sagittal plane: Divides the body into left and right sections, not anterior and posterior.

 

Option C. Transverse plane: Divides the body into superior (upper) and inferior (lower) sections.

 

Option D. Oblique plane: Refers to a plane that makes an angle with the standard planes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The coronal plane is essential for dividing the body into anterior and posterior sections and is widely used in imaging.

questions.text: What triage category is a degloving injury going to be tagged?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Yellow

 

 

  • The yellow category in triage indicates urgent care is required, but the patient is likely to survive if treatment is provided within hours.
  • A degloving injury, which involves severe soft tissue loss and risk of infection, fits this category.
  • Immediate attention is not critical for survival, but delayed care can lead to complications such as infection, tissue necrosis, or systemic involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Red: This category is reserved for patients who are in immediate need of treatment to survive, such as those with tension pneumothorax, massive hemorrhage, or other life-threatening injuries. Degloving injuries, while severe, are not usually life-threatening in the immediate term.

 

Option C. Green: This category is for non-urgent cases, such as minor lacerations or simple fractures. Degloving injuries are much more severe and require urgent medical intervention.

 

Option D. Black: This category is for patients who are unsalvageable, such as those with severe brain damage or injuries incompatible with life. Degloving injuries do not fall into this category as the prognosis is good with timely intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A degloving injury is triaged as yellow because it is an urgent condition that requires medical treatment within hours but is not immediately life-threatening. 
  • Triage categories prioritize resource allocation during mass casualty events.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man, Mr. Raghav from Bengaluru, with a 7-year history of ankylosing spondylitis (AS) presents to the clinic with persistent back pain. He describes morning stiffness and nighttime aching that improves during the day. Despite high-dose naproxen, his pain relief is now moderate. Six months ago, he had right hip pain, but imaging showed no joint involvement.

 

Vitals: Within normal limits.


Examination: Limited spinal mobility and sacroiliac joint tenderness.


Laboratory findings:

 

  • Hemoglobin: 10.5 g/dL (mild anemia)
  • Platelets: 350,000/µL (normal)
  • Creatinine: 0.8 mg/dL (normal)
  • C-reactive protein: 11 mg/dL (elevated, indicating inflammation).

 

What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adalimumab

 

  • This patient has ankylosing spondylitis with persistent symptoms despite treatment with high-dose NSAIDs (naproxen). 
  • The next step is to initiate a tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) inhibitor, such as adalimumab, as it is highly effective in managing axial symptoms and improving quality of life in AS.

 

Key points about management:

 

  • First-line therapy: NSAIDs (e.g., naproxen, indomethacin).
  • Second-line therapy: TNF-α inhibitors for patients with persistent symptoms despite NSAIDs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methotrexate: Effective for peripheral arthritis in certain conditions (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis) but not for axial symptoms in AS.

 

Option C. Prednisone: Corticosteroids are not recommended for axial disease in AS as they provide limited benefit and have significant side effects with prolonged use.

 

Option D. Sulfasalazine: Effective for peripheral arthritis or extra-articular symptoms but not for axial symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In ankylosing spondylitis, TNF-α inhibitors (e.g., adalimumab) are the treatment of choice for persistent axial symptoms refractory to NSAIDs. 
  • Early and aggressive management prevents complications such as spinal fusion and improves functional outcomes.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman in active labor is found to have a transverse lie presentation during an ultrasound examination. There are no signs of labor progression, and the fetal heart rate is normal. What maternal position is often recommended to encourage fetal repositioning into a more favorable presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lateral recumbent position

 

  • The lateral recumbent position is often recommended for patients with a transverse lie to encourage the fetus to reposition into a more favorable cephalic or breech presentation.
  • This position relieves pressure from the umbilical cord and promotes better uteroplacental blood flow.
  • It is also used to relieve pressure on the presenting part in cases of cord prolapse until definitive management like a cesarean section is arranged.
  • Additional positions such as knee-chest or Trendelenburg positions may also be used in emergencies to reposition the fetus or alleviate pressure on the cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Supine position:

 

  • The supine position is contraindicated, especially in later pregnancy, due to the risk of supine hypotensive syndrome.
  • The heavy uterus compresses the inferior vena cava, reducing venous return to the heart, and leading to decreased cardiac output and uteroplacental perfusion.

 

Option C. Semi-Fowler's position:

 

  • This position may provide comfort to the mother during labor, but it is not effective for resolving a transverse lie presentation.
  • It does not encourage significant fetal repositioning.

 

Option D. Prone position:

 

  • Lying prone is uncomfortable and impractical during pregnancy due to the size of the uterus.
  • This position does not aid in repositioning the fetus and is rarely, if ever, recommended.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Transverse lie is a fetal malpresentation that requires immediate attention to avoid complications like cord prolapse.
  • Emergency cesarean delivery is typically the treatment of choice if labor progresses.
  • Positions like the lateral recumbent, knee-chest, or Trendelenburg may temporarily improve maternal-fetal outcomes by relieving cord pressure and promoting fetal repositioning.

It is inhibited by a fall in the insulin/glucagon ratio.

questions.text: Which of the following statement concerning gluconeogenesis is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is important in maintaining blood glucose during a 2-day fast.

 

  • During a 2-day fast, glycogen stores are depleted, and gluconeogenesis maintains blood glucose. 
  • This is an energy-requiring (endergonic) pathway (both ATP and GTP get hydrolyzed) that occurs primarily in the liver, with the kidneys becoming major glucose producers in prolonged fasting. 
  • Gluconeogenesis uses both mitochondrial and cytosolic enzymes and is stimulated by a fall in the insulin/glucagon ratio. 
  • Fatty acid degradation yields acetyl coenzyme A (CoA), which cannot be converted to glucose. 
  • This is because there is no net gain of carbons from acetyl CoA in the tricarboxylic acid cycle, and the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is physiologically irreversible. 
  • It is the carbon skeletons of most amino acids that are glucogenic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gluconeogenesis is an energy-producing (exergonic) process: Incorrect. Gluconeogenesis is an energy-requiring (endergonic) pathway. It consumes ATP and GTP in several steps, such as the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate (via pyruvate carboxylase) and oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate (via PEPCK). This energy expenditure is supported by fatty acid oxidation during fasting.

 

Option C. Gluconeogenesis is inhibited by a fall in the insulin/glucagon ratio: Incorrect. A fall in the insulin/glucagon ratio stimulates gluconeogenesis by promoting the transcription of key enzymes (e.g., PEPCK) and activating regulatory molecules such as fructose-2,6-bisphosphatase, which removes an inhibitor of gluconeogenesis.

 

Option D. Gluconeogenesis occurs in the cytosol of muscle cells to sustain glucose production: Incorrect. Gluconeogenesis primarily occurs in the liver and kidneys, not in muscle cells. Muscle cells lack glucose-6-phosphatase, the enzyme required to convert glucose-6-phosphate into free glucose for release into the bloodstream. Muscle glycogen serves only local energy needs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gluconeogenesis is the primary mechanism for maintaining blood glucose during prolonged fasting, especially after glycogen stores are depleted. 
  • This endergonic process occurs in the liver and kidneys and is stimulated by a low insulin/glucagon ratio, ensuring a continuous glucose supply for essential tissues like the brain and red blood cells.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with corneal scarring undergoes intraocular pressure (IOP) measurement. The clinician uses a tonometer shown in the image below. Which of the following devices is most likely depicted?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mackay-Marg tonometer

 

  • The Mackay-Marg tonometer is specifically designed to measure intraocular pressure in patients with irregular corneal surfaces, such as those with scarring. 
  • It employs a combination of applanation and indentation techniques, which allows it to overcome inaccuracies associated with other tonometry devices. 
  • The design ensures that corneal irregularities minimally affect the IOP measurement, making it suitable for such cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Goldmann tonometer: This device primarily uses applanation to measure IOP and is considered the gold standard for normal corneas. However, it is less accurate in cases of corneal irregularities.

 

 

Option C. Perkins tonometer: A portable version of the Goldmann tonometer that also relies solely on applanation, which is suboptimal for irregular corneas.

 

 

Option D. Schiotz tonometer: This uses indentation tonometry, which is less accurate compared to modern methods, especially in the presence of corneal abnormalities.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Mackay-Marg tonometer is an ideal tool for measuring IOP in patients with irregular corneal surfaces, as it integrates both applanation and indentation techniques to improve accuracy.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman undergoes a routine laparoscopic cholecystectomy for symptomatic cholelithiasis. During the procedure, the surgeon carefully identifies and dissects the structures within the Calot's triangle to avoid injury to surrounding anatomical structures. The image below was captured during the surgery.  Identify the structure as marked arrow.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystic duct

 

  • The cystic duct connects the gallbladder to the common bile duct.
  • It is one of the key structures dissected and identified in the Calot's triangle during a laparoscopic cholecystectomy to avoid iatrogenic injury. 
  • Identification and safe ligation of the cystic duct are essential steps in the procedure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cystic Artery: The cystic artery supplies blood to the gallbladder and is also found within Calot's triangle. However, it is smaller in caliber compared to the cystic duct and has a more tortuous course, often branching near its origin from the right hepatic artery.

 

Option C. Right Hepatic Artery: The right hepatic artery is a branch of the common hepatic artery and passes superior to Calot's triangle. While it is an important anatomical structure to identify and protect during surgery, it is not the structure marked in the given image.

 

Option D. Hepatic Duct: The common hepatic duct is located medially and inferiorly to the cystic duct and is a part of the biliary tree leading to the common bile duct. It is outside the Calot's triangle and would not appear in this specific marked location.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In laparoscopic cholecystectomy, careful identification of the cystic duct and artery within Calot's triangle is critical to prevent bile duct or vascular injuries. 
  • The cystic duct is a key structure connecting the gallbladder to the common bile duct and must be properly ligated to ensure successful surgical outcomes.

A 67-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with increasing dyspnea, purulent sputum production, and worsening shortness of breath over the past 2 days. His most recent FEV1 was 0.8 L, and he is on chronic oxygen therapy.

 

Examination Findings:

 

  • Vitals:
    • Temperature: 36.7°C (98°F).
    • Blood pressure: 130/90 mm Hg.
    • Pulse: 96/min.
    • Respirations: 20/min.
  • Respiratory:
    • Difficulty speaking in complete sentences.
    • Prolonged expiratory phase.
    • Decreased breath sounds.
  • Other:
    • Right ventricular lift.
    • Bilateral 1+ pedal edema.

Lab Findings:

  • Fingerstick glucose: 90 mg/dL.
  • Creatinine: 1.0 mg/dL.


Which of the following arterial blood gas (ABG) findings would most likely be compatible with his clinical picture?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) pH 7.30, bicarbonate 34 mEq/L, and anion gap of 8 mEq/L

 

  • This patient has an acute exacerbation of COPD (AECOPD), characterized by worsening dyspnea, increased sputum production, and sputum purulence.

 

Key Considerations for ABG:

 

  1. Primary abnormality:
    • In COPD exacerbations, hypercapnic respiratory acidosis occurs due to impaired gas exchange and CO2 retention.
  2. Compensation:
    • In chronic COPD, metabolic compensation increases bicarbonate to buffer the retained CO2, resulting in elevated bicarbonate levels.
  3. ABG Pattern:
    • Chronic hypercapnia with acute worsening:
      • Low pH (<7.35): Acidosis due to acute CO2 retention.
      • High bicarbonate (>30 mEq/L): Reflects metabolic compensation from chronic CO2 retention.
      • Normal anion gap: Not a metabolic acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. pH 7.30, bicarbonate 24 mEq/L, and anion gap of 10 mEq/L: This suggests an acute respiratory acidosis without metabolic compensation, inconsistent with chronic COPD.

 

Option C. pH 7.30, bicarbonate 14 mEq/L, and anion gap of 17 mEq/L: Suggests a metabolic acidosis with an elevated anion gap, seen in conditions like sepsis or lactic acidosis, not COPD exacerbation.

 

Option D. pH 7.47, bicarbonate 24 mEq/L, and anion gap of 10 mEq/L: This represents respiratory alkalosis and is inconsistent with COPD exacerbation, where CO2 retention causes acidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In COPD exacerbations with chronic hypercapnia, ABG typically shows respiratory acidosis (low pH) with metabolic compensation (elevated bicarbonate) and a normal anion gap.

questions.text: A patient with a history of mild cognitive impairment is started on trospium for overactive bladder. Which of the following mechanisms explains why trospium is the drug of choice in this population?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Its hydrophilic nature, preventing significant blood-brain barrier penetration.

 

  • Trospium is a muscarinic receptor antagonist with a hydrophilic molecular structure, limiting its ability to cross the BBB. 
  • This feature minimizes CNS side effects, such as confusion or cognitive decline, making it a safer option for patients with cognitive impairment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Its selective action on nicotinic receptors: Trospium does not act on nicotinic receptors; it is a muscarinic receptor antagonist.

 

Option C. Its ability to enhance acetylcholine release in the CNS: Trospium blocks muscarinic receptors and does not enhance acetylcholine release.

 

Option D. Its primary metabolism by cytochrome P450 enzymes, reducing drug interactions: Trospium is primarily excreted unchanged in the urine and does not rely heavily on CYP450 metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Trospium’s hydrophilic property limits CNS penetration, reducing the risk of cognitive side effects in patients with cognitive impairment.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with short stature, primary amenorrhea, and a webbed neck. On examination, she has low-set ears and lymphedema of the hands and feet. Which cardiac lesion is most likely in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coarctation of the aorta

 

  • Turner Syndrome (45,XO) is a chromosomal disorder associated with a variety of congenital abnormalities, including cardiac lesions. The most common cardiac manifestations in Turner Syndrome are:
    • Coarctation of the aorta: A narrowing of the aorta, which can lead to hypertension in the upper extremities and weak pulses in the lower extremities.
    • Bicuspid aortic valve: Present in many cases and predisposes to aortic stenosis or regurgitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atrial septal defect: While common in syndromes like Down Syndrome, it is not typically associated with Turner Syndrome.

 

Option C. Pulmonary valve stenosis: This is more characteristic of Noonan Syndrome, which can present with some overlapping features but affects both sexes.

 

Option D. Tetralogy of Fallot: This cyanotic congenital heart defect is not commonly seen in Turner Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Turner Syndrome (45,XO) is associated with congenital cardiac defects, most notably coarctation of the aorta and bicuspid aortic valve. 
  • Early recognition of these lesions is critical to prevent complications such as hypertension, left ventricular hypertrophy, and heart failure.

questions.text: Identify the type of drain shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closed suction

 

  • The drain shown in the image is a closed suction drain, which is commonly used in surgical procedures to remove fluids from a wound or body cavity. 
  • This type of drain helps prevent infection by containing fluids within a closed system and applying gentle suction to aid in drainage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open suction: In an open suction drain, the collected fluid is drained into an open system, such as a gauze or container without any closed mechanism, which increases the risk of infection and is generally not preferred in modern surgical settings.

 

Option C. Closed continuous: This term can sometimes refer to closed systems that have continuous drainage but may not specifically use suction. Closed continuous drains maintain a sealed environment but may differ in application compared to closed suction.

 

Option D. Semi closed: Semi-closed systems are less commonly used and may allow partial exposure to the external environment, reducing the containment of fluids and increasing infection risks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Closed suction drains provide a safe and effective way to manage post-operative fluid accumulation and reduce infection risks by containing fluids in a closed environment while applying suction to promote drainage.

questions.text: A 33-year-old pregnant woman at 11 weeks of gestation visits your clinic for prenatal counseling. She has a family history of chromosomal abnormalities and is concerned about the risk of aneuploidy in her fetus. She inquires about non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT). Which of the following statements about NIPT is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is used for the diagnosis of trisomy 13, 18 and 21.

 

  • Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is a screening test, not a diagnostic test. It utilizes cell-free fetal DNA (cffDNA) in the maternal serum to screen for common chromosomal aneuploidies, including trisomies 21, 18 and 13.
  • Although NIPT has a high sensitivity (99%) and specificity, confirmatory diagnostic tests such as chorionic villus sampling (CVS) or amniocentesis are required to establish a definitive diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum.: This statement is correct. NIPT relies on the presence of cell-free fetal DNA in the maternal circulation, which originates from trophoblastic cells of the placenta.

 

Option C. It can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation: This statement is correct. NIPT can be conducted after 10 weeks of pregnancy, when an adequate amount of cell-free fetal DNA becomes available in the maternal bloodstream.

 

Option D. It is done after the routine first-trimester ultrasound assessment: This statement is correct. NIPT is typically offered after a first-trimester ultrasound, which assesses fetal viability, dating, and nuchal translucency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is a screening tool that uses cell-free fetal DNA in maternal serum to screen for trisomies 21, 18 and 13 along with sex chromosome aneuploidies. 
  • It has high sensitivity and specificity but requires confirmatory testing (CVS or amniocentesis) for diagnosis. 
  • NIPT can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation and is often preceded by a first-trimester ultrasound.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman undergoes parathyroidectomy for primary hyperparathyroidism. Before surgery, she experienced bone pain and had a compression fracture of the T11 vertebra.

 

Preoperative Lab Results:

 

  • Calcium: 11.3 mg/dL (high)
  • Phosphorus: 2.0 mg/dL (low)
  • Albumin: 3.7 g/dL (normal)
  • Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL (normal)
  • TSH: 2.1 µU/mL (normal)
  • Alkaline phosphatase: 210 U/L (high)
  • PTH: 235 pg/mL (high)
  • 25-hydroxyvitamin D: 14 ng/mL (low)

 

Postoperative Course:

 

  • Normal serum calcium on day 1 post-op.
  • On day 3, the patient presents with perioral numbness, hand spasms, and positive Chvostek’s sign.

 

ECG is shown below: 

 

 

Which of the following laboratory results would be expected now?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Low calcium, high phosphorus, and low PTH

 

  • The patient is experiencing postoperative hypocalcemia, most likely due to hungry bone syndrome, a condition following parathyroidectomy in patients with significant bone disease from long-standing primary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Key Features Supporting Hungry Bone Syndrome:

 

  • Symptoms of hypocalcemia: Perioral numbness, hand spasms, and Chvostek’s sign.
  • ECG changes: Prolonged QT interval, commonly seen in hypocalcemia.

 

Mechanism of Laboratory Changes:

 

  1. Low calcium: Calcium is rapidly deposited into the bones after PTH withdrawal.
  2. High phosphorus: PTH normally increases renal phosphorus excretion; without it, phosphorus levels rise.
  3. Low PTH: The remaining parathyroid glands are suppressed postoperatively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High calcium, low phosphorus, and high PTH: Describes untreated primary hyperparathyroidism, not the postoperative state.

 

Option B. Low calcium, high phosphorus, and high PTH: PTH levels would not remain high after successful parathyroidectomy unless there was incomplete gland removal.

 

Option C. Low calcium, low phosphorus, and normal PTH: More typical of vitamin D deficiency, which is not the current scenario.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Hungry bone syndrome is a common cause of post-parathyroidectomy hypocalcemia, characterized by low calcium, high phosphorus, low PTH, and ECG findings of prolonged QT interval. 
  • Prompt calcium and vitamin D supplementation are essential.

choices.text: Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days
