questions.text: Which of the following statements about fetal circulation is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days

 

  • The foramen ovale is an interatrial opening allowing blood to bypass the fetal lungs by flowing from the right atrium to the left atrium.
  • Functional closure occurs immediately after birth due to increased left atrial pressure. However, the anatomical closure, where the tissue grows together and permanently seals the opening, typically takes 1 month to 1 year.
  • Hence, stating that anatomical closure occurs by 3 to 5 days is false.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anatomical closure of ductus venosus is by 3 to 7 days:

 

  • The ductus venosus connects the umbilical vein to the inferior vena cava, allowing oxygenated blood to bypass the liver.
  • It undergoes functional closure within minutes after birth and anatomical closure within 3 to 7 days, forming the ligamentum venosum. This statement is correct.

 

Option C. Right umbilical vein is absent:

 

  • In fetal circulation, only the left umbilical vein persists to carry oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus. The right umbilical vein regresses early in development. This is correct.

 

Option D. Anatomical closure of ductus arteriosus is by 2 to 3 weeks:

 

  • The ductus arteriosus connects the pulmonary artery to the descending aorta, bypassing the fetal lungs.
  • It undergoes functional closure within the first 10 to 96 hours after birth due to increased oxygen and decreased prostaglandins. Anatomical closure typically takes 2 to 3 weeks, forming the ligamentum arteriosum. This is correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anatomical closure of the foramen ovale takes 1 month to a year.

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotic combinations is most likely to exhibit antagonism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ampicillin and chloramphenicol.

 

  • The combination of a bactericidal agent (ampicillin) with a bacteriostatic agent (chloramphenicol) can be antagonistic because bactericidal agents require active bacterial division, which is inhibited by bacteriostatic agents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cephalexin and gentamicin: Incorrect. Cephalexin and gentamicin target different bacterial processes and are not antagonistic.

 

Option C. Ciprofloxacin and piperacillin: Incorrect. Ciprofloxacin and piperacillin do not exhibit antagonism.

 

Option D. Vancomycin and amikacin: Incorrect. Vancomycin and amikacin act on different targets and can have synergistic effects.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Combinations of bacteriostatic and bactericidal antibiotics may result in antagonistic interactions.

questions.text: Anaphylactoid reactions are most common with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gelatin

 

  • Anaphylactoid reactions occur most frequently with gelatin, with an incidence of approximately 0.35%. 
  • Gelatin is a colloid that has a higher antigenic potential, predisposing patients to allergic and anaphylactoid reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Albumin: Although albumin can cause allergic reactions, its antigenicity is lower compared to gelatin.

 

Option C. Hydroxyethyl starch: Hydroxyethyl starch has the lowest incidence of anaphylactoid reactions (less than 0.06%) among colloids, making it relatively safe in this regard.

 

Option D. Dextran: Dextran has an intermediate risk of anaphylactoid reactions (0.28%), and its risk can be reduced by pretreatment with a hapten inhibitor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Anaphylactoid reactions are most commonly associated with gelatin-based colloids, while hydroxyethyl starch has the lowest incidence of these reactions among commonly used colloids.

choices.text: The classification and systematic organization of diseases based on their characteristics and etiologies
The study of the distribution and determinants of health-related states in specified populations
The branch of medicine dealing with the prevention of diseases and promotion of health
The investigation and study of the causes of diseases

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the concept of nosology?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The classification and systematic organization of diseases based on their characteristics and etiologies

 

  • Nosology is the branch of medical science that deals with the classification and systematic organization of diseases. 
  • It aims to categorize diseases based on shared features such as symptoms, etiology, or pathology, providing a standardized framework for diagnosis, research, and treatment. 
  • Nosology forms the foundation for systems like the International Classification of Diseases (ICD).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The study of the distribution and determinants of health-related states in specified populations: Describes epidemiology, which focuses on the study of the distribution and determinants of health and disease in populations. While nosology aids in disease classification, it does not directly deal with population-based studies.

 

Option C. The branch of medicine dealing with the prevention of diseases and promotion of health: Refers to public health, which focuses on disease prevention and health promotion, rather than classification or organization of diseases.

 

Option D. The investigation and study of the causes of diseases: Refers to etiology, the study of the causes of diseases. While nosology may incorporate etiological factors, it is primarily concerned with classification, not the causes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nosology refers to the classification of diseases based on shared characteristics such as etiology, pathology, and clinical presentation, serving as the foundation for systematic disease diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication to bag and mask ventilation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diaphragmatic hernia

 

  • Patients with diaphragmatic hernia are at a greater risk of aspiration during bag and mask ventilation. 
  • This occurs because air entering the stomach increases intragastric pressure, leading to a higher risk of regurgitation and aspiration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obstructive sleep apnea: This condition is not a contraindication for bag and mask ventilation but requires careful monitoring.

 

Option C. Pneumothorax: Pneumothorax is not a direct contraindication to bag and mask ventilation but warrants caution if positive pressure ventilation is performed.

 

Option D. Severe asthma: Severe asthma is not a contraindication to bag and mask ventilation; however, careful titration of ventilation pressures is required to prevent air trapping.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated in patients at high risk of aspiration, such as those with diaphragmatic hernia or undergoing rapid sequence induction, and should be used cautiously in cases of severe facial trauma or unstable cervical spine fractures.

questions.text: A researcher is developing antiviral drugs targeting RNA-dependent RNA polymerase. Which of the following viruses is most likely to be affected by this drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Influenza virus

 

  • Influenza virus belongs to the Orthomyxoviridae family, which is a negative-stranded RNA virus. 
  • It relies on RNA-dependent RNA polymerase for mRNA synthesis and genome replication, making it susceptible to drugs targeting this enzyme.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis C virus: Positive-stranded RNA virus that directly uses its RNA genome as mRNA.

 

Option C. Rotavirus: Double-stranded RNA virus that uses its own RNA polymerase but is not classified as a negative-stranded RNA virus.

 

Option D. Human immunodeficiency virus: Retrovirus that uses reverse transcriptase, not RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Negative-stranded RNA viruses, like Influenza virus, depend on RNA-dependent RNA polymerase for replication, making it a viable drug target.

choices.text: Immobilization in a Minerva cast or halo cast

questions.text: A 12-month-old boy who has a neck injury from a motor vehicle accident. He is neurologically intact without any other injuries. Following successful closed reduction of the fracture, what is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immobilization in a Minerva cast or halo cast

 

  • A Minerva cast or halo cast is a rigid immobilization device that provides superior stability to the cervical spine. 
  • For a young child with a cervical spine injury, especially after closed reduction of a fracture, a Minerva cast, or halo cast is preferred to ensure that the cervical spine remains stable and is not subject to movement during the healing process.
  • Minerva cast extends from the shoulders up to the head, providing a stable and rigid form of immobilization of the neck and upper spine.
  • Halo cast involves a ring placed around the head, with pins that attach to the skull and a body vest that keeps the spine immobilized.
  • These devices are generally used in young children and infants who require immobilization of the cervical spine due to their ability to prevent movement more effectively than a cervical collar. 
  • The best next step in management for this child would be to ensure adequate immobilization using either a Minerva cast or halo cast following the successful closed reduction of the fracture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immobilization in a cervical collar:

 

  • Cervical collars are commonly used to stabilize the neck in adults and sometimes in children with neck injuries. 
  • However, in a 12-month-old child, a cervical collar is less effective compared to more rigid forms of immobilization. 
  • Infants have more flexibility in their cervical spine and are more likely to move, reducing the effectiveness of a simple cervical collar. 
  • In children under 2 years of age, a Minerva cast, or halo cast is generally preferred for better immobilization.
  • While a cervical collar may be used in some pediatric neck injuries, it is not the best choice because it does not provide enough stability in a 12-month-old child.

 

Option C. Anterior odontoid fixation:

 

  • Anterior odontoid fixation is a surgical procedure used to treat fractures of the odontoid process (the peg-like structure on the second cervical vertebra, or C2). 
  • This procedure is often considered for adults or older children with specific types of odontoid fractures that require surgical stabilization. 
  • However, this procedure would not be the first step in a 12-month-old child with a neck injury unless there were specific indications of an odontoid fracture requiring surgical intervention.
  • This is an invasive surgical procedure, which is not the first-line management for this patient. The child does not need anterior odontoid fixation unless the fracture is more complex or requires surgical stabilization.

 

Option D. Posterior C1-C2 instrumented arthrodesis:

 

  • Posterior C1-C2 instrumented arthrodesis (fusion) is a surgical procedure often used to stabilize the upper cervical spine, specifically the atlantoaxial joint (C1-C2), in cases of instability, fractures, or dislocations. 
  • This procedure is typically considered in cases of severe instability or when non-surgical management options fail or are not effective.
  • In this case, the child is neurologically intact, and the fracture has been successfully reduced. This means that immediate surgery such as instrumented arthrodesis is not necessary. 
  • Non-surgical management with immobilization (like a Minerva cast or halo cast) is typically sufficient.
  • Surgical stabilization with posterior fusion is not indicated at this stage in a child with a successful closed reduction and no neurological compromise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The best next step in management for this 12-month-old child after successful closed reduction of a cervical spine fracture is Immobilization in a Minerva cast or halo cast. 
  • These methods provide the most effective stabilization for a child’s cervical spine and help prevent movement that could compromise healing.

questions.text:
A 82-year-old woman, Mrs. Shanta from Chennai, presents with a wound on her right lower leg that has been gradually expanding over the past 2 weeks. She has a long-standing history of chronic lower-extremity swelling. Her caregiver reports that the patient often complains of her legs feeling tired and heavy, especially when sitting for long periods, which improves with walking. She denies fever, chills, warmth, or purulent drainage from the wound.

 

Examination Findings:

 

  • Vital signs: Normal
  • Cardiovascular: Normal heart rate, rhythm, and jugular venous pressure.
  • Lungs: Clear on auscultation.

 

Lower extremities: 

 

 

What is the best next step in management, in addition to wound dressing recommendations?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Compression garments and aspirin

 

  • The clinical presentation is consistent with chronic venous insufficiency (CVI) and a resulting venous stasis ulcer.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ankle-brachial index: Used for evaluating peripheral arterial disease (PAD), which is unlikely in this patient as pulses are palpable and there are no signs of ischemia.

 

Option C. Furosemide: Not indicated for CVI as the edema is due to venous stasis, not fluid overload.

 

Option D. Oral antibiotic therapy: There are no signs of infection (e.g., warmth, erythema, purulent drainage), so antibiotics are unnecessary.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Compression therapy and wound care are the cornerstone treatments for venous stasis ulcers, while aspirin may further aid in healing. 
  • Accurate diagnosis and targeted therapy are essential for optimal outcomes.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a 3-month history of feeling excessively sleepy during the day despite adequate nighttime sleep. He also describes sudden episodes of muscle weakness triggered by laughter or emotional excitement. Polysomnography shows decreased REM sleep latency. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Narcolepsy

 

  • Narcolepsy is characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness, cataplexy (sudden muscle weakness triggered by emotions), and reduced REM sleep latency on polysomnography.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Obstructive sleep apnea: Features include snoring and nocturnal apneic episodes, which are not described here.

 

Option C. Idiopathic hypersomnia: Does not involve cataplexy or altered REM sleep latency.

 

Option D. Major depressive disorder: May cause fatigue but not cataplexy or changes in REM sleep latency.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Narcolepsy with cataplexy (Type 1 Narcolepsy) is characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness, cataplexy, sleep paralysis, and hypnagogic hallucinations. 
  • Cataplexy is a sudden and transient episode of muscle weakness accompanied by full conscious awareness, typically triggered by emotions.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents with chronic sinusitis and productive cough. A nasal biopsy reveals ciliated cell degeneration, characterized by shedding and loss of cilia. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute viral respiratory infection

 

  • Ciliocytophthoria refers to the degeneration of ciliated cells seen in acute viral infections, such as the common cold or influenza. 
  • This phenomenon involves loss of cilia, leading to impaired mucociliary clearance and transient susceptibility to secondary infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kartagener syndrome: Characterized by ciliary immotility due to structural defects, not degeneration.

 

Option C. Cystic fibrosis: Involves normal ciliary structure but thick mucus impairs clearance.

 

Option D. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease: Associated with epithelial metaplasia and mucus hypersecretion, not ciliated cell degeneration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ciliocytophthoria occurs in acute viral respiratory infections, resulting in ciliated cell degeneration and impaired clearance.

choices.text: G to A mutation in the Pre-C region
Stop codon mutation in the P region

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient with chronic hepatitis B infection is found to have undetectable levels of HBeAg despite active viral replication. Which mutation in the hepatitis B virus genome is most likely responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) G to A mutation in the Pre-C region

 

  • Pre-core mutants of hepatitis B virus are unable to synthesize HBeAg due to a G to A mutation at the 28th amino acid in the Pre-C region. 
  • This mutation introduces a stop codon, preventing the synthesis of HBeAg. 
  • These mutants can still produce HBcAg and replicate actively, leading to high viral loads despite the absence of HBeAg.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mutation in the S region: This region codes for HBsAg, which is unrelated to the production of HBeAg.

 

Option B. Mutation in the C region: The C region codes for HBcAg, not HBeAg, and is not affected in Pre-core mutants.

 

Option D. Stop codon mutation in the P region: The P region codes for viral polymerase and is unrelated to HBeAg synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Pre-core mutants of hepatitis B virus have a G to A mutation in the Pre-C region, resulting in a stop codon that prevents HBeAg synthesis while allowing active viral replication.

choices.text: Record daily maximum and minimum temperatures
Assess humidity levels in the environment

questions.text: What is the most likely function of the instrument shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Record daily maximum and minimum temperatures

 

  • The instrument in the image is a Six's Maximum and Minimum Thermometer, designed specifically for recording the highest (maximum) and lowest (minimum) temperatures during a set period. 
  • It consists of two bulbs (one filled with alcohol, the other with mercury or another liquid) and movable markers that indicate the extreme temperatures reached. 
  • It is commonly used in meteorology and environmental studies.
  • How it works:
    • The alcohol in the bulb expands or contracts with temperature changes, moving the mercury column.
    • The markers in the thermometer stay at the positions of the maximum and minimum temperatures until reset.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Measure real-time ambient temperature: Incorrect. The instrument does not measure real-time ambient temperature, but rather the extremes of temperature within a period. For real-time measurements, a simple liquid-in-glass thermometer or digital thermometer is used.

 

Option C. Assess humidity levels in the environment: Incorrect. Humidity levels are measured using a hygrometer, not this thermometer.

 

Option D. Calculate wind speed and direction: Incorrect. Wind speed and direction are assessed using an anemometer and wind vane, not a thermometer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Six's Maximum and Minimum Thermometer is a specialized instrument used for recording the maximum and minimum temperatures over a period. It is a vital tool in meteorology for environmental monitoring and weather forecasting.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a one-year history of chronic diarrhea, unintentional weight loss, and arthralgia. Physical examination reveals generalized lymphadenopathy. A duodenal biopsy is performed. Which of the following histological image is most specific for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 

 

 

  • The patient’s presentation of chronic diarrhea, weight loss, arthralgia, and lymphadenopathy strongly suggests Whipple’s disease, caused by Tropheryma whipplei. 
  • The hallmark histological finding in Whipple’s disease is foamy macrophages in the lamina propria of the small intestine, which are PAS-positive due to bacterial content. 
  • This finding confirms the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Image A: 

 

 

Represents glomerular changes unrelated to gastrointestinal pathology or Whipple's disease.

 

Option B. Image B: 

 

 

Suggests reactive lymphoid hyperplasia, which is nonspecific and not diagnostic.

 

Option D. Image D: 

 

 

Characteristic of celiac disease, which is associated with villous atrophy and intraepithelial lymphocytosis, but does not present with systemic symptoms such as arthralgia or lymphadenopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Whipple’s disease is diagnosed histologically by PAS-positive macrophages in the lamina propria, which are pathognomonic and correlate with systemic and gastrointestinal manifestations of the disease.

choices.text: Use of immunosuppressive therapy targeting T cells post-transplantation.
HLA mismatching to avoid sex-specific antigen presentation.

questions.text: A transplant surgeon is discussing potential risks with a female patient who will receive a liver transplant from her male sibling. Which of the following interventions would most likely mitigate the effects of the Eichwald-Silmser effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Use of immunosuppressive therapy targeting T cells post-transplantation.

 

  • Immunosuppressive therapy targeting T cells is effective in preventing rejection caused by the Eichwald-Silmser effect. 
  • The rejection occurs because T cells in the female recipient recognize Y chromosome-derived antigens from the male donor. 
  • Immunosuppressive agents suppress the immune response, reducing the risk of graft rejection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administration of anti-thymocyte globulin pre-transplantation: Incorrect. While this may reduce T-cell activity, it does not address the specific issue of Y chromosome-derived antigen recognition.

 

Option C. Pre-transplant desensitization using donor lymphocytes: Incorrect. This is used to reduce alloimmune responses, but it is not specific to the Eichwald-Silmser effect.

 

Option D. HLA mismatching to avoid sex-specific antigen presentation: Incorrect. HLA mismatching increases the likelihood of rejection and is not a solution to this sex-linked incompatibility.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • The Eichwald-Silmser effect highlights the importance of immunosuppressive therapy to prevent rejection due to Y chromosome-derived antigens in male-to-female transplants.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with weakness of dorsiflexion of big toe and decreased sensation over the dorsum of foot. His reflexes are normal. Which of the following is possibly affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Extraforaminal L5-S1 disc herniation

 

  • An extraforaminal L5-S1 disc herniation occurs outside the main vertebral foramen, affecting the L5 nerve root in particular. 
  • Since the L5 nerve root provides motor function for dorsiflexion of the big toe and sensory input to the dorsum of the foot, this type of herniation can explain both the weakness in dorsiflexion of the big toe and the decreased sensation over the dorsum of the foot. 
  • Additionally, an extraforaminal herniation is less likely to affect reflexes, which is consistent with the patient’s normal reflexes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterolateral L3-L4 disc herniation:

 

  • L3-L4 disc herniation typically affects the L4 nerve root. 
  • Common symptoms include weakness of the quadriceps (hip flexion and knee extension) and sensory loss around the medial aspect of the knee or anterior thigh. 
  • The weakness of dorsiflexion and sensory loss over the dorsum of the foot is more likely associated with an L5 nerve root involvement rather than the L4 nerve root.

 

Option B. Posterolateral L5-S1 disc herniation:

 

  • L5-S1 disc herniation usually affects the S1 nerve root, which is responsible for controlling the muscles involved in plantar flexion of the foot (e.g., gastrocnemius and soleus). 
  • Symptoms of S1 nerve root involvement include weakness of plantar flexion and sensory loss along the lateral foot and little toe. 
  • The patient's symptoms of dorsiflexion weakness and dorsum of the foot sensory loss are more consistent with L5 nerve root involvement.

 

Option D. Extraforaminal L4-L5 disc herniation:

 

  • An extraforaminal L4-L5 disc herniation would primarily affect the L4 nerve root, leading to symptoms such as weakness in hip flexion, knee extension, and sensory loss in the medial aspect of the leg. 
  • The L4 nerve root does not typically cause weakness in dorsiflexion of the big toe or sensory loss over the dorsum of the foot, which is more indicative of L5 nerve root involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The patient's symptoms are most likely due to an extraforaminal L5-S1 disc herniation, which can cause weakness of dorsiflexion of the big toe and decreased sensation over the dorsum of the foot. 
  • This is because the L5 nerve root is involved, which controls both motor function for dorsiflexion and sensory function for the dorsum of the foot.

questions.text:
A newborn is evaluated for congenital anomalies. Imaging reveals diffuse intracranial calcifications and hydrocephalus. Ophthalmologic examination shows chorioretinitis. 

 

 

Which of the following congenital infections is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Toxoplasmosis

 

Toxoplasmosis is characterized by diffuse intracranial calcifications, hydrocephalus, and chorioretinitis, a triad commonly associated with congenital toxoplasmosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytomegalovirus (CMV): Typically associated with periventricular calcifications, not diffuse calcifications.

 

Option C. Rubella: Sensorineural hearing loss, cataracts, and patent ductus arteriosus are characteristic, but calcifications are not a key feature.

 

Option D. Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV): Commonly presents with vesicles and microcephaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Toxoplasmosis should be suspected in newborns with diffuse intracranial calcifications, hydrocephalus, and chorioretinitis.
  • Early diagnosis and treatment prevent long-term sequelae.

questions.text: A 47-year-old multiparous woman presents to the gynecology clinic with complaints of heavy, irregular bleeding following a few months of amenorrhea. She attributes the symptoms to approaching menopause. On examination, her BMI is 30 kg/m². Her vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal and pelvic examinations are unremarkable, with a normal-sized uterus. An ultrasound reveals a thickened endometrium, and an office biopsy confirms endometrial hyperplasia without atypia. What is the best treatment option for her?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insertion of LNG-IUS

 

  • The levonorgestrel intrauterine system (LNG-IUS), such as Mirena, is the first-line treatment for endometrial hyperplasia without atypia.
  • It provides local delivery of progestogen to the endometrium, reducing thickness and inducing regression of hyperplasia.
  • Treatment should be continued for at least 6 months, and patients should undergo regular surveillance, including endometrial sampling at 6-month intervals.
  • LNG-IUS is highly effective, especially in patients who are not candidates for surgery or want to preserve their uterus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy:

 

  • Hysterectomy is indicated in endometrial hyperplasia with atypia or in cases where hyperplasia persists or progresses despite medical treatment.
  • It is not the first-line treatment for simple endometrial hyperplasia without atypia.

 

Option B. Endometrial ablation:

 

  • Endometrial ablation destroys the endometrium but does not provide a tissue diagnosis or allow for surveillance.
  • It is not appropriate for patients with endometrial hyperplasia as it may mask a potential progression to malignancy.

 

Option D. Combined oral contraceptives (COCs):

 

  • COCs may regulate bleeding but are not as effective as LNG-IUS or continuous progestogens in inducing histological regression of hyperplasia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Endometrial hyperplasia without atypia is effectively treated with LNG-IUS due to its local progestogenic effect, reducing the risk of progression to endometrial cancer. 
  • Regular surveillance is essential, and patients with atypia should be considered for hysterectomy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old public health officer is tasked with designing a health initiative to optimize the use of limited resources in a rural area with high infant mortality rates. She needs to implement a framework that provides a standardized set of rules to ensure efficiency and systematic application of efforts in addressing the issue. Which of the following best describes such a framework?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Procedure

 

  • A procedure is a standardized set of rules or protocols developed to ensure that tasks are carried out systematically and efficiently. 
  • It helps in maximizing the effective use of resources and efforts by guiding the process, leaving minimal room for error or redundancy. 
  • In the context of public health, procedures are critical for implementing health initiatives efficiently.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Programme: Refers to a sequence of activities designed to accomplish objectives, often with a broader focus than specific procedural rules. While a programme encompasses procedures, it also includes goals, timelines, and resource allocation strategies.

 

Option C. Schedule: A time-bound sequence for executing tasks. Schedules organize tasks but do not provide detailed procedural guidance for how they should be performed.

 

Option D. Target: Represents the end goal or measurable achievement expected from a programme or procedure. Targets do not outline the steps or rules for achieving those goals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A procedure is a critical tool in public health that ensures the systematic and efficient use of resources by providing clear, standardized rules for task execution. 
  • This is distinct from broader frameworks like programmes or specific milestones like targets.

questions.text: Intramembranous ossification is seen in which bones?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Maxilla

 

  • The maxilla (upper jaw) is a flat bone that primarily forms through intramembranous ossification. 
  • This means that the mesenchymal cells in the region directly differentiate into bone cells without first forming a cartilage model. 
  • This is typical of the facial bones, particularly the maxilla, mandible, and some other cranial bones, as these bones need to form early in development to protect the brain and support facial structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pelvis:

 

  • The pelvis is largely formed through endochondral ossification, not intramembranous ossification. 
  • In endochondral ossification, bone forms from a cartilage model. 
  • While some parts of the pelvis may have some involvement in intramembranous ossification during early development, the majority of the pelvic bones (like the ilium, ischium, and pubis) undergo endochondral ossification, particularly in the later stages of skeletal development. 

 

Option C. Long bones:

 

  • Long bones (such as the femur, tibia, and humerus) do not form through intramembranous ossification. 
  • Instead, they undergo endochondral ossification. In this process, cartilage serves as a template for the formation of bone. 
  • The cartilage model gradually gets replaced by bone as the long bones grow in length and develop the necessary structural support for weight-bearing. 

 

Option D. Both A & B:

 

  • This option suggests that both the pelvis and maxilla form through intramembranous ossification, but as explained, the pelvis primarily undergoes endochondral ossification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intramembranous ossification is primarily seen in the flat bones of the skull, face, and some parts of the clavicle. 
  • The maxilla is one of the bones that forms through this process. 
  • The pelvis, however, undergoes endochondral ossification, and long bones also follow the endochondral process.

choices.text: Defect in type III collagen synthesis
Defect in elastin and collagens I and III

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with easy bruising, hyperextensible skin, and recurrent joint dislocations. She is found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Which of the following connective tissue defects best explains her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Defect in type III collagen synthesis

 

  • The clinical features of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (vascular subtype), including hyperextensible skin, easy bruising, and aneurysm formation, are due to defective type III collagen synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Defective cross-linking of collagen fibers: Associated with scurvy due to vitamin C deficiency, not Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

 

Option C. Defect in fibrillin synthesis: Associated with Marfan syndrome.

 

Option D. Defect in elastin and collagens I and III: Seen in Loeys-Dietz syndrome, not Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (vascular subtype) results from a defect in type III collagen synthesis, leading to aneurysm formation and connective tissue fragility.
  • Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome Type IV (Vascular type):
    • Caused by a defect in type III collagen synthesis
    • COL3A1 gene mutation
  • Key features:
    • Thin, translucent skin
    • Easy bruising
    • Arterial and organ rupture (e.g., aortic aneurysm, uterine rupture)
    • Mild joint hypermobility (not as extreme as classic type)
  • Mnemonic for Vascular EDS:
    • "Type III = 3 things: Bruising, Aneurysms, and Arterial Rupture"

questions.text: A pediatrician evaluates an infant with a strong sweaty feet odor and suspecting a metabolic condition orders urine organic acid analysis. The test confirms an abnormal accumulation of a particular organic acid. Given the enzyme involved, which cofactor supplementation might help in managing this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Riboflavin (Vitamin B2)

 

  • Isovaleryl-CoA dehydrogenase, the enzyme deficient in isovaleric aciduria, requires riboflavin (Vitamin B2) as a cofactor. 
  • Supplementing riboflavin can enhance residual enzyme activity, potentially ameliorating symptoms by decreasing isovaleric acid accumulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B12 (Cobalamin): Vitamin B12 is essential for the function of methylmalonyl-CoA mutase, not isovaleryl-CoA dehydrogenase.

 

Option B. Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine): Vitamin B6 is a cofactor for transaminases, not related to the leucine degradation pathway.

 

Option C. Biotin: Biotin is a cofactor for carboxylase enzymes, not dehydrogenases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Appreciate that riboflavin supplementation can potentially improve the clinical management of isovaleric aciduria by enhancing the activity of residual isovaleryl-CoA dehydrogenase. 
  • This approach underscores the importance of cofactor support in treating certain metabolic enzyme deficiencies.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient is scheduled for a contrast-enhanced imaging procedure. The physician is concerned about the risks associated with the use of contrast agents, particularly in diabetic patients. Which of the following contrast agents cannot be safely used in diabetic patients?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ionic high-osmolar contrast media (HOCM)

 

  • Ionic high-osmolar contrast media (HOCM), such as Diatrizoate, are not recommended for diabetic patients due to the increased risk of nephrotoxicity and contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN). 
  • These agents have higher osmolality and can worsen kidney function in patients with pre-existing renal issues, such as those with diabetes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nonionic low-osmolar contrast media (LOCM): Nonionic LOCM, such as Iohexol, have lower osmolality and are generally safer for diabetic patients because they have a reduced risk of nephrotoxicity.

 

Option C. Nonionic iso-osmolar contrast media (IOCM): Nonionic IOCM, such as Iodixanol, have iso-osmolar properties and are considered even safer than LOCM for diabetic patients, especially for those with renal impairment.

 

Option D. Barium sulfate: Barium sulfate is not an iodinated contrast agent and is generally used for gastrointestinal studies. It does not pose the same risks to kidney function as iodinated contrast agents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ionic high-osmolar contrast media (HOCM) are associated with a higher risk of nephrotoxicity, particularly in diabetic patients with renal impairment.
  • Low-osmolar and iso-osmolar contrast agents (such as Iohexol and Iodixanol) are safer options for these patients. 
  • Always assess renal function before administering contrast agents, especially in patients with diabetes.

questions.text: The abnormal pink curve in the flow-volume loop is least likely to be associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency

 

  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency leads to emphysema, an obstructive disease, and is unlikely to produce a restrictive flow-volume loop.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis can cause restrictive lung disease due to granuloma formation.

 

Option B. Interstitial lung disease: Interstitial lung disease results in restrictive patterns with reduced lung compliance.

 

Option C. Obesity hypoventilation syndrome: Obesity hypoventilation syndrome causes a restrictive pattern due to mechanical limitations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Restrictive patterns on flow-volume loops are not characteristic of obstructive diseases like alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

choices.text: Growth hormone (GH) therapy is most effective if started after 10 years of age.
Estrogen therapy should be started immediately alongside growth hormone.
Progestogen is added 1–2 years after starting estrogen or upon breakthrough bleeding.
Hormone replacement is unnecessary for breast development in Turner Syndrome.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl with Turner Syndrome is brought to the pediatric endocrinology clinic for management. She has been showing signs of decreased linear growth velocity over the past year. Which of the following statements about hormone replacement in Turner Syndrome is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Progestogen is added 1–2 years after starting estrogen or upon breakthrough bleeding.

 

  • In Turner Syndrome, hormone replacement therapy (HRT) mimics normal pubertal development.
  • Estrogen is started first in low doses to initiate breast development, uterine growth, and maintain bone health.
  • Progestogen is typically added 1–2 years after estrogen initiation or earlier if breakthrough bleeding occurs, mimicking the normal sequence of puberty.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Growth hormone (GH) therapy is most effective if started after 10 years of age: GH therapy is most effective if started at a young age, ideally before 4 years of age, to maximize final adult height. Initiating after 10 years of age significantly reduces its impact on height outcomes.

 

Option B. Estrogen therapy should be started immediately alongside growth hormone: Estrogen therapy is not started immediately alongside GH. GH therapy is initiated to maximize height before starting low-dose estrogen therapy, which is added at the appropriate pubertal age.

 

Option D. Hormone replacement is unnecessary for breast development in Turner Syndrome: Hormone replacement is essential for breast development, uterine growth, and maintaining bone health in Turner Syndrome, as these girls have ovarian insufficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Turner Syndrome, GH therapy should be initiated early to maximize final height. 
  • Hormone replacement therapy is introduced to mimic normal pubertal development, with estrogen started first and progestogen added later to support reproductive and bone health.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with metastatic lung cancer is enrolled in a clinical trial comparing the effectiveness of two new chemotherapy regimens on overall survival. The study monitors patients for five years, and survival data is presented using Kaplan-Meier curves. Which statistical test is most appropriate to determine if there is a significant difference in survival between the two groups?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cox proportional hazards model

 

  • The Cox proportional hazards model is used in survival analysis to compare time-to-event data between two or more groups while adjusting for covariates. 
  • It evaluates the hazard ratio, providing insight into the relative risk of an event occurring in one group compared to another. 
  • Kaplan-Meier curves visually represent the survival function, and the Cox model complements this by providing statistical significance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Logistic regression: Logistic regression is used for binary outcomes, not time-to-event data.

 

Option B. Chi-square test: The chi-square test is used for categorical data and is not appropriate for analyzing survival data.

 

Option C. ANOVA: ANOVA compares means between groups, but it does not handle survival or time-to-event data.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • The Cox proportional hazards model is used in survival analysis to compare the hazard rates between groups while accounting for covariates.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is diagnosed with persistent atrial fibrillation. She is prescribed an antiarrhythmic drug that selectively prolongs the action potential by blocking delayed rectifier potassium channels (IKr) during Phase 3. The drug has no significant effects on sodium or calcium channels, nor does it act on beta-adrenergic receptors. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed to her?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dofetilide

 

  • Dofetilide is a pure Class III antiarrhythmic agent that acts specifically by blocking the delayed rectifier potassium channels (IKr) during Phase 3 of the cardiac action potential. 
  • This results in prolonged repolarization and an increased duration of the action potential. 
  • Unlike other Class III agents like amiodarone, dofetilide does not have additional effects on sodium, calcium, or adrenergic receptors. 
  • It is specifically indicated for the maintenance of sinus rhythm in patients with atrial fibrillation or flutter.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amiodarone: While it is a Class III antiarrhythmic agent, it has multiple effects, including sodium channel blockade, beta-adrenergic blockade, and calcium channel inhibition, making it a non-pure action potential-prolonging drug.

 

Option B. Procainamide: This is a Class IA antiarrhythmic agent that primarily blocks sodium channels and prolongs the action potential by slowing Phase 0 depolarization. It is not a pure potassium channel blocker.

 

Option D. Phenytoin: A Class IB antiarrhythmic agent, phenytoin shortens the action potential duration by accelerating repolarization. It does not block potassium channels in the same way as Class III agents.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Dofetilide is a pure Class III antiarrhythmic drug that prolongs the action potential by selectively blocking the delayed rectifier potassium channels (IKr) during Phase 3 of the cardiac action potential. 
  • It does not have effects on sodium or calcium channels or adrenergic receptors, distinguishing it from other Class III agents.

choices.text: Vitrectomy to clear the vitreous opacities
Laser photocoagulation to prevent retinal detachment

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman with hypertension and hypercholesterolemia presents with the following ocular finding. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Observation and reassurance

 

  • Asteroid hyalosis is usually asymptomatic and does not typically affect vision. 
  • Treatment is rarely required. Vitrectomy is only indicated in cases where the opacities significantly impair vision or interfere with other ocular procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitrectomy to clear the vitreous opacities: Vitrectomy is not routinely performed for asymptomatic asteroid hyalosis.

 

Option C. Intravitreal corticosteroids to reduce inflammation: There is no inflammatory component requiring corticosteroids.

 

Option D. Laser photocoagulation to prevent retinal detachment: Laser photocoagulation is used for retinal detachment or tears, not asteroid hyalosis.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Asteroid hyalosis is a benign condition that usually requires no treatment. Observation and reassurance are the primary approaches unless vision is significantly affected.

questions.text:
Which of these are correct statements? 

 

  1. Tranexamic acid reduces the risk of mortality only in patients of penetrating trauma with no role in blunt trauma cases
  2. All patients with signs of shock should receive tranexamic acid within 3 hours of injury
  3. Crystalloids are preferred over blood and blood products for resuscitation of severely hypovolemic patients with trauma
  4. eFAST can be done even in unstable patients
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2, 4

 

2. All patients with signs of shock should receive tranexamic acid within 3 hours of injury: Tranexamic acid is effective in reducing mortality when administered early in patients with signs of shock or major bleeding following trauma. It is most effective when given within 3 hours of injury, regardless of whether the trauma is blunt or penetrating.

 

4. eFAST can be done even in unstable patients: The extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (eFAST) is a rapid and non-invasive diagnostic tool to evaluate free fluid in the abdomen, pericardium, or thoracic cavity. It is particularly valuable in unstable patients as it can guide immediate management decisions like laparotomy or thoracostomy.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Tranexamic acid reduces the risk of mortality only in patients of penetrating trauma with no role in blunt trauma cases: This is incorrect. Tranexamic acid is effective in both blunt and penetrating trauma when used within the recommended time frame (3 hours of injury).

 

3. Crystalloids are preferred over blood and blood products for resuscitation of severely hypovolemic patients with trauma: This is incorrect. Blood and blood products are preferred for resuscitation in trauma patients with severe hypovolemia to restore oxygen-carrying capacity and avoid the complications of excessive crystalloid use, such as dilutional coagulopathy and acidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In trauma management, tranexamic acid should be administered within 3 hours of injury in patients with shock or major bleeding, regardless of trauma type, and eFAST can be performed even in unstable patients to guide management decisions.
  • Blood and blood products are preferred over crystalloids in severe hypovolemia.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old woman is hospitalized with an acute inferior ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). She did not undergo revascularization due to delayed presentation. She has a history of deep vein thrombosis and is a factor V Leiden carrier.

 

Clinical Course:


On day 3 of hospitalization, she develops severe shortness of breath and hypotension.

 

Vitals and Examination:

 

  • Blood pressure: 84/60 mm Hg
  • Pulse: 112/min, regular
  • Apical impulse: Hyperdynamic
  • Cardiac auscultation: Faint early systolic murmur at the apex, no precordial thrill
  • Lungs: Bilateral crackles
  • Extremities: Cold and clammy

 

Investigations:

 

  • Echocardiogram: Inferior and inferolateral wall akinesis, LVEF 45%
  • ECG: Sinus tachycardia with Q waves in leads II, III, and aVF

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mitral regurgitation

 

  • The patient presents with acute severe mitral regurgitation (MR) due to papillary muscle rupture, a known complication of inferior myocardial infarction.

 

Key Features Supporting Mitral Regurgitation:

 

  1. Papillary muscle rupture: Commonly occurs 2–7 days post-inferior MI due to ischemia of the posteromedial papillary muscle, which is supplied solely by the posterior descending artery.
  2. Clinical findings:
    • Hypotension and tachycardia (cardiogenic shock).
    • Hyperdynamic apical impulse and faint systolic murmur (a loud murmur or thrill is often absent in acute MR because of rapid equalization of pressures between the left atrium and left ventricle).
    • Pulmonary edema (bilateral crackles).
  3. Echocardiogram findings: Wall motion abnormalities in the inferior and inferolateral walls indicate ischemia in the region of papillary muscles.

 

Management:

 

  • Urgent echocardiography to confirm the diagnosis.
  • Emergency surgery or percutaneous intervention to repair the mitral valve and restore hemodynamic stability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute myocardial ischemia: Unlikely because the patient has persistent Q waves indicating completed infarction, not ongoing ischemia.

 

Option B. Left ventricular free wall rupture: Typically causes cardiac tamponade and profound hypotension. Physical exam reveals jugular venous distension, muffled heart sounds, and pulsus paradoxus.

 

Option D. Pulmonary embolism: Presents with sudden shortness of breath, pleuritic chest pain, and hypoxemia. While this patient has a risk factor (factor V Leiden), the hyperdynamic apex and mitral murmur favor MR.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Acute severe mitral regurgitation secondary to papillary muscle rupture is a life-threatening complication of inferior MI, presenting with hypotension, pulmonary edema, and a hyperdynamic apex. 
  • Urgent echocardiography is essential for confirmation and management.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a history of chronic otitis media presents for tympanoplasty. During surgery, the surgeon discovers that both the malleus and incus are absent, but the stapes is intact. According to Wullstein's classification, which type of tympanoplasty is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type III

 

  • According to Wullstein’s classification, Type III tympanoplasty is performed when both the malleus and incus are absent. 
  • In this procedure, the tympanic membrane graft is directly placed on the stapes head to reconstruct the sound conduction mechanism. 
  • This allows the stapes to act as the connection to the inner ear for sound transmission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I: This type involves placing the tympanic membrane graft on an intact and functioning ossicular chain. Since both the malleus and incus are absent in this case, Type I tympanoplasty is not applicable.

 

Option B. Type II: Type II tympanoplasty is used when the malleus is absent or eroded, and the graft is placed on the incus. However, in this scenario, the incus is also absent, so this approach does not apply.

 

Option D. Type IV: This type involves placing the tympanic membrane graft over the round window to protect it when the stapes is eroded or absent. Since the stapes is present and intact in this case, Type IV tympanoplasty is not required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Type III tympanoplasty, the tympanic membrane graft is placed directly on the stapes head when both the malleus and incus are absent, as per Wullstein’s classification.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old man presents with fever, headache, and a maculopapular rash with petechiae on his arms and legs. He had a root canal 2 weeks ago with mild post-procedure gum swelling and is an avid biker.

 

Key Findings:

 

  • Vitals:
    • Temperature: 39.7°C (103.5°F)
    • Pulse: 114/min (regular).
    • Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg.
  • Examination:
    • Rash: Maculopapular with petechiae on arms and legs.
    • No lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, or meningeal signs.
    • Lungs clear, no heart murmurs.
  • Labs:
    • Thrombocytopenia: Platelets 90,000/mm³.
    • Hyponatremia: Sodium 134 mEq/L.
    • Transaminitis: Elevated AST (162 U/L) and ALT (174 U/L).
    • Hypoalbuminemia (2.2 g/dL) with mild bilirubin elevation (1.3 mg/dL).


What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Doxycycline

 

  • The patient likely has Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF), a tick-borne illness caused by Rickettsia rickettsii.

 

Supporting Features for RMSF:

 

  1. Tick exposure history: The patient is an outdoor enthusiast and biker, increasing the likelihood of tick exposure.
  2. Fever with rash: The maculopapular rash with petechiae on the arms and legs is characteristic.
  3. Thrombocytopenia and transaminitis: Common in RMSF due to vascular damage and systemic inflammation.
  4. Hyponatremia: Frequently seen in RMSF due to inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion or increased vascular permeability.
  • Doxycycline is the treatment of choice for RMSF, regardless of patient age. Early treatment significantly reduces morbidity and mortality.
  • Treatment should be initiated empirically based on clinical suspicion, as serology results take time and delaying treatment increases risk of complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lumbar puncture: Unnecessary as there are no meningeal signs (e.g., nuchal rigidity) or neurological deficits suggesting meningitis or encephalitis.

 

Option C. Monospot test: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) can cause fever and rash but does not explain the petechiae, thrombocytopenia, or transaminitis in this patient.

 

Option D. Syphilis serology: Secondary syphilis can cause a diffuse maculopapular rash, but petechiae and systemic findings such as thrombocytopenia and transaminitis are uncommon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with fever, rash, thrombocytopenia, and transaminitis, particularly with a history of outdoor activities, Rocky Mountain spotted fever should be suspected, and doxycycline should be initiated promptly.

choices.text: Activation of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)-dependent protein kinase A
Conversion of cAMP to AMP by phosphodiesterase
Direct activation of glycogen synthase b
Direct activation of phosphorylase kinase b

questions.text: In contracting skeletal muscle, a sudden elevation of the sarcoplasmic calcium concentration will result in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Direct activation of phosphorylase kinase b

 

  • During skeletal muscle contraction, calcium (Ca²⁺) is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum into the sarcoplasm. The increase in calcium concentration leads to:
    1. Activation of phosphorylase kinase b: Calcium binds to the calmodulin subunit of phosphorylase kinase, causing allosteric activation of the dephosphorylated (inactive) "b" form of the enzyme.
    2. Role in glycogenolysis: Once activated, phosphorylase kinase b facilitates the conversion of glycogen phosphorylase b to its active form (phosphorylase a), which then breaks down glycogen into glucose-1-phosphate, providing energy for muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Activation of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)-dependent protein kinase A: Incorrect. Protein kinase A is activated by cAMP, not by calcium. cAMP signaling is associated with hormonal regulation (e.g., epinephrine), not directly with sarcoplasmic calcium elevation.

 

Option B. Conversion of cAMP to AMP by phosphodiesterase: Incorrect. Phosphodiesterase breaks down cAMP into AMP, but this process is not triggered by calcium elevation. Instead, it regulates cAMP levels in various signaling pathways.

 

Option C. Direct activation of glycogen synthase b: Incorrect. Glycogen synthase b is the inactive form of glycogen synthase, and its activation requires dephosphorylation, not calcium. Calcium instead promotes glycogen breakdown (glycogenolysis), not glycogen synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Calcium released during skeletal muscle contraction activates phosphorylase kinase b through binding to its calmodulin subunit. This activation initiates glycogenolysis, providing a rapid supply of energy to support muscle activity.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with bradycardia and hypotension after ingesting a large dose of metoprolol. Despite alpha-1 mediated vasoconstriction by noradrenaline, cardiac output does not improve significantly. What is the next best pharmacologic intervention?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucagon

 

  • Glucagon bypasses beta-adrenergic receptors and directly stimulates adenylate cyclase, increasing intracellular cAMP levels in cardiac myocytes. 
  • This improves heart rate and contractility independently of beta-receptor activation, making it the preferred treatment in beta-blocker overdose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dobutamine: Ineffective due to beta-1 receptor blockade.

 

Option C. Epinephrine: Its beta-1 effects are limited due to receptor blockade by metoprolol.

 

Option D. Atropine: Effective for bradycardia caused by vagal stimulation but does not address reduced contractility.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Glucagon is the preferred treatment for beta-blocker overdose as it directly enhances myocardial contractility and heart rate via cAMP.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of excessive fear and avoidance of social situations. She reports intense anxiety about being embarrassed or judged by others during public interactions, which has severely impacted her academic performance. What is the first-line treatment for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT)

 

  • CBT is the first-line treatment for social anxiety disorder, as it helps modify maladaptive thought patterns and reduce avoidance behavior.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fluoxetine: Effective as adjunctive therapy but not the first-line standalone treatment.

 

Option C. Benzodiazepines: Useful for short-term symptom control but not recommended as a primary or long-term treatment.

 

Option D. Exposure therapy: A component of CBT but less effective as a standalone treatment.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Social anxiety disorder involves the fear of social situations, including situations that involve contact with strangers. 
  • Patients with this disorder are afraid of embarrassing themselves in social situations. DSM-5 provides a subtype of performance only. 
  • This subtype is characterized by a pronounced fear of performing or speaking in front of others, but not necessarily experiencing social anxiety in other contexts. 
  • The recommended treatments for Social Anxiety Disorder include: SSRIs, cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and Beta-blockers (e.g., propranolol).

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with a history of pseudophakic bullous keratopathy presents with worsening corneal edema and recurrent episodes of microbial keratitis. A decision is made to apply an adhesive that is activated by ultraviolet light to address the ectasia. Which of the following adhesives is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Riboflavin-based bioadhesive

 

  • Riboflavin-based bioadhesive, activated by ultraviolet A light, is used in conditions such as post-LASIK ectasia, pseudophakic bullous keratopathy, and infectious keratopathy. 
  • It works by strengthening the corneal stroma through cross-linking.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fibrin glue: Fibrin glue is used for conjunctival and intraocular surgeries, not for corneal strengthening or ectasia management.

 

Option C. Cyanoacrylate glue: Cyanoacrylate glue is used for corneal perforations but does not address ectasia.

 

Option D. Bovine serum albumin-based bioadhesive: Bovine serum albumin-based bioadhesive is primarily used in squint surgeries and is not appropriate for corneal pathology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Riboflavin-based bioadhesive is activated by ultraviolet light and is particularly effective in strengthening the cornea in conditions like post-LASIK ectasia and pseudophakic bullous keratopathy.

choices.text: Alteration of DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is diagnosed with a urinary tract infection caused by Escherichia coli resistant to ciprofloxacin. What is the most likely mechanism of resistance in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alteration of DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV

 

  • Resistance to ciprofloxacin and other fluoroquinolones often involves mutations in DNA gyrase or topoisomerase IV, the enzymes targeted by this drug. 
  • These mutations reduce the drug's binding affinity, decreasing its efficacy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enzymatic inactivation of ciprofloxacin: Incorrect because enzymatic inactivation of fluoroquinolones is uncommon.

 

Option C. Development of beta-lactamase enzymes: Incorrect as beta-lactamases are not involved in fluoroquinolone resistance.

 

Option D. Alteration of cell membrane permeability: Incorrect because reduced permeability is not the primary mechanism for ciprofloxacin resistance.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Ciprofloxacin resistance typically arises from mutations in DNA gyrase or topoisomerase IV, the drug’s primary targets.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of severe anal pain during defecation and chronic constipation. The surgeon prepares to perform a proctoscopy but is concerned about exacerbating the patient’s symptoms. In which of the following conditions is the use of this instrument contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fissure in ano

 

  • The proctoscope is an instrument used to examine the inside of the rectum and anus. 
  • It is typically utilized to diagnose conditions such as tumors, polyps, inflammation, bleeding, or hemorrhoids. 
  • However, in cases of fissure in ano, the condition involves extensive spasm of the anal sphincter, which results in extreme pain and discomfort for the patient. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Haemorrhoids: Proctoscopy is commonly used in the diagnosis of haemorrhoids. It allows direct visualization of internal haemorrhoids, which may not be visible with external examination alone. Therefore, it is not contraindicated for haemorrhoids.

 

Option B.  Bleeding per rectum: Bleeding per rectum is one of the primary reasons to perform a proctoscopic examination. It helps in identifying the source of bleeding, such as hemorrhoids, polyps, or tumors. Thus, it is not contraindicated for this condition.

 

Option D. Ca rectum: Proctoscopy is a valuable diagnostic tool for evaluating rectal cancer (Ca rectum) as it provides direct visualization of any rectal growths or abnormalities. Therefore, it is not contraindicated in cases of rectal cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The use of a proctoscope is contraindicated in patients with fissure in ano due to severe anal sphincter spasm and associated extreme pain during the procedure.

questions.text: A patient being treated with ibutilide develops QT prolongation. Which of the following drugs would most likely exacerbate this side effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Quinidine

 

  • Quinidine is a class IA antiarrhythmic drug that also prolongs the QT interval by blocking sodium and potassium channels. 
  • Concurrent use with ibutilide can lead to additive effects on QT prolongation, increasing the risk of torsades de pointes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lidocaine: Lidocaine (class IB) shortens the action potential and has minimal effect on QT interval.

 

Option C. Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic and does not directly affect QT interval.

 

Option D. Metoprolol: Metoprolol is a beta-blocker that primarily reduces heart rate and contractility, without significant effects on QT interval.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Combining drugs like ibutilide and quinidine that prolong the QT interval increases the risk of torsades de pointes and requires careful monitoring.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of weakness in his right arm after using crutches for six weeks due to a leg fracture. He mentions that the crutches were possibly too tall for him, as they pressed hard into his armpit. On examination, there is a notable deficit in the extension of his wrist and fingers, and he has difficulty with thumb abduction. His sense of touch is diminished over the posterior aspect of his arm and forearm and the dorsum of his hand. Given the distribution of his symptoms, which structure is most likely to be affected by the prolonged use of crutches?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior cord

 

  • The posterior cord of the brachial plexus gives rise to the radial nerve and axillary nerve. Prolonged pressure on the axilla, such as during improper crutch use, can compress the posterior cord, leading to radial nerve injury (commonly known as "crutch palsy").
  • The radial nerve controls wrist and finger extension and supplies sensation to the posterior arm, forearm, and dorsum of the hand. 
  • Compression of the posterior cord explains the patient's motor deficits (wrist drop, weak thumb abduction) and sensory loss over the described regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lateral cord: The lateral cord gives rise to the musculocutaneous nerve, lateral root of the median nerve, and lateral pectoral nerve. Injury here would cause deficits in elbow flexion (biceps and brachialis muscles) and sensory loss in the lateral forearm, not the posterior arm or forearm.

 

Option C. Medial cord: The medial cord forms the ulnar nerve, medial root of the median nerve, and medial cutaneous nerves of the arm and forearm. Damage to this cord would result in sensory loss over the medial arm and forearm and ulnar nerve-related deficits (e.g., claw hand), which are not seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Upper trunk: The upper trunk of the brachial plexus gives rise to the suprascapular nerve, subclavian nerve, and contributions to the lateral and posterior cords. Damage here would primarily cause deficits in shoulder abduction and lateral rotation (supraspinatus and infraspinatus) and sensory loss over the lateral shoulder and arm, not the posterior arm or hand.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The posterior cord of the brachial plexus gives rise to the radial and axillary nerves. 
  • Prolonged axillary pressure, such as improper crutch use, can compress the posterior cord, leading to radial nerve injury characterized by wrist drop, weakness in thumb abduction, and sensory loss over the posterior arm, forearm, and dorsum of the hand.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was evaluated for burning sensations in his feet and clusters of small, red-purple spots on his skin. Laboratory studies revealed protein in his urine. Enzymatic analysis revealed a deficiency of α galactosidase, and enzyme replacement therapy was recommended. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fabry disease

 

  • Fabry disease is an X-linked sphingolipidosis caused by a deficiency of the enzyme α-galactosidase A, leading to the accumulation of globotriaosylceramide (Gb3) in various tissues. 
  • This results in the following hallmark features:
    1. Pain in the extremities (acroparesthesias): A common early symptom due to small-fiber neuropathy.
    2. Angiokeratomas: Clusters of small, red-purple spots, typically found in the lower trunk and thighs.
    3. Proteinuria: Indicates kidney damage, which progresses to chronic kidney disease if untreated.
    4. Cardiac complications: Include left ventricular hypertrophy and arrhythmias in later stages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Farber disease: Incorrect. Farber disease results from a deficiency of ceramidase, leading to ceramide accumulation. It presents with joint deformities, subcutaneous nodules, and hoarseness, which are not seen in this case.

 

Option C. Gaucher disease: Incorrect. Gaucher disease is caused by a deficiency of β-glucocerebrosidase, leading to glucocerebroside accumulation. It presents with hepatosplenomegaly, bone pain, and pancytopenia, not angiokeratomas or extremity pain.

 

Option D. Krabbe disease: Incorrect. Krabbe disease is due to a deficiency of galactocerebrosidase, causing galactocerebroside accumulation. It manifests as progressive neurodegeneration, irritability, and developmental delay, which are absent in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fabry disease is a rare X-linked lysosomal storage disorder caused by α-galactosidase A deficiency. 
  • Early symptoms include extremity pain and angiokeratomas. 
  • Progression leads to kidney and cardiac complications, emphasizing the importance of early diagnosis and enzyme replacement therapy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with a 2-month history of right-sided facial pain, difficulty swallowing, and hearing loss. On examination, there is evidence of palatal asymmetry with the uvula deviating to the left side, and the patient reports reduced hearing in the right ear. Neurological examination confirms trigeminal neuralgia on the right side. This presentation is most consistent with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

 

  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma: Trotter’s triad consists of:
     
    1. Palatal palsy due to involvement of the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X), leading to uvular deviation to the unaffected side.
    2. Ipsilateral trigeminal neuralgia due to involvement of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), causing facial pain.
    3. Conductive hearing loss due to Eustachian tube obstruction or middle ear involvement.
  • This triad is typically associated with nasopharyngeal carcinoma, which can compress or invade the cranial nerves.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ramsay Hunt syndrome: This condition is caused by varicella-zoster virus reactivation in the geniculate ganglion, leading to facial paralysis, vesicular rash, and hearing loss. It does not include palatal palsy or trigeminal neuralgia.

 

Option C. Bell’s palsy: Bell’s palsy is idiopathic facial nerve paralysis and does not involve trigeminal neuralgia, palatal palsy, or conductive hearing loss.

 

Option D. Ménière’s disease: Ménière’s disease is characterized by episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, and tinnitus. It does not involve cranial nerve palsies or trigeminal neuralgia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Trotter’s triad—palatal palsy, ipsilateral trigeminal neuralgia, and conductive hearing loss—is typically associated with nasopharyngeal carcinoma compressing or invading the cranial nerves.

choices.text: Infection from a new sexual partner

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman, Ms. Priya from Mumbai, presents for her annual examination. Two weeks ago, she was treated for Chlamydia trachomatis infection diagnosed by nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) at an urgent care center. She was prescribed doxycycline orally twice daily for 7 days, and her symptoms resolved. Her partner also tested positive for Chlamydia and received treatment.

 

Current Status:

 

  • No sexual activity since her last visit.
  • Asymptomatic during this visit.

 

Current Testing Results:

 

  • Pap test: Normal.
  • NAAT for Chlamydia trachomatis: Positive.

 

What is the most likely explanation for this positive test result?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) False-positive Chlamydia trachomatis test result

 

  • The patient is likely experiencing a false-positive test result due to residual DNA or RNA fragments of Chlamydia trachomatis from her prior infection. 
  • NAAT is highly sensitive and can detect non-viable bacterial nucleic acid for up to 3 weeks after successful treatment.

 

Key Points Supporting This Diagnosis:

 

  1. Resolution of symptoms: Indicates successful treatment.
  2. No sexual activity: Rules out reinfection.
  3. Partner treatment: Reduces the likelihood of reinfection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inadequate treatment of cervicitis: Doxycycline is 97%-100% effective for treating Chlamydia trachomatis infection. Symptom resolution further supports adequate treatment.

 

Option C. Infection from a new sexual partner: The patient reported no sexual activity since her treatment, making this unlikely.

 

Option D. Infection with doxycycline-resistant Chlamydia trachomatis: Resistance to doxycycline is extremely rare, and the patient’s symptom resolution suggests the infection responded to therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Residual nucleic acid fragments from Chlamydia trachomatis can result in false-positive NAAT results for up to 3 weeks after successful treatment. 
  • Routine follow-up testing is not recommended unless symptoms persist or reinfection is suspected.

choices.text: High Vmax and lack of inhibition by G6P

questions.text: A researcher is studying an enzyme involved in glucose metabolism that is notably inhibited by glucose-6-phosphate (G6P). This enzyme is likely to exhibit which of the following characteristics in most body tissues?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low Km and low Vmax

 

  • Hexokinase has a low Km and low Vmax, which allows it to effectively phosphorylate glucose at low concentrations, making it ideal for most tissues that require consistent glucose utilization regardless of large fluctuations in glucose concentration. 
  • Its activity is inhibited by G6P to prevent excessive phosphorylation when glucose is abundant.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. High Km and inducibility: High Km and inducibility describe glucokinase, not hexokinase, which functions in a high glucose environment like the liver and pancreatic beta cells. 

 

Option C. High Vmax and lack of inhibition by G6P: High Vmax and lack of inhibition by G6P incorrectly describes glucokinase, which is not inhibited by G6P but does have a high Vmax. 

 

Option D. Inducibility and high tissue specificity: Inducibility and high tissue specificity are incorrect as hexokinase is not inducible and is found in most tissues, not specifically.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Learn the kinetic properties of hexokinase, including low Km and low Vmax, and its inhibition by G6P, critical for regulating glucose metabolism in most tissues.
