questions.text: A stool culture from a patient with bloody diarrhea grows colonies on EMB agar, as shown in the image below. Biochemical testing identifies the organism as beta-glucuronidase positive. What is the most likely virulence factor responsible for the patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Shiga-like toxin

 

  • E. coli strains producing Shiga-like toxin, such as enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC), cause bloody diarrhea by damaging the colonic mucosa and disrupting protein synthesis in host cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heat-stable enterotoxin: Associated with enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC), causing watery diarrhea, not bloody diarrhea.

 

Option C. Cholera toxin: Produced by Vibrio cholerae, causing secretory diarrhea.

 

Option D. Invasion of Peyer’s patches: Characteristic of enteroinvasive E. coli (EIEC), which does not typically produce Shiga-like toxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Shiga-like toxin production in enterohemorrhagic E. coli is a major virulence factor leading to bloody diarrhea and hemolytic uremic syndrome.

choices.text: No net water movement occurs, as the solution is isotonic.
RBCs shrink, as the solution is hyperosmotic.
RBCs swell and lyse, as the solution becomes hypo-osmotic after urea equilibration.
RBC morphology remains unchanged, as the solution is iso-osmotic and isotonic.

questions.text: 25-year-old male receives an infusion of 150 mMol/L urea. Which of the following correctly describes the behavior of RBCs in this solution?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) RBCs swell and lyse, as the solution becomes hypo-osmotic after urea equilibration.

 

  • The solution is initially iso-osmotic, but urea rapidly equilibrates across the RBC membrane. 
  • This leaves the extracellular NaCl concentration (150 mMol/L) to define the effective osmolality, creating a hypo-osmotic environment and causing water influx into the cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No net water movement occurs, as the solution is isotonic: Incorrect; isotonicity is disrupted by urea permeability.

 

Option B. RBCs shrink, as the solution is hyperosmotic: Incorrect; hyperosmotic effects do not apply to permeable solutes like urea.

 

Option D. RBC morphology remains unchanged, as the solution is iso-osmotic and isotonic: Incorrect; isotonicity is lost due to urea's rapid diffusion.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Permeable solutes like urea render solutions hypo-osmotic, causing RBC swelling and lysis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old construction worker presents to the clinic complaining of numbness over the back of his right hand following a fall from a ladder two weeks ago. He reports no weakness in his grip strength or fine motor tasks. On examination, there is a patch of sensory loss over the area marked in the image below, but motor strength in the forearm extensors is intact. Based on the anatomical distribution of sensory loss, which nerve is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Radial nerve

 

  • The radial nerve is responsible for sensory innervation to the posterior surface of the lateral 3 ½ digits and their associated dorsum on the hand via its superficial branch.
  • Additional sensory branches of the radial nerve include:
    • Inferior lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm: Lateral aspect of the upper arm between the deltoid and elbow.
    • Posterior cutaneous nerve of the arm: Posterior upper arm.
    • Posterior cutaneous nerve of the forearm: A strip in the posterior middle forearm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior Interosseous Nerve (PIN):

 

  • Originates as a continuation of the deep branch of the radial nerve.
  • Motor only: Supplies deep extensors of the forearm. No sensory function, making it incorrect in this case.

 

Option C. Median Nerve: Provides sensory innervation to the palmar aspect of the lateral 3 ½ fingers and the associated palm area, not the dorsum of the hand.

 

Option D. Ulnar Nerve: Provides sensory innervation to the medial 1 ½ fingers and the associated hand region, including both the palmar and dorsal aspects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The radial nerve's superficial branch provides sensory innervation to the dorsum of the lateral 3 ½ fingers and hand. 
  • Damage to the radial nerve in isolation often spares motor functions while causing sensory deficits in this region, as seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female Jennifer is pregnant with twins. She has a history of one live birth delivered at the beginning of 8th month and two abortions. What is her obstetric score?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) G4P0121

 

The obstetric score using the G P (TPAL) system is calculated as follows:

 

  • G (Gravida): Total number of pregnancies, including the current pregnancy.
    • Jennifer has had 1 live birth, 2 abortions, and the current twin pregnancy, making her G4.
  • P (Para): Denotes the outcome of pregnancies, subdivided into TPAL (Term, Preterm, Abortions, Live births).
    • T (Term births): 0 (as the live birth was preterm).
    • P (Preterm births): 1 (the live birth delivered at the beginning of 8th month qualifies as preterm).
    • A (Abortions): 2 (Jennifer has had 2 abortions).
    • L (Living children): 1 (the live preterm birth).

 

Hence, the score is G4P0121.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. G5P0121: This score would imply that Jennifer has had five pregnancies, which is incorrect.

 

Option C. G4P1012: This score would imply one term birth and no preterm births, which does not match Jennifer's history.

 

Option D. G5P1021: This score includes an extra pregnancy, which is not supported by Jennifer's obstetric history.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The G P (TPAL) system provides a standardized way to summarize obstetric history. 
  • Gravida includes all pregnancies, while Para denotes the outcomes (Term, Preterm, Abortions, and Living children).

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room with fever, chest pain, and difficulty breathing. A chest X-ray reveals lobar pneumonia. Blood cultures show gram-positive, lancet-shaped diplococci. Colonies on blood agar incubated for 24 hours show a characteristic pattern as shown below. Which of the following is responsible for this appearance?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Autolysin

 

  • Autolysin is an amidase enzyme produced by Streptococcus pneumoniae that cleaves peptidoglycan, leading to the autolysis of cells. 
  • This enzymatic activity results in the central umbonation and concentric rings of colonies, commonly described as the "draughtsman appearance" or "carrom coin appearance."

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lipoteichoic acid: Lipoteichoic acid is a component of gram-positive cell walls but does not cause this colony morphology.

 

Option C. Capsule polysaccharides: Capsule polysaccharides are responsible for virulence and resistance to phagocytosis but do not influence colony morphology.

 

Option D. Pneumolysin: Pneumolysin is a cytotoxin that contributes to tissue damage but does not influence colony appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "draughtsman appearance" of Streptococcus pneumoniae colonies is due to autolysin, an enzyme responsible for peptidoglycan degradation and bile solubility.

choices.text: Leading questions can be asked during examination-in-chief if the witness is an expert in the subject matter of the case.
Leading questions can be asked during examination-in-chief if the witness is hostile.
Leading question can be asked during examination-in-chief if the evidence of witness fails to prove that accused has done the crime.

questions.text: In a criminal trial, a witness who initially agreed to testify for the prosecution later refuses to cooperate and provides contradictory statements during examination-in-chief. The prosecutor seeks the court's permission to ask leading questions. Under what circumstance can this be allowed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leading questions can be asked during examination-in-chief if the witness is hostile.

 

  • A leading question is one that suggests the answer to the witness, often limiting their response to "yes" or "no."
  • Generally, leading questions are not permitted during examination-in-chief because the purpose is to allow the witness to narrate events in their own words.

 

However, an exception arises when a witness is declared hostile. A hostile witness is one who:

 

  • Provides testimony that is evasive, contradictory, or inconsistent with their prior statements.
  • Refuses to cooperate with the prosecution.

 

When a witness is declared hostile, the court may grant permission to the prosecutor to ask leading questions during examination-in-chief. This rule ensures that key facts can still be elicited, even if the witness is uncooperative.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leading question can be asked during examination-in-chief if the witness is an expert in the subject matter of the case: Incorrect. Leading questions are generally not allowed during examination-in-chief, whether the witness is an expert or not. The rule is aimed at ensuring that the witness is speaking from their own knowledge and memory, rather than being guided by the examiner. The exception to this rule comes when the witness is hostile or unwilling to cooperate, not simply because the witness is an expert.

 

Option C. Leading question can be asked during examination-in-chief if the evidence of witness fails to prove that accused has done the crime: Incorrect. The effectiveness or strength of the witness's evidence does not influence the allowance of leading questions.

 

Option D. Both B and C: While B is correct, C is not a valid reason to ask leading questions. The ability to ask leading questions is tied to the witness’s behavior (i.e., being hostile), not the content or strength of their testimony.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leading questions are typically reserved for cross-examination but may be used during examination-in-chief if a witness is declared hostile. 
  • This legal provision allows the court to extract crucial facts despite the witness’s uncooperative behavior.

choices.text: CGG repeat expansion on the FMR1 gene

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with progressive ataxia, kyphoscoliosis, and bilateral foot deformities. Neurological examination reveals diminished proprioception and absent reflexes in the lower extremities. An echocardiogram shows left ventricular hypertrophy. Which genetic abnormality is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GAA repeat expansion on chromosome 9q13

 

  • The clinical presentation of Friedrich's ataxia includes ataxia, kyphoscoliosis, foot deformities (e.g., pes cavus), diminished proprioception, and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. 
  • This is caused by a GAA trinucleotide repeat expansion in the frataxin gene on chromosome 9q13.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CAG repeat expansion on chromosome 4: This is characteristic of Huntington's disease, which involves chorea and cognitive decline.

 

Option C. CTG repeat expansion on chromosome 19: This is associated with myotonic dystrophy, characterized by muscle weakness and myotonia.

 

Option D. CGG repeat expansion on the FMR1 gene: This is linked to fragile X syndrome, causing intellectual disability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Friedrich's ataxia is caused by a GAA trinucleotide repeat expansion in the frataxin gene on chromosome 9q13.

questions.text: A laboratory is performing an antibiotic sensitivity test for a Gram-negative organism isolated from a patient with septicemia. Which of the following would be the most appropriate method for precise determination of MIC and allows easy interpretation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Epsilometer test (E-test)

 

  • The Epsilometer test provides a precise MIC by using a gradient antibiotic strip placed on an agar plate. 
  • This method combines the principles of diffusion and dilution, making it simpler to interpret compared to traditional dilution methods.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Agar dilution method: Incorrect. The agar dilution method requires the preparation of multiple plates with increasing antibiotic concentrations, making it labor-intensive.

 

Option B. Tube dilution method: Incorrect. Tube dilution involves serial dilutions in liquid medium, requiring extensive handling and interpretation.

 

Option C. Kirby-Bauer method: Incorrect. Kirby-Bauer is a diffusion-only method and does not provide MIC values.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The E-test offers a combination of diffusion and dilution for precise MIC determination and is ideal for clinical laboratories.

choices.text: Initiation of dystrophin transcription will be defective.
Termination of dystrophin transcription will be defective.
Capping of dystrophin messenger RNA will be defective.
Splicing of dystrophin messenger RNA will be defective.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child who easily tires and has trouble walking is diagnosed with Duchenne muscular dystrophy, an X-linked recessive disorder. Genetic analysis shows that the patient’s gene for the muscle protein dystrophin contains a mutation in its promoter region. Of the choices listed, which would be the most likely effect of this mutation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Initiation of dystrophin transcription will be defective

 

  • Mutations in the promoter typically prevent formation of the RNA polymerase II transcription initiation complex, resulting in a decrease in the initiation of messenger RNA (mRNA) synthesis. 
  • A deficiency of dystrophin mRNA will result in a deficiency in the production of the dystrophin protein. 
  • Capping, splicing, and tailing defects are not a consequence of promoter mutations. 
  • They can, however, result in mRNA with decreased stability (capping and tailing defects) or an mRNA in which exons have been skipped (lost) or introns retained (splicing defects).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Termination of dystrophin transcription will be defective: Incorrect. Termination of transcription is regulated by sequences located at the end of the gene, not by the promoter region.

 

Option C. Capping of dystrophin messenger RNA will be defective: Incorrect. mRNA capping involves the addition of a 5’ cap to stabilize the mRNA. This process is unrelated to promoter region mutations.

 

Option D. Splicing of dystrophin messenger RNA will be defective: Incorrect. Splicing defects occur due to mutations in introns or splice site junctions, not in the promoter region. Splicing errors can lead to exon skipping or intron retention but are not caused by promoter mutations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Promoter region mutations impair the initiation of transcription by disrupting the recruitment of RNA polymerase II and other transcription factors. This results in reduced mRNA and protein production, as seen in disorders like Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

choices.text: Lymphatics from the scrotum drain into internal iliac nodes
The anterior third of the scrotum is supplied by ilioinguinal and genitofemoral nerves
Layers of the scrotum from outer to inner are skin, dartos, external spermatic fascia, internal spermatic fascia, cremaster, parietal layer of tunica vaginalis
The right half of the scrotum is lower than the left side

questions.text: 45-year-old farmer presented to the emergency department with complaints of right-sided scrotal pain and progressive swelling for the past 5 days. He also reported fever with chills. On physical examination, his right hemiscrotum appeared erythematous, warm, and tender to touch. The cremasteric reflex was intact. A scrotal ultrasound was performed, confirming the diagnosis of a scrotal abscess. Which of the following statements pertaining to this case is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The anterior third of the scrotum is supplied by ilioinguinal and genitofemoral nerves

 

  • The scrotum receives sensory innervation from:
    • Anterior third: Ilioinguinal nerve and the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve.
    • Posterior two-thirds: Scrotal branches of the pudendal nerve.
      This anatomical distribution explains the sensory patterns in cases of scrotal pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymphatics from the scrotum drain into internal iliac nodes:
This is incorrect. Lymphatic drainage of the scrotum is to the superficial inguinal nodes, not the internal iliac nodes. This distinction is important in evaluating metastasis or infections in the scrotum.

 

Option C. Layers of the scrotum from outer to inner are skin, dartos, external spermatic fascia, internal spermatic fascia, cremaster, parietal layer of tunica vaginalis: This is incorrect in the given order. 

 

The correct order is:

 

  1. Skin
  2. Dartos fascia
  3. External spermatic fascia
  4. Cremaster muscle and fascia
  5. Internal spermatic fascia
  6. Parietal layer of the tunica vaginalis

 

Option D. Right half of the scrotum is lower than the left side: This is incorrect. The left side of the scrotum is lower than the right due to the longer left spermatic cord, allowing better thermal regulation for spermatogenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

With regards to scrotum:

 

  • Lymphatic drainage to superficial inguinal nodes.
  • Sensory innervation: Ilioinguinal and genitofemoral nerves (anterior third); pudendal nerve (posterior two-thirds).
  • Correct anatomical sequence of scrotal layers for clinical correlation in trauma or infections.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man is hospitalized for congestive heart failure exacerbation and treated with intravenous diuretics. He has a history of non-ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) treated with a right coronary artery stent three weeks ago. On hospital day 6, he develops a drop in platelet count to 62,000/µL (from 210,000/µL on admission) while receiving unfractionated heparin for DVT prophylaxis.

 

Key Lab Findings:

 

  • Platelets: 62,000/µL (significant drop).
  • Hemoglobin: 14.2 g/dL (normal).
  • Leukocytes: 9,000/µL (normal).
  • Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL (normal).
  • Troponin I: 0.012 ng/mL (normal).

 

Current Status:

 

  • Subcutaneous heparin has been discontinued due to concern for heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).

 

What is the best approach to prevent thromboembolism in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Argatroban

 

  • This patient’s clinical presentation is concerning for heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) due to the significant drop in platelet count (>50%) following heparin exposure. 
  • HIT is a prothrombotic disorder caused by antibodies against platelet factor 4-heparin complexes, leading to platelet activation and increased risk of thromboembolism.

 

Management of HIT:

 

  1. Immediate discontinuation of all heparin products, including low-molecular-weight heparin (e.g., enoxaparin).
  2. Start a non-heparin anticoagulant, such as:
    • Argatroban: A direct thrombin inhibitor that prevents thrombus formation.
    • Fondaparinux: A factor Xa inhibitor (alternative in some cases).

 

Rationale for Argatroban:

 

  • Effective in preventing thromboembolism during acute HIT.
  • Safe for patients with normal renal function (creatinine 1.2 mg/dL).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ambulation as tolerated only: While ambulation is encouraged, it is not sufficient for thromboembolism prevention in HIT.

 

Option C. Compression stockings only: Mechanical prophylaxis alone does not adequately prevent thromboembolism in HIT.

 

Option D. Enoxaparin: A low-molecular-weight heparin, contraindicated in HIT due to cross-reactivity with heparin antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with suspected or confirmed HIT, discontinue all heparin products and initiate a non-heparin anticoagulant such as argatroban to reduce thromboembolic risk.

choices.text: Distal interphalangeal joint arthritis with nail involvement
Migratory arthritis affecting the large joints

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with lesions as shown in the image. He reports associated joint stiffness, especially in the mornings. What is the most likely pattern of arthritis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Distal interphalangeal joint arthritis with nail involvement

 

  • Psoriatic arthritis commonly involves the distal interphalangeal joints and is associated with nail changes. 
  • Other patterns include asymmetric oligoarthritis, symmetric polyarthritis, and arthritis mutilans.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Symmetrical small joint polyarthritis: Seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Option B. Monoarthritis of the large joints: More common in conditions like gout.

 

Option D. Migratory arthritis affecting the large joints: Associated with rheumatic fever or gonococcal arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Psoriatic arthritis often involves the distal interphalangeal joints and is associated with nail dystrophy.

choices.text: Increased conduction velocity through the AV node
Decreased sympathetic tone to the AV node
Decreased parasympathetic influence on the heart

questions.text: A 56-year-old male with refractory ventricular arrhythmias undergoes a left stellate ganglion block, which is a procedure that reduces sympathetic time to the heart. What is the most likely effect on cardiac physiology following this intervention?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased sympathetic tone to the AV node

 

  • The left stellate ganglion provides sympathetic innervation to the AV node. Blocking the ganglion reduces sympathetic tone, which slows AV nodal conduction and decreases heart rate. 
  • This intervention is often used in the management of refractory ventricular arrhythmias to modulate autonomic influence on the heart.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased conduction velocity through the AV node: Sympathetic blockade reduces conduction velocity through the AV node rather than increasing it.

 

Option C. Increased SA nodal activity: Sympathetic input to the SA node decreases, leading to reduced activity, not an increase.

 

Option D. Decreased parasympathetic influence on the heart: Parasympathetic tone is unaffected by the procedure; rather, its relative influence may increase due to reduced sympathetic input.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand that a left stellate ganglion block reduces sympathetic tone to the heart, resulting in decreased AV nodal conduction and heart rate.

choices.text: This disease begins at the rectum and moves proximally
The fulminant disease is characterized by more than 10 bowel movements in a day
The disease is limited to mucosa and submucosa only

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented with tenesmus and rectal bleeding. On endoscopy, the following picture was obtained. What is the False statement concerning the above condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Smoking is a risk factor

 

  • Given colonoscopy is of ulcerative colitis, showing continuous ulcers (no skip areas). Smoking is protective for UC.
  • Contrary to many other health conditions where smoking is a risk factor, in ulcerative colitis, smoking has been observed to have a protective effect

 

Other Options:

 

In a case suggestive of ulcerative colitis, as depicted by endoscopy findings of continuous ulcers starting at the rectum, assess the following statements:

 

Option A. This disease begins at the rectum and moves proximally: The characteristic pattern of inflammation in ulcerative colitis begins at the rectum and typically extends proximally in a continuous manner.


Option C. The fulminant disease is characterized by more than 10 bowel movements in a day: Fulminant colitis, a severe form of ulcerative colitis, can present with more than 10 bowel movements per day, often with systemic symptoms and a risk of toxic megacolon.

 

Option D. The disease is limited to mucosa and submucosa only: Ulcerative colitis affects only the mucosal and submucosal layers of the colon, which differentiates it from Crohn's disease that can involve the entire thickness of the bowel wall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Smoking is not a risk factor for ulcerative colitis; it is, in fact, inversely associated, with a protective effect reported in some studies.

choices.text: In T1WI, CSF appears hypointense, while in T2WI, CSF appears hyperintense.
In T1WI, both gray and white matter have the same signal intensity, while in T2WI, gray matter appears white and white matter appears gray.
T1WI is better for evaluating pathology, while T2WI is ideal for anatomical details.
In both T1WI and T2WI, most pathologies are hypointense, but the signal changes in T2WI are more pronounced.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with unexplained neurological symptoms, and a brain MRI is performed to evaluate potential pathology. The MRI reveals both T1-weighted and T2-weighted images. The radiologist notes significant differences in the appearance of various brain tissues, including cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and gray/white matter, depending on the MRI sequence used. Based on the given MRI characteristics, which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the comparison between T1 and T2 imaging sequences?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) In T1WI, CSF appears hypointense, while in T2WI, CSF appears hyperintense.

 

  • In T1-weighted imaging (T1WI), CSF appears hypointense (darker), which is due to the slow recovery of longitudinal magnetization of CSF (long T1 recovery time).
  • In contrast, in T2-weighted imaging (T2WI), CSF appears hyperintense (brighter), as it has a high signal intensity due to the prolonged transverse relaxation (long T2 decay time), which leads to greater signal retention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. In T1WI, both gray and white matter have the same signal intensity, while in T2WI, gray matter appears white and white matter appears gray: This is incorrect. In T1WI, gray matter appears gray and white matter appears white. In T2WI, gray matter appears white and white matter appears gray, not the reverse as described here.

 

Option C. T1WI is better for evaluating pathology, while T2WI is ideal for anatomical details: This is incorrect. T2WI is typically better for evaluating pathology, particularly fluid-filled structures and pathologies like tumors or inflammation, due to its sensitivity to differences in tissue water content. T1WI is often better for anatomical imaging due to its sharper contrast between structures.

 

Option D. In both T1WI and T2WI, most pathologies are hypointense, but the signal changes in T2WI are more pronounced: This is incorrect. In T1WI, most pathologies tend to be hypointense, but in T2WI, most pathologies are typically hyperintense, not hypointense, due to the water content and decay characteristics of tissues in these sequences.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • T1-weighted MRI typically shows CSF as hypointense, while T2-weighted MRI shows CSF as hyperintense. 
  • T2WI is better for evaluating pathologies, whereas T1WI is more suitable for anatomical details. 
  • Understanding these differences in MRI sequences is crucial for accurate interpretation in clinical practice.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after a fall. She has a history of advanced breast cancer, treated with radical mastectomy and chemotherapy a year ago.

 

Findings:

 

  • Symptoms: Headache and mild right arm pain after the fall.
  • CT head: Unremarkable.
  • Lower extremity radiographs is shown below. 

 

 

  • Lab results:
    • Creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL (creatinine clearance: 30 mL/min).
    • Calcium: 9.6 mg/dL (normal).
    • Alkaline phosphatase: 220 U/L (elevated).

 

What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Denosumab

 

  • This patient has breast cancer with bone metastases, as evidenced by radiographic findings. 
  • Bone metastases in breast cancer patients can lead to skeletal-related events (SREs), including fractures, spinal cord compression, and hypercalcemia.

 

Preferred Therapy:

 

  • Denosumab, a monoclonal antibody that inhibits RANKL, is effective in reducing SREs in patients with bone metastases.
  • It is preferred over bisphosphonates (e.g., alendronate or zoledronic acid) in patients with renal impairment (creatinine clearance <30 mL/min), as it does not require renal excretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alendronate: Bisphosphonates are not first-line for bone metastases and are contraindicated in patients with renal impairment (creatinine clearance <30 mL/min).

 

Option B. Calcium and vitamin D: Although supplementation is important in osteoporosis prevention, it is not sufficient for managing bone metastases or preventing SREs.

 

Option C. Calcitonin: Primarily used for acute hypercalcemia, not for long-term management of bone metastases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For patients with bone metastases and renal impairment, denosumab is the treatment of choice to prevent skeletal-related events and improve bone health.

choices.text: Bradycardia due to suppressed sympathetic tone
Peripheral edema due to calcium channel blockade
Sedation due to central nervous system effects

questions.text: A patient with essential hypertension is treated with clonidine. Which of the following side effects is least likely to occur with clonidine therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peripheral edema due to calcium channel blockade

 

  • Clonidine acts as a central alpha-2 adrenergic agonist and does not block calcium channels. 
  • Peripheral edema is a side effect of calcium channel blockers like amlodipine, not clonidine. 
  • Clonidine can cause sedation, bradycardia, and rebound hypertension if abruptly discontinued.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rebound hypertension upon abrupt discontinuation: Rebound hypertension is a well-known complication of abrupt clonidine withdrawal.

 

Option B. Bradycardia due to suppressed sympathetic tone: Bradycardia occurs due to decreased sympathetic stimulation.

 

Option D. Sedation due to central nervous system effects: Sedation is common with centrally acting alpha-2 adrenergic agonists.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Clonidine does not cause peripheral edema because it is not a calcium channel blocker. 
  • Its primary side effects are related to its central nervous system actions.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male in a tropical country donates his cornea after an accidental death. The eye bank team retrieves the cornea and places it in a moist chamber for transportation. Considering the environmental conditions and preservation method, what is the maximum time frame within which the cornea can be successfully transplanted?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 48 hours

 

  • The cornea is an avascular structure highly dependent on endothelial cell viability for successful transplantation. 
  • In a tropical climate, corneas preserved in a moist chamber can remain viable for up to 48 hours. 
  • This preservation method minimizes desiccation and microbial contamination while maintaining tissue integrity. However, delays beyond this time frame increase the risk of endothelial cell damage, compromising graft success. 
  • Proper handling during retrieval and transportation is critical.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A donor cornea preserved in a moist chamber remains viable for up to 48 hours in tropical climates, provided it is handled and transported under optimal conditions.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with advanced African trypanosomiasis involving CNS symptoms such as confusion and ataxia. Which of the following drugs is most effective for treating late-stage CNS involvement in this disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Melarsoprol

 

  • Melarsoprol is an arsenical compound that crosses the blood-brain barrier and is the drug of choice for treating late-stage African trypanosomiasis with CNS involvement. 
  • It is highly effective in managing both blood and CNS stages of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suramin: Effective against early-stage African trypanosomiasis but does not cross the blood-brain barrier and is not effective for late-stage CNS involvement.

 

Option B. Emetine: Used for amoebic infections, not African trypanosomiasis.

 

Option D. Nifurtimox: Effective when combined with eflornithine but less effective than melarsoprol for CNS involvement.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Melarsoprol is the preferred treatment for late-stage African trypanosomiasis with CNS involvement due to its ability to cross the blood-brain barrier.

questions.text: A 3-month-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of progressive vision loss. Physical examination reveals cataracts, but no signs of liver damage or neurologic deficits. Urinalysis is positive for reducing sugar but negative for glucose. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Galactokinase

 

  • The girl is deficient in galactokinase and is unable to appropriately phosphorylate galactose. 
  • Galactose accumulates in the blood (and urine). In the lens of the eye, galactose is reduced by aldose reductase to galactitol, a sugar alcohol, which causes osmotic effects that result in cataract formation. 
  • Deficiency of galactose 1-phosphate uridyltransferase also results in cataracts but is characterized by liver damage and neurologic effects. 
  • Fructokinase deficiency is a benign condition. Aldolase B deficiency is severe, with effects on several tissues. Cataracts are not typically seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aldolase B: Incorrect. Aldolase B deficiency is associated with hereditary fructose intolerance, a severe condition characterized by hypoglycemia, vomiting, hepatomegaly, and failure to thrive upon fructose ingestion. Cataracts are not a feature of this condition.

 

Option B. Fructokinase: Incorrect. Fructokinase deficiency results in essential fructosuria, a benign and asymptomatic condition. It does not cause cataracts or systemic complications.

 

Option D. Galactose 1-phosphate uridylyltransferase: Incorrect. GALT deficiency causes classic galactosemia, a condition that includes cataracts but also presents with severe systemic manifestations such as liver damage, failure to thrive, and neurologic effects. The absence of these findings in this patient makes GALT deficiency unlikely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Galactokinase deficiency causes cataracts due to the accumulation of galactitol in the lens, which results from the reduction of galactose. 
  • The condition is relatively mild, lacking the systemic complications seen in galactose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase deficiency. 
  • Urinalysis showing reducing sugar in the absence of glucose is a key diagnostic clue.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with metastatic colorectal cancer. He is started on a monoclonal antibody that targets vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) to inhibit angiogenesis. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bevacizumab

 

  • Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits VEGF, a key factor in angiogenesis. 
  • By blocking VEGF, Bevacizumab prevents the formation of new blood vessels that supply the tumor, thereby slowing tumor growth and metastasis. 
  • It is used in metastatic colorectal cancer, renal cell carcinoma, and other solid tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nivolumab: Nivolumab targets the PD-1 immune checkpoint pathway, enhancing T-cell activation. It is used in cancers like melanoma and lung cancer but does not inhibit angiogenesis.

 

Option C. Rituximab: Rituximab targets CD20 and is used for B-cell malignancies such as non-Hodgkin lymphoma, not solid tumors.

 

Option D. Trastuzumab: Trastuzumab targets HER2-positive tumors and is not used in colorectal cancer.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Bevacizumab inhibits VEGF-mediated angiogenesis, reducing blood supply to tumors and slowing the progression of solid tumors like metastatic colorectal cancer.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents to the clinic complaining of a diminished sense of taste. On examination, the tongue appears normal in color and texture. A biopsy of the posterior part of the tongue near the sulcus terminalis is taken, and the histological section is shown in the image below. Identify the papillae from the given histological section:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Circumvallate 

 

  • Circumvallate papillae are the largest papillae on the tongue, numbering around 8–12.
  • They are cylindrical in shape and located in a V-shaped row immediately in front of the sulcus terminalis on the dorsal surface of the tongue.
  • Histologically, they are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium and contain numerous taste buds (around 250 per papilla) within their walls, allowing them to play a significant role in taste sensation.
  • The serous glands of von Ebner secrete into the trenches surrounding these papillae to flush food particles and aid in taste perception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fungiform Papillae: These are large, rounded, and reddish protrusions found on the dorsal surface and margins of the tongue. They are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium and contain taste buds, but they lack the distinctive trenches seen in circumvallate papillae.

 

Option C. Filiform Papillae: These are the most numerous papillae on the dorsal surface of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. They are small, conical, and covered by keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. They lack taste buds and are primarily involved in mechanical functions, such as food manipulation.

 

Option D. Foliate Papillae: Located bilaterally at the posterior lateral edges of the tongue, foliate papillae are leaf-like ridges covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. They also contain taste buds but lack the cylindrical shape and trenches characteristic of circumvallate papillae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Circumvallate papillae are located on the posterior tongue in front of the sulcus terminalis.
  • They are the largest papillae, have trenches surrounding them, and house numerous taste buds that contribute to taste sensation

questions.text: A researcher aims to understand the psychological adaptation of disaster survivors over a period of five years. Which type of interview method is most appropriate for this study?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Repetitive interview

 

  • A repetitive interview is specifically used to assess gradual influences on social or psychological processes. 
  • It involves conducting interviews over multiple intervals, which is ideal for long-term studies like tracking the psychological adaptation of disaster survivors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct interview: This involves structured questions in a single session, not over a prolonged period.

 

Option B. Focused interview: Targets specific aspects of a problem, such as the impact of mass communication, and is not suitable for longitudinal studies.

 

Option C. Non-directive interview: Allows participants to express their opinions freely but does not involve repeated interviews over time.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Repetitive interviews are used in longitudinal studies to assess gradual social or psychological changes over time.

choices.text: A high proportion of memory T cells due to prior antigen exposure.
A predominant naïve T cell population, suggesting limited antigenic exposure or immunodeficiency.
A defective CD2 pathway preventing memory T cell activation.
Impaired IL-2 signaling leading to an absence of memory T cells.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with a history of recurrent infections undergoes an immune function test that reveals a low CD45RO/CD45RA ratio. Which of the following best explains this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A predominant naïve T cell population, suggesting limited antigenic exposure or immunodeficiency.

 

  • A low CD45RO/CD45RA ratio indicates a predominance of naïve T cells (CD45RA-positive), which may occur in individuals with limited antigenic exposure (e.g., lack of vaccination or infection history) or immunodeficiency. 
  • Naïve T cells require co-stimulatory signals for activation and differentiation into memory T cells (CD45RO-positive).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A high proportion of memory T cells due to prior antigen exposure: Incorrect. A low CD45RO/CD45RA ratio indicates a predominance of naïve T cells, not memory T cells.

 

Option C. A defective CD2 pathway preventing memory T cell activation: Incorrect. CD2 is involved in the activation of memory T cells, but a low ratio reflects naïve T cell predominance.

 

Option D. Impaired IL-2 signaling leading to an absence of memory T cells: Incorrect. While IL-2 is important for naïve T cell activation, it does not directly influence the CD45RO/CD45RA ratio.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A low CD45RO/CD45RA ratio reflects a predominance of naïve T cells (CD45RA-positive), indicating limited antigenic exposure or potential immunodeficiency.

Peak plasma concentration relative to MIC (peak/MIC ratio).
Total plasma concentration at steady state.

questions.text: A patient with gram-negative bacteremia shows suboptimal response to aminoglycoside therapy. Which of the following pharmacokinetic properties most likely determines the efficacy of aminoglycosides in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peak plasma concentration relative to MIC (peak/MIC ratio).

 

  • Aminoglycosides exhibit concentration-dependent killing, and their efficacy correlates with achieving a high peak/MIC ratio rather than time above the MIC or total concentration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Time above the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC): Incorrect. Aminoglycosides do not rely on time above MIC for efficacy.

 

Option B. Area under the concentration-time curve (AUC): Incorrect. AUC is more relevant to time-dependent agents.

 

Option D. Total plasma concentration at steady state: Incorrect. Total plasma concentration is less important for aminoglycoside efficacy.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Aminoglycoside efficacy is determined by achieving a high peak/MIC ratio.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a stochastic effect of radiation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Genetic mutation

 

  • Genetic mutation is a stochastic effect of radiation. 
  • Stochastic effects are those that occur by chance and are typically associated with long-term exposure to radiation. 
  • These effects include cancer and genetic mutations, which may appear years after the exposure. 
  • The probability of these effects occurring increases as the dose of radiation increases, but the severity is not dose-dependent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radiation-induced myelitis: This is a deterministic effect, not a stochastic effect. Deterministic effects have a threshold dose and are related to the severity of the radiation exposure.

 

Option C. Mucosal enteritis: Like radiation-induced myelitis, mucosal enteritis is a deterministic effect associated with high doses of radiation.

 

Option D. Alopecia: While alopecia (hair loss) can result from radiation exposure, it is also a deterministic effect, which depends on the dose and severity of the radiation exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Stochastic effects of radiation, such as genetic mutations and cancer, occur by chance and are characterized by a probability that increases with dose, though their severity is not dose-dependent. 
  • Understanding these effects is critical in assessing the risks of radiation exposure in medical imaging and treatment.

choices.text: Transverse septum in the proximal vagina

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the outpatient department with complaints of primary amenorrhea and cyclical lower abdominal pain over the past year. She denies any history of sexual activity. On physical examination, a bulge is observed at the vaginal introitus, which is soft and bluish in appearance. Digital rectal examination reveals a tense, elongated mass along the vaginal canal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Imperforate hymen

 

  • Imperforate hymen is a congenital anomaly that results in the obstruction of menstrual blood outflow, leading to primary amenorrhea and cyclical pain due to the accumulation of blood (hematocolpos).
  • On examination, the bluish bulge protruding at the vaginal introitus is characteristic of an imperforate hymen.
  • The condition is confirmed clinically and treated with a cruciate incision to drain the accumulated blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transverse septum in the proximal vagina: A transverse vaginal septum can also cause primary amenorrhea and cyclical pain, but the obstruction is located higher in the vagina, so the bulge is not visible at the introitus. Hematocolpos is not observed, but hematometra (blood collection in the uterus) may develop.

 

Option B. Complete vaginal atresia: This condition is characterized by the absence of the vaginal canal. It also presents with primary amenorrhea and cyclical pain. However, a bulge at the introitus will not be observed, and there will be hematometra or a blind-ending vagina on examination.

 

Option D. Cervical agenesis: In cervical agenesis, the obstruction is at the level of the cervix, leading to hematometra and sometimes hematosalpinx. Clinical examination reveals some normal external genitalia with no visible bulge at the introitus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with primary amenorrhea and cyclical pain, an obstructive anomaly should be suspected. 
  • Imperforate hymen presents with a bluish bulge at the introitus due to hematocolpos. 
  • Diagnosis is clinical, and treatment involves a cruciate incision to relieve the obstruction. 
  • Differentiation from other obstructive conditions, such as transverse septum or vaginal atresia, relies on physical findings and imaging.

questions.text: Find the incorrect match regarding Ankle Brachial Pressure Index (ABPI):
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Limb threatening ischemia- 0.5

 

  • This is the incorrect match. A value less than/equal to 0.4 suggests chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI), not 0.5.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal - 0.9-1.2: The normal resting ABI is indeed 0.9–1.4.

 

Option B. Diabetes mellitus - 1.5: Correct. Artificially high ABI readings (>1.4) can occur in patients with diabetes mellitus due to media sclerosis and calcification of the arterial wall, causing vessel incompressibility.

 

Option D. Drop in resting ABI after exercise in patients with PAD - 25%: A drop in the resting ABI of >20% after exercise is indicative of flow-limiting arterial disease.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Under standing the correct ranges of the Ankle-Brachial Pressure Index (ABI) and recognizing the significance of a drop in ABI after exercise in patients with peripheral arterial disease.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents with a fluctuant mass in the jaw region and purulent discharge from multiple sinuses. The culture shows the colonies displayed in the given image below. Which of the following is a key feature of the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gram-positive obligate anaerobe

 

  • Actinomyces species are Gram-positive obligate anaerobes that are part of the normal oral and gastrointestinal flora, is characterized by the formation of molar tooth colonies on culture. 
  • They cause chronic granulomatous infections, particularly in immunocompromised hosts or following mucosal injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gram-negative obligate anaerobe: Incorrect; Actinomyces are Gram-positive.

 

Option B. Gram-positive facultative anaerobe: Incorrect; Actinomyces are obligate anaerobes.

 

Option D. Acid-fast bacterium: Acid-fast staining identifies Mycobacterium species, not Actinomyces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Actinomyces species are Gram-positive obligate anaerobes associated with chronic granulomatous infections, presenting with molar tooth colonies on culture.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents to the emergency room with a history of diarrhea for 3 days. On examination, the child is lethargic, has a weak and thready pulse, and exhibits a prolonged capillary refill time. The skin turgor test shows a recoil time of more than 2 seconds. Which of the following is the most likely level of dehydration in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe dehydration

 

  • The child’s symptoms, including lethargy, weak and thready pulse, prolonged capillary refill, and skin turgor recoil >2 seconds, are consistent with severe dehydration (loss of >9% body weight). 
  • These findings indicate significant fluid loss requiring immediate intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No or minimal dehydration: This would present with normal mental status, normal thirst, and normal physical findings (e.g., instant skin recoil).

 

Option B. Mild to moderate dehydration: Symptoms would include fatigue or irritability, thirst, increased heart rate, and skin turgor recoil of less than 2 seconds, which are less severe than those described.

 

Option D. Hypervolemia: This refers to an excess of fluid in the body and is not relevant in the context of diarrhea and dehydration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Severe dehydration presents with lethargy, poor perfusion (prolonged capillary refill), weak or impalpable pulses, and delayed skin turgor recoil. 
  • Immediate rehydration therapy is critical to prevent complications.

choices.text: Urothelial neoplasm of low malignant potential

questions.text: A bladder biopsy reveals a lesion diagnosed as papillary urothelial carcinoma, grade 2, using the old WHO system. How would this lesion most likely be classified under the WHO/ISUP system?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Papillary urothelial carcinoma, low grade

 

  • Under the WHO/ISUP system, most grade 2 lesions in the old WHO classification are reclassified as low-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma based on architectural and cytological features.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Papillary urothelial carcinoma, high grade: Includes lesions previously classified as grade 3.

 

Option C. Urothelial neoplasm of low malignant potential: Represents lesions with minimal atypia and no invasion.

 

Option D. Urothelial papilloma: Represents benign lesions with no malignant potential.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The WHO/ISUP classification simplifies the grading of urothelial carcinomas into low grade and high grade, with most grade 2 lesions reclassified as low grade.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman, Mrs. Meena from Delhi, is brought to the emergency department with severe nausea, vomiting, palpitations, and altered mental status. She has a history of Graves' hyperthyroidism and was treated with methimazole, which was stopped 2 months ago due to a rash. Three days prior, she underwent radioactive iodine (RAI) therapy. She has no history of tobacco or alcohol use.

 

On Examination:

 

  • Vitals:
    • Temperature: 39.4°C (103°F)
    • Blood pressure: 160/90 mmHg
    • Pulse: 160/min
    • Respirations: 24/min
  • Agitated and confused.
  • Thyroid: Diffusely enlarged but nontender.
  • Fine hand tremor and mild lid lag.

 

Investigations:

  • TSH: <0.01 µU/mL
  • Total T3: 444 ng/mL
  • Free T4: 4.7 ng/dL

 

What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Propranolol and propylthiouracil (PTU)

 

  • The patient presents with a thyroid storm, a life-threatening complication of hyperthyroidism triggered by radioactive iodine therapy.

 

Key Features of Thyroid Storm:

 

  • Severe hyperthyroid symptoms (e.g., tachycardia, fever, agitation, tremors).
  • Systemic involvement (e.g., gastrointestinal symptoms, confusion).
  • Precipitating factors: RAI therapy, surgery, or infections.

 

Management:

 

  • Propranolol: Controls tachycardia and adrenergic symptoms.
  • Propylthiouracil (PTU): Reduces thyroid hormone synthesis and decreases peripheral T4 to T3 conversion.
  • Supportive therapy: IV fluids, cooling blankets, and antipyretics (e.g., acetaminophen).

  • Dexamethasone: May be added to reduce T4 to T3 conversion.

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood cultures and empiric antibiotics: There is no evidence of infection (e.g., fever with normal leukocyte count and no localizing signs), making sepsis unlikely.

 

Option B. Dexamethasone: Dexamethasone is used adjunctively in thyroid storm but is not the primary treatment.

 

Option D. Lorazepam: Benzodiazepines may help with agitation but do not address the underlying thyroid storm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thyroid storm requires urgent treatment with beta-blockers (e.g., propranolol) and antithyroid drugs (e.g., PTU) to control symptoms and reduce hormone levels.

questions.text: Dupuytren’s contracture the basic pathology involves:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myofibroblasts

 

  • Myofibroblasts are fibroblast-like cells that exhibit contractile properties similar to smooth muscle cells. 
  • They are key players in wound healing and tissue remodeling. In the case of Dupuytren's contracture, myofibroblasts proliferate and secrete excessive amounts of collagen, leading to fibrosis (thickening) of the palmar fascia.
  •  Over time, this results in the development of thick cords of tissue that pull the fingers into a bent position, causing the characteristic contracture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fibroblasts:

 

  • Fibroblasts are cells responsible for producing collagen and extracellular matrix, which provide structural support to tissues. 
  • While fibroblasts do play a role in Dupuytren's contracture by contributing to the thickening of the palmar fascia, myofibroblasts (a more specialized form of fibroblasts with contractile abilities) are primarily involved in the disease pathology.
  • So, while fibroblasts are important, myofibroblasts are more directly responsible for the contracture.

 

Option C. Fascia:

 

  • The palmar fascia is a fibrous connective tissue structure in the palm of the hand.
  • While Dupuytren's contracture affects the fascia (leading to thickening and shortening), the basic pathology is more related to the cells (myofibroblasts) that interact with the fascia, rather than the fascia itself. 
  • So, the fascia is involved, but the answer focuses on the cell type involved in the pathological process.

 

Option D. Tendon:

 

  • Tendons connect muscles to bones and are not primarily involved in Dupuytren's contracture. The condition affects the palmar fascia, not the tendons. Therefore, this option is not correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dupuytren’s contracture is a condition in which myofibroblasts (contractile fibroblasts) proliferate and produce excessive collagen, causing fibrosis and contracture of the palmar fascia, leading to bending of the fingers.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with osteoporosis is started on risedronate to reduce her risk of fractures. The medication acts by inhibiting an enzyme involved in cholesterol biosynthesis, disrupting osteoclast function. Which of the following enzymes is directly inhibited by risedronate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Farnesyl pyrophosphate synthase (FPPS)

 

  • Risedronate is a bisphosphonate that inhibits farnesyl pyrophosphate synthase (FPPS), a key enzyme in the mevalonate pathway. 
  • FPPS catalyzes the synthesis of farnesyl pyrophosphate, a precursor for isoprenoid lipids crucial for osteoclast function. 
  • By inhibiting this enzyme, risedronate disrupts osteoclast activity, reducing bone resorption and increasing bone density
  • This mechanism makes bisphosphonates like risedronate highly effective in treating osteoporosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HMG-CoA reductase: Statins inhibit this enzyme, reducing cholesterol synthesis. Risedronate does not target HMG-CoA reductase.

 

Option C. Squalene synthase: This enzyme is involved later in cholesterol synthesis but is not inhibited by risedronate.

 

Option D. Geranylgeranyl transferase: This enzyme is responsible for post-translational prenylation of proteins but is not directly inhibited by risedronate.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Risedronate inhibits farnesyl pyrophosphate synthase in the mevalonate pathway, impairing osteoclast function and reducing bone resorption.

Enhanced angiogenesis within the tumor microenvironment
Inactivation of retinoblastoma (RB) tumor suppressor protein

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with a rapidly growing bladder tumor. Genetic analysis reveals an activating mutation in the HRAS oncogene. What is the primary role of this mutation in the pathogenesis of bladder carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased invasiveness and metastatic potential

 

  • HRAS mutations are associated with enhanced invasiveness and metastatic potential in bladder carcinoma by promoting cell proliferation and tumor progression. 
  • These mutations contribute to the transformation from adenomas to carcinomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of apoptosis and promotion of tumor cell survival: While relevant to tumor growth, HRAS mutations primarily drive invasiveness.

 

Option B. Enhanced angiogenesis within the tumor microenvironment: Not a primary role of HRAS in bladder carcinoma.

 

Option D. Inactivation of retinoblastoma (RB) tumor suppressor protein: HRAS mutation has no effect on inactivation of Rb gene in HRAS-driven bladder carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Activating mutations in HRAS enhance the invasiveness and metastatic potential of bladder carcinomas, contributing to their aggressive behavior.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man sustains a severe alkali burn to his eye while working in an industrial setting. Despite initial irrigation and treatment, he presents three weeks later with persistent epithelial defects and chronic visual impairment. Which of the following complications is the hallmark of alkali injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Limbal stem cell deficiency

 

Explanation:


Limbal stem cell deficiency is the hallmark complication of alkali injuries due to their deeper tissue penetration and destruction of limbal stem cells. The loss of limbal stem cells leads to persistent epithelial defects, conjunctivalization of the cornea, and chronic visual impairment. These changes significantly impact corneal transparency and vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conjunctival scarring: Conjunctival scarring is a common long-term complication of ocular injuries but is not as immediate or severe as limbal stem cell deficiency in alkali burns.

 

Option C. Corneal neovascularization: Corneal neovascularization occurs in later stages of healing as a secondary response to limbal stem cell loss. It is not the primary hallmark of alkali injuries.

 

Option D. Symblepharon: Symblepharon refers to adhesions between the bulbar and palpebral conjunctiva. While it may occur in severe cases of ocular injuries, it is less common and less critical than limbal stem cell deficiency in alkali burns.

 

Educational Objective:


Limbal stem cell deficiency is the defining feature of alkali injuries, leading to persistent epithelial defects and chronic visual impairment. Understanding this complication helps prioritize treatment and preventive measures for ocular injuries.

questions.text: Which of the following parasitic infections is most closely associated with the histological finding shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Schistosoma haematobium

 

  • Schistosoma haematobium is a trematode parasite that causes chronic schistosomiasis, leading to squamous cell carcinoma of the urinary bladder.
  • The keratin pearls shown in the image are characteristic of squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Chronic inflammation and fibrosis induced by this parasite predispose to malignancy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clonorchis sinensis: Associated with cholangiocarcinoma due to bile duct inflammation and damage.

 

Option C. Schistosoma mansoni: Causes intestinal and hepatic schistosomiasis, associated with portal hypertension but not bladder cancer.

 

Option D. Opisthorchis viverrini: Linked to bile duct carcinoma, similar to Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Schistosoma haematobium is linked to bladder squamous cell carcinoma, often presenting with keratin pearls on histology.

questions.text: A patient with the condition in the image is being treated with systemic corticosteroids. Which additional treatment is most appropriate to prevent disease progression?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Azathioprine

 

  • In bullous pemphigoid, systemic corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment. Immunosuppressive agents like azathioprine are often added to reduce steroid dosage and prevent disease progression. 
  • Azathioprine inhibits purine synthesis, reducing lymphocyte proliferation and modulating the autoimmune response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methotrexate: Incorrect. Methotrexate is primarily used in psoriasis and other conditions, not first-line for bullous pemphigoid.

 

Option B. Dapsone: Incorrect. Used for dermatitis herpetiformis, not bullous pemphigoid.

 

Option C. Rituximab: Incorrect. Rituximab is a second-line therapy for refractory cases.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Azathioprine is often used alongside corticosteroids to manage bullous pemphigoid and reduce steroid dependency.

questions.text: A 29-year-old patient diagnosed with secondary syphilis presents with mucosal lesions, as shown in the image. Which of the following statements about these lesions is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mucous patches are painless and highly infectious.

 

  • Mucous patches in secondary syphilis are painless, shallow ulcers or erosions on mucous membranes that are teeming with spirochetes, making them highly infectious. 
  • They are often seen in conjunction with the rash of secondary syphilis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Mucous patches in secondary syphilis are painless but highly infectious due to the presence of spirochetes.

choices.text: Diathermy excision with base cauterization ± Dapsone

questions.text: A 25-year-old man from a coastal area presents with a history of nasal stuffiness and blood-tinged nasal discharge for 3 months. On examination, a polypoidal, strawberry-colored mass is observed in the nasal cavity that bleeds on touch. Biopsy confirms the presence of spores bursting through the chitinous wall of sporangia. What is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diathermy excision with base cauterization ± Dapsone

 

  • The treatment of rhinosporidiosis caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi involves surgical excision of the lesion using diathermy and cauterization of the base to prevent recurrence. 
  • Dapsone is sometimes used adjunctively for its anti-inflammatory and anti-protozoal effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibiotic therapy with tetracycline: Antibiotics are ineffective as rhinosporidiosis is caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, now classified under protozoa, and not bacteria.

 

Option C. Radiation therapy: Radiation therapy is not used for rhinosporidiosis as it is ineffective and not part of standard treatment protocols.

 

Option D. Antifungal therapy with itraconazole: While Rhinosporidium seeberi was initially thought to be a fungus, it is now classified under protozoa, and antifungal agents are not effective.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The treatment of rhinosporidiosis involves diathermy excision of the lesion with base cauterization to prevent recurrence, with optional adjunctive use of Dapsone.

questions.text: Which of the following facility-based newborn care services is most appropriate for a neonate weighing 1500 g and requiring continuous monitoring but not assisted ventilation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Special Newborn Care Unit

 

  • Special Newborn Care Units (SNCUs) provide care for neonates weighing less than 1800 g and those needing comprehensive monitoring and treatment but not assisted ventilation or major surgery. 
  • This facility is ideal for a 1500 g neonate requiring continuous monitoring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Newborn Care Corner: This is not equipped for monitoring neonates with significant medical conditions.

 

Option B. Neonatal Intensive Care Unit: NICUs are reserved for advanced care, including ventilation and major surgical procedures, which are not needed in this case.

 

Option D. Newborn Stabilization Unit: These units cater to neonates weighing more than 1800 g and provide stabilization rather than comprehensive care.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Special Newborn Care Units (SNCUs) provide advanced care for neonates weighing less than 1800 g, excluding cases requiring assisted ventilation or major surgical interventions.

choices.text: Chronic phenytoin-induced folate deficiency leading to megaloblastic anemia.
Iron deficiency anemia unrelated to phenytoin use.
Vitamin B12 deficiency associated with phenytoin.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with epilepsy presents with fatigue and pallor. Laboratory findings include hemoglobin of 4.8 g/dL, MCV of 75 fL, MCH of 23 pg/dL, and total leukocyte count of 7500/mm³. He has been taking phenytoin for 3 years. What is the most likely underlying cause of his anemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Iron deficiency anemia unrelated to phenytoin use.

 

  • The patient’s microcytic hypochromic anemia (low MCV and MCH) strongly suggests iron deficiency anemia. 
  • This type of anemia is not a common side effect of phenytoin, which typically causes macrocytic anemia due to folate deficiency. 
  • Investigating iron deficiency with iron studies is appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic phenytoin-induced folate deficiency leading to megaloblastic anemia: Phenytoin-induced folate deficiency causes macrocytic anemia, not microcytic hypochromic anemia.

 

Option C. Phenytoin-induced bone marrow suppression causing pancytopenia: Pancytopenia would involve reductions in all cell lines (e.g., hemoglobin, white blood cells, and platelets), which is not observed in this patient.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12 deficiency associated with phenytoin: Vitamin B12 deficiency causes macrocytic anemia and is not typically associated with phenytoin use.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Microcytic hypochromic anemia is consistent with iron deficiency. Phenytoin-associated anemia is typically macrocytic due to folate deficiency.

choices.text: Switch to lactose-free formula and initiate calcium supplementation
Begin antibiotic therapy for suspected neonatal sepsis
Administer intravenous glucose and continue breastfeeding

questions.text: A 2-day-old newborn presents with lethargy, jaundice, vomiting, and feeding intolerance. The infant was born at term and had been exclusively breastfed. Laboratory findings reveal elevated transaminases, hyperbilirubinemia, and reducing substances in the urine. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Switch to lactose-free formula and initiate calcium supplementation

 

  • The presentation is consistent with classic galactosemia, an autosomal recessive disorder caused by deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase. 
  • This leads to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate, causing multi-organ damage, particularly in the liver, kidneys, and brain.
  • Immediate elimination of galactose and lactose from the diet is critical to prevent further accumulation of toxic metabolites. Non-lactose containing formula is recommended.
  • Calcium supplementation is necessary to compensate for calcium loss due to the elimination of milk products.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Initiate phototherapy for neonatal jaundice: Phototherapy is useful for unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia but does not address the underlying metabolic disorder in galactosemia.

 

Option C. Begin antibiotic therapy for suspected neonatal sepsis: While galactosemia increases the risk of E. coli neonatal sepsis, this infant's primary issue is metabolic, requiring dietary management. Antibiotics might be indicated if sepsis is confirmed but are not the first-line management here.

 

Option D. Administer intravenous glucose and continue breastfeeding: Continuing breastfeeding would worsen the condition by providing more lactose, the precursor of galactose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Galactosemia is a metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency in galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase. 
  • Early recognition and dietary management with a non-lactose containing formula are critical to preventing life-threatening complications like liver failure, sepsis, and brain damage. 
  • Calcium supplementation is essential due to the exclusion of dairy products from the diet.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic with fatigue and muscle weakness. She has been on a calorie-restricted diet for the past six months, consisting mainly of white rice and very few legumes. The physician suspects a thiamine deficiency. Which of the following foods should be included in her diet to provide the highest thiamine content?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gingelly seeds

 

  • Gingelly seeds have the highest thiamine content compared to other foods listed. 
  • Thiamine, also known as vitamin B1, is essential for energy metabolism, and its deficiency is common in diets predominantly based on polished rice. 
  • Including thiamine-rich foods like gingelly seeds can help alleviate deficiency symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bengal gram: Though rich in thiamine, it has less compared to gingelly seeds.

 

Option C. Groundnut: Contains thiamine but in smaller quantities than gingelly seeds.

 

Option D. Raw rice: Has the least thiamine content and is inadequate for addressing deficiency.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The descending order of thiamine content in foods: gingelly seeds > groundnut > Bengal gram > whole wheat > raw rice.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for preventing arterial thrombosis in patients undergoing PCI and works by targeting the P2Y12 receptor?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prasugrel

 

  • Prasugrel is an antiplatelet agent that selectively targets the P2Y12 receptor, preventing platelet activation and aggregation, making it ideal for preventing arterial thrombosis after PCI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Edoxaban: Incorrect. Edoxaban is an anticoagulant acting on factor Xa.

 

Option B. Dabigatran: Incorrect. Dabigatran inhibits thrombin, reducing venous thromboembolism risk.

 

Option D. Dicumarol: Incorrect. Dicumarol is a vitamin K antagonist and is not used for arterial thrombosis prevention.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Prasugrel is used to prevent arterial thrombosis in PCI by inhibiting platelet aggregation through P2Y12 receptor antagonism.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman presents with a history of heavy and irregular uterine bleeding for the past six months. A transvaginal ultrasound reveals thickened endometrium. She is scheduled for a dilation and curettage (D&C) procedure to evaluate and treat the underlying condition. During the procedure, the instrument shown in the image is used. Identify this instrument.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Uterine curette

 

  • The image shows a uterine curette, a surgical instrument used for scraping or curetting the endometrium.
  • It is commonly used in procedures such as:
    • Dilation and Curettage (D&C): For diagnostic or therapeutic purposes in abnormal uterine bleeding.
    • Post-suction evacuation in medical termination of pregnancy (MTP): To ensure complete removal of retained products of conception.
  • Structure:
    • The curette has two ends:
      • Sharp end: Used in gynecological procedures.
      • Blunt end: Used in obstetric procedures to prevent trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ovum forceps:

 

  • Ovum forceps are used to grasp and remove retained products of conception or during suction evacuation.
  • They are long with a fenestrated and serrated tip, making them unsuitable for curetting the endometrium.

 

Option B. Punch biopsy forceps:

 

  • These are used for obtaining tissue samples from the cervix or other accessible lesions during colposcopy.
  • They have a small cutting edge for excising tissue, not suitable for endometrial curettage.

 

Option C. Tenaculum:

 

  • A tenaculum is a sharp-pointed, hook-like instrument used to grasp and stabilize the cervix during gynecological procedures.
  • It does not perform curettage but aids in procedures requiring cervical manipulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A uterine curette is a vital instrument in gynecological procedures, particularly for D&C and management of abnormal uterine bleeding. 
  • It comes in sharp and blunt variations, catering to different procedural needs while minimizing trauma.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presented to OPD with complaints of pain over her right leg especially the knee for the past 3 days. She had a recent history of fall from her bicycle. The given image is the CT scan of the right lower limb. Which of the following statements is true regarding the structure pointed in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is the pes anserinus group

 

  • The pes anserinus group is formed by the tendons of the sartorius, gracilis, and semitendinosus muscles.
  • It is located medial to the medial surface of the tibia, near the proximal tibial region, which corresponds to the structure indicated in the CT scan.
  • These tendons form a conjoined structure that inserts onto the anteromedial surface of the proximal tibia. 
  • This area is often associated with pes anserinus bursitis in clinical practice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the extensor muscles of the leg: The extensor muscles form the anterior compartment of the leg and arise from the lateral surface of the tibia. These include the tibialis anterior, extensor hallucis longus, extensor digitorum longus, and peroneus tertius. They are not related to the structure indicated in the medial tibial region.

 

Option B. It is the hamstrings muscle group: The hamstrings are located in the posterior thigh and arise from the ischial tuberosity. This group includes the semitendinosus, semimembranosus, adductor magnus (ischial head), and the long head of the biceps femoris. While the semitendinosus contributes to the pes anserinus, the hamstrings as a group are not confined to the indicated region in the image.

 

Option D. It is the peroneal muscle group: The peroneal muscles are located on the lateral side of the leg and arise from the lateral surface of the fibula. These include the peroneus longus and peroneus brevis. They are unrelated to the medial structure highlighted in the CT image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The pes anserinus group, composed of the sartorius, gracilis, and semitendinosus tendons, is located medially to the proximal tibia. 
  • This structure is crucial in knee stabilization and is often involved in pes anserinus bursitis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman at 32 weeks of gestation presents with painless vaginal bleeding. Ultrasound reveals that the placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it. Based on the image provided and the clinical findings, identify the type of placenta previa.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type II 

 

  • In Type II placenta previa (marginal), the placenta extends to the margin of the internal cervical os but does not cover it. 
  • This is consistent with the ultrasound findings and the provided image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I (Low-lying): In Type I placenta previa, the majority of the placenta is attached to the upper uterine segment, with only the lower margin encroaching on the lower segment but not reaching the internal os. This is not consistent with the findings in this case.

 

Option C. Type III (Incomplete or Partial Central): In Type III placenta previa, the placenta partially covers the internal os when it is closed but does not completely cover it when the cervix is fully dilated. This is not described in the case.

 

Option D. Type IV (Complete or Total Central): In Type IV placenta previa, the placenta completely covers the internal os even when it is fully dilated. This is not the case here, as the placenta does not cover the os.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Type II (Marginal) placenta previa is characterized by the placenta reaching the margin of the internal cervical os without covering it, leading to painless vaginal bleeding in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is admitted with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and initiated on unfractionated heparin therapy. After 72 hours, he develops thrombocytopenia (platelet count 40,000/µL). What is the best course of action?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Discontinue heparin and start argatroban with aPTT monitoring.

 

  • The patient’s thrombocytopenia is suggestive of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), which necessitates discontinuing all heparin products. 
  • Argatroban, a direct thrombin inhibitor, is preferred in such cases, with aPTT monitoring to guide dosing. 
  • Initiating warfarin during acute HIT is contraindicated due to the risk of warfarin-induced skin necrosis. 
  • Enoxaparin, a low molecular weight heparin, is also contraindicated in HIT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue heparin and monitor platelet counts: Incorrect. Continuing heparin risks further thrombocytopenia and thrombosis.

 

Option C. Discontinue heparin and initiate warfarin therapy immediately: Incorrect. Warfarin is not started in the acute phase of HIT.

 

Option D. Switch to enoxaparin as it is less likely to cause thrombocytopenia: Incorrect. Enoxaparin is contraindicated in HIT due to cross-reactivity with heparin.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • In HIT, discontinue heparin and initiate a direct thrombin inhibitor like argatroban with aPTT monitoring. 
  • Avoid warfarin and low molecular weight heparins in the acute phase.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with a barking cough, inspiratory stridor, and respiratory distress. The child is diagnosed with moderate to severe croup. Which of the following is not recommended as part of the treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Broad-spectrum antibiotics

 

  • Racemic epinephrine nebulization: Indicated for moderate to severe croup to reduce airway swelling and relieve stridor.
  • Dexamethasone: Administered in all grades of croup through the least invasive route (oral > IM > IV). It helps reduce airway inflammation and the need for hospitalization.
  • Oxygen therapy: Provided for hypoxemia (SpO₂ <92%).
  • Antibiotics: Not indicated for croup as it is primarily caused by viral infections, such as parainfluenza virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Management of moderate to severe croup includes racemic epinephrine nebulization, dexamethasone, and oxygen for hypoxemia. 
  • Antibiotics are not indicated as croup is typically viral in etiology.
