questions.text:
A 30-year-old man, Ramesh from Bengaluru, presents with progressive weakness and back pain over the past 4 days. He initially noticed tingling in his feet and hands, followed by difficulty walking. He now reports palpitations, excessive sweating, and mild shortness of breath. He denies recent travel, infections, or vaccinations. His past medical history is unremarkable, and he drinks alcohol occasionally but does not use tobacco or drugs.

 

Examination Findings:

 

  • Neurological:
    • Pupils: Bilateral sluggish reaction to light.
    • Speech: Mild dysarthria.
    • Upper extremity strength: 4/5 with hyporeflexia.
    • Lower extremity strength: 3/5 with areflexia.
    • Sensation: Decreased vibration and proprioception in both feet.
  • No spine tenderness or neck rigidity.

 

Investigations:

 

  • Chest X-ray: Normal.
  • Complete blood count: Normal.
  • Basic metabolic panel: Normal.

 

Which of the following findings on lumbar puncture would most likely confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased protein with normal leukocyte count and normal glucose

 

  • This patient’s clinical features—progressive weakness, areflexia, sensory loss, and autonomic dysfunction—are classic for Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS).

 

CSF Findings in GBS:

 

  • Albuminocytologic dissociation:
    • Elevated CSF protein (>45 mg/dL).
    • Normal CSF white blood cell count (<10 cells/µL).
    • Normal CSF glucose.
    • This occurs due to inflammation and demyelination of peripheral nerves without CNS infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased protein, elevated leukocyte count, and normal glucose: Suggests infectious meningitis, not GBS.

 

Option C. Increased protein, decreased glucose, and elevated leukocyte count: Suggests tubercular or fungal meningitis, not GBS.

 

Option D. Normal protein, normal glucose, and normal leukocyte count: Normal CSF findings are inconsistent with GBS, which demonstrates albuminocytologic dissociation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The hallmark CSF finding in Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is albuminocytologic dissociation, characterized by elevated protein with a normal white blood cell count. 
  • This pattern is diagnostic and helps differentiate GBS from infectious or inflammatory conditions.

questions.text: A pharmacologist conducts an experiment with adrenaline in the presence of different antagonists and analyzes their dose-response curves. One of the antagonists shifts the curve to the right without reducing the maximal response. Which type of antagonist is most likely responsible for this observation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Reversible competitive antagonist

 

  • Reversible competitive antagonists compete with the agonist (e.g., adrenaline) for the same binding site on the receptor. 
  • This competition shifts the dose-response curve to the right, indicating that higher concentrations of the agonist are required to achieve the same effect. 
  • Importantly, the maximal response remains unchanged because increasing the agonist concentration can displace the antagonist.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Non-competitive antagonist: This reduces the maximal response by binding to a different site or altering receptor function, which was not observed in this case.

 

Option B. Irreversible competitive antagonist: This also reduces the maximal response because the antagonist forms a covalent bond with the receptor, preventing agonist binding even at high concentrations.

 

Option D. Allosteric antagonist: This binds to a different site on the receptor and changes the receptor's configuration, reducing the maximal response or altering the curve differently.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Reversible competitive antagonists shift the dose-response curve of an agonist to the right without affecting the maximal response.

questions.text: A drug classified as an inverse agonist at benzodiazepine receptors is likely to produce which of the following effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased anxiety and seizures

 

  • Inverse agonists at benzodiazepine receptors, such as beta-carbolines, reduce receptor activity below baseline, opposing the effects of benzodiazepine agonists. 
  • This leads to increased neuronal excitability, manifesting as heightened anxiety, restlessness, and seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sedation and anxiolysis: Sedation and anxiolysis are effects of agonists at benzodiazepine receptors, not inverse agonists.

 

Option C. Reduction of dopamine activity: Dopamine activity is not directly affected by benzodiazepine receptor modulation.

 

Option D. Partial dopamine receptor blockade: Partial dopamine receptor blockade is unrelated to benzodiazepine receptor effects.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Inverse agonists reduce receptor activity below baseline, leading to excitatory effects like anxiety and seizures at benzodiazepine receptors.

questions.text: A middle-aged male presents with fever and diarrhea for 1 week and acute onset abdominal pain for the past 6 hours. On physical examination, he shows signs of dehydration, and his vital signs reveal tachycardia and hypotension. An erect abdominal X-ray is taken. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Toxic megacolon

 

  • The radiographic findings of dilated transverse and descending colon with loss of characteristic haustrations are suggestive of toxic megacolon, which is often associated with inflammatory bowel diseases like ulcerative colitis. 
  • The key diagnostic criteria include a significantly dilated colon (>6 cm) along with clinical signs such as fever, tachycardia, neutrophilic leukocytosis, and altered sensorium. 
  • Treatment involves immediate medical management, including antibiotics, steroids, and supportive care. Surgery is considered if the condition does not improve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Appendicitis: Appendicitis typically presents with right lower quadrant pain, fever, and nausea/vomiting. The radiographic findings would show localized inflammation, not a dilated colon. The absence of a localized pain pattern and the features of generalized colonic distension make appendicitis unlikely.

 

Option B. Perforation peritonitis: While perforation can lead to peritonitis and is associated with air under the diaphragm on radiographs, the absence of free air in this patient’s X-ray makes perforation peritonitis less likely. Toxic megacolon can cause symptoms similar to perforation but with distinct radiographic features such as colonic dilation.

 

Option D. Pneumatosis intestinalis: Pneumatosis intestinalis refers to the presence of gas within the wall of the intestines and is usually associated with conditions such as ischemic bowel or inflammatory bowel disease. It does not typically present with the extensive colonic dilation seen in toxic megacolon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Toxic megacolon is a life-threatening condition characterized by massive colonic distention, often seen in patients with inflammatory bowel disease. 
  • Diagnosis is confirmed through imaging (X-ray/CT) and clinical criteria, including fever, tachycardia, leukocytosis, and abdominal distention. 
  • Early recognition and management are essential to prevent complications such as perforation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida presents to the emergency room at 37 weeks of gestation with painful genital ulcers and mild fever for the past two days. She denies a history of similar lesions in the past. On examination, multiple vesicular and ulcerative lesions are noted on the vulva and perineal region. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Elective cesarean section

 

  • Primary genital herpes infection: This patient presents with a primary episode of genital herpes simplex virus (HSV), confirmed by the absence of a prior history of similar lesions and the PCR result.
  • Risk to the neonate: In cases of primary HSV, the risk of neonatal herpes following vaginal delivery is very high (up to 50%), leading to significant morbidity and mortality. Neonatal herpes can result in disseminated disease, central nervous system involvement, and death.
  • Management: Initiation of antiviral therapy (Acyclovir) is critical for maternal symptom control. However, the recommended mode of delivery to minimize neonatal transmission is elective cesarean section.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start antivirals and proceed with vaginal delivery: This is incorrect as vaginal delivery significantly increases the risk of neonatal herpes in primary HSV infection. Antivirals reduce maternal viral shedding and symptoms but do not eliminate the risk of transmission.

 

Option C. Wait for spontaneous labor onset and proceed with vaginal delivery: This is also incorrect because spontaneous vaginal delivery increases the risk of neonatal infection, especially in primary HSV.

 

Option D. No intervention is required: This is incorrect. Without intervention, the risk of neonatal transmission is unacceptably high, and maternal symptoms will persist without antiviral therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In primary genital herpes simplex virus infection during pregnancy, the risk of neonatal herpes following vaginal delivery is very high. 
  • Initiation of antiviral therapy (e.g., Acyclovir) is essential, and the preferred mode of delivery to reduce neonatal risk is elective cesarean section.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with peripheral neuropathy is unable to detect sustained pressure on his foot caused by his shoe. Which receptor dysfunction most likely explains this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Merkel’s discs

 

  • Merkel’s discs are specialized slow-adapting mechanoreceptors located in the basal epidermis and hair follicles. These receptors play a critical role in detecting sustained pressure, fine touch, and texture discrimination. Dysfunction of Merkel’s discs, often due to peripheral neuropathy (e.g., diabetic neuropathy), impairs the ability to perceive prolonged tactile stimuli, such as the sustained pressure caused by tight footwear.

 

Key features of Merkel’s discs:

 

  • Function: Sustained pressure and texture perception.
  • Location: Fingertips, lips, and specialized areas with high tactile resolution.

  • Adaptation: Slow-adapting, allowing them to respond continuously to a prolonged stimulus.

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meissner’s corpuscles: These are rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors responsible for detecting light touch and low-frequency vibrations. Dysfunction would impair light touch perception rather than sustained pressure.

 

Option B. Pacinian corpuscles: These are rapidly adapting receptors specialized for detecting high-frequency vibrations and transient pressure changes, such as a tap or fluttering sensation. Sustained pressure detection is not their primary function.

 

Option D. Hair follicle receptors: These receptors are sensitive to hair movement and light touch but do not detect sustained pressure. Dysfunction of these receptors would result in impaired detection of hair movement, not prolonged tactile stimuli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Merkel’s discs are slow-adapting mechanoreceptors essential for detecting sustained pressure and texture. 
  • Their dysfunction in conditions like peripheral neuropathy impairs prolonged tactile perception, increasing the risk of unnoticed pressure-related injuries.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of abnormal vaginal discharge and mild pelvic discomfort for the past week. She denies any significant fever or systemic symptoms. On examination, the cervix appears erythematous with mucopurulent discharge. A cervical swab is taken for investigation. Her sexual history reveals multiple partners in the past year. Based on the clinical presentation and findings, what is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neisseria gonorrhoeae

 

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis are the most common causes of cervicitis, which presents with mucopurulent cervical discharge, friability, and erythema.
  • In sexually active women with risk factors, gonorrhoeae is a leading bacterial sexually transmitted infection. It can cause ascending infections leading to pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) if untreated.

 

  • Management:
    • Ceftriaxone (500 mg IM) + Azithromycin (1 g orally) is the recommended treatment for gonorrhoeae.
    • This dual therapy also provides coverage for Chlamydia trachomatis, which often coexists.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trichomonas vaginalis:

 

  • This protozoan infection is a common cause of vaginitis, not cervicitis.
  • Clinical presentation includes frothy greenish-yellow discharge, vaginal irritation, and strawberry cervix on examination.

 

Option C. Candida albicans:

 

  • Candida is associated with vulvovaginal candidiasis rather than cervicitis.
  • Presents with thick, curd-like vaginal discharge and intense itching, without mucopurulent cervical discharge.

 

Option D. Gardnerella vaginalis:

 

  • Gardnerella is the most common causative organism of bacterial vaginosis (BV), not cervicitis.
  • BV presents with thin, grayish-white discharge and a fishy odor (positive whiff test).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common causes of cervicitis are Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis. 
  • These infections present with mucopurulent cervical discharge and may lead to severe complications if untreated. 
  • Treatment includes dual therapy with Ceftriaxone and Azithromycin to cover both pathogens effectively.

questions.text: All of the following are complications of an open aortic aneurysm repair except :
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endoleak

 

  • This is not a complication of open aortic aneurysm repair. 
  • Endoleak is specific to endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR), where there is persistent blood flow within the aneurysm sac despite graft placement.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Aortoduodenal fistula: This is a complication of open aortic aneurysm repair. Aortoduodenal fistula can occur months to years after surgery and presents with symptoms such as hematemesis or melena.

 

Option B. Colonic ischemia: This is a complication of open aortic aneurysm repair. Colonic ischemia can result from impaired blood flow to the colon during the surgical procedure.

 

Option D. Atelectasis: This is a complication of open aortic aneurysm repair. Atelectasis and lung consolidation can occur postoperatively.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Complications of open aortic aneurysm repair include aorto-duodenal fistula, colonic ischemia, atelectasis, cardiac ischemia, acute kidney injury, sexual dysfunction, spinal cord ischemia, and graft infection.
  •  Endoleak is a specific complication of EVAR, not open repair.

questions.text: 40-year-old man who recently returned from West Africa presents with recurrent episodes of painless swelling on his arms and legs that resolve spontaneously within a few days, only to reappear at a different location. On examination, transient swellings are noted, as shown in the image below. He also complains of occasional itching and redness in his eyes. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Loa loa

 

  • Loa loa causes loiasis, characterized by recurrent Calabar swellings (fugitive swellings) as the adult worm migrates through subcutaneous tissues. 
  • The disease is transmitted by the bite of Chrysops species (deerflies). Ocular manifestations, such as conjunctival migration of the worm, are also characteristic of Loa loa infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wuchereria bancrofti: Causes lymphatic filariasis and elephantiasis, with no transient subcutaneous swellings.

 

Option B. Onchocerca volvulus: Causes river blindness and subcutaneous nodules but does not produce Calabar swellings.

 

Option D. Brugia malayi: Causes lymphatic filariasis, similar to Wuchereria bancrofti, without migratory subcutaneous swellings.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Loa loa infection presents with transient Calabar swellings and conjunctival worm migration and is transmitted by deerflies.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of weakness, fatigue, and frequent bruising, especially on his legs and arms. He also reports that his gums bleed easily, and he’s been experiencing joint pain. Upon examination, the patient shows signs of petechiae, swollen gums, and poor wound healing. His dietary history reveals a lack of fresh fruits and vegetables. A blood test shows anemia. Which of the following nutrients is essential for the hydroxylation of proline and lysine, a critical step in collagen synthesis, and is likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ascorbic Acid 

 

  • Ascorbic acid is essential for the hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues during collagen synthesis, an important process for maintaining the structural integrity of connective tissues, blood vessels, skin, and bones. 
  • A deficiency in ascorbic acid leads to scurvy, characterized by bleeding gums, poor wound healing, joint pain, and bruising—consistent with the patient’s symptoms. 
  • Supplementation with vitamin C can help resolve these issues.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Biotin: Biotin acts as a coenzyme in carboxylation reactions, particularly in processes like gluconeogenesis and fatty acid synthesis. While important for these metabolic pathways, biotin is not involved in the hydroxylation of proline and lysine in collagen synthesis. Biotin deficiency may lead to symptoms like hair thinning, dermatitis, and neurological issues but is unrelated to the patient's presentation.

 

Option B. Thiamine: Thiamine (vitamin B1) is a coenzyme in several key metabolic reactions, including the actions of pyruvate dehydrogenase and α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complexes. It plays a significant role in carbohydrate metabolism and the TCA cycle. A deficiency in thiamine results in conditions such as beriberi or Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which present with neurological and cardiovascular symptoms rather than those related to collagen synthesis.

 

Option D. Pyridoxal Phosphate (Vitamin B6): Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) is the active form of vitamin B6 and functions as a coenzyme in various enzymatic reactions, including transamination, decarboxylation, and glycogenolysis. While important for amino acid metabolism, pyridoxal phosphate does not play a role in collagen synthesis or the hydroxylation of proline and lysine. Vitamin B6 deficiency is more commonly associated with neurological symptoms and anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is critical for the hydroxylation of proline and lysine in collagen synthesis. 
  • A deficiency results in scurvy, characterized by bleeding gums, petechiae, joint pain, and poor wound healing. 
  • These clinical features are a result of defective collagen formation.

Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Effector lymphocytes recirculate between blood and peripheral lymphoid organs after activation.


Reason (R): Effector lymphocytes function by producing cytokines or directly attacking infected cells at the site of infection.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A is false, but R is true.

 

  • Effector lymphocytes, once activated in peripheral lymphoid organs, do not recirculate between blood and lymphoid organs. 
  • Instead, they migrate to sites of infection or inflammation. 
  • This migration is guided by chemokines and adhesion molecules expressed at the site of infection. 
  • Effector T lymphocytes play a central role in immune defense by producing cytokines (e.g., IFN-γ, TNF-α) to recruit and activate other immune cells or directly killing infected cells via cytotoxic mechanisms.
  • The assertion (A) is incorrect because effector lymphocytes are programmed to leave the lymphoid tissues and home to the sites of infection, rather than continuing to recirculate through lymphoid organs. 
  • However, the reason (R) is correct, as effector lymphocytes indeed function at the infection site by producing cytokines or through cytotoxic activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Effector lymphocytes migrate to sites of infection or inflammation after activation, where they mediate immune responses by releasing cytokines or directly killing infected cells. 
  • They do not recirculate between blood and lymphoid organs after activation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with chronic, painless nodules on his right forearm and hand, as shown in the image below. The lesions have gradually enlarged over the past year and occasionally discharge yellowish granules. Histopathological examination reveals bacterial granulomas, as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Staphylococcus aureus

 

  • Staphylococcus aureus is the most common causative organism for botryomycosis, a rare chronic bacterial granulomatous infection that primarily involves the skin and occasionally the viscera. 
  • The condition gets its name from the Greek word 'Botrys,' meaning "bunch of grapes," due to the characteristic appearance of granules composed of bacterial cocci seen in discharge or histological specimens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Actinomyces israelii: Incorrect. Actinomyces israelii is responsible for actinomycosis, which involves lumpy jaw and sulfur granules but does not typically present with the skin findings seen in botryomycosis.

 

Option C. Nocardia brasiliensis: Incorrect. Nocardia brasiliensis is associated with mycetoma, which presents as chronic subcutaneous swelling, sinus formation, and discharge of granules but is not linked to botryomycosis.

 

Option D. Aspergillus fumigatus: Incorrect. Aspergillus fumigatus causes invasive aspergillosis or aspergillomas, primarily affecting immunocompromised hosts or pre-existing cavitary lesions in the lung.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Botryomycosis is a rare chronic bacterial granulomatous infection, most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus. 
  • It is characterized by painless skin nodules, yellowish granule discharge, and histological evidence of bacterial cocci. 
  • It must be differentiated from actinomycosis, mycetoma, and fungal infections through microbiological or histological examination.

questions.text: A community health researcher is studying the impact of occupational classification on social health outcomes in an urban population. He identifies significant limitations in using occupation as a measure of social class. Which of the following is not a commonly recognized limitation of occupational classification?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Educational attainment disparities

 

  • Educational attainment disparities are not a direct limitation of occupational classification as a measure of social class. 
  • The recognized limitations include gender biases (where the same occupation may be perceived differently for men and women), heterogeneous grouping (occupations grouped together may not always be related), and occupational mobility (occupational shifts over time can affect classification). 
  • Educational disparities influence social classification but are separate from occupational classification limitations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gender biases: A recognized limitation, where the perception of occupations may differ based on gender.

 

Option B. Heterogeneous grouping: A key limitation, as grouped occupations may not reflect uniformity in social status.

 

Option D. Occupational mobility: A valid limitation, as occupational shifts over time can alter classification and its relevance.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The limitations of occupational classification as a measure of social class include gender biases, heterogeneous grouping, and occupational mobility.

choices.text: Trabeculae of woven bone surrounded by fibrovascular stroma
Malignant osteoid production with atypical mitoses
Multinucleated giant cells surrounding hemorrhagic spaces
Fibrous tissue with scattered irregular bony trabeculae

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents with localized bone pain in the tibia. Imaging reveals a small radiolucent lesion surrounded by dense reactive sclerosis. The pain improves with NSAIDs. Which of the following is a histological feature of the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trabeculae of woven bone surrounded by fibrovascular stroma

 

  • Osteoid osteoma exhibits a characteristic histological pattern of trabeculae of woven bone surrounded by fibrovascular stroma within a nidus. 
  • This benign lesion is often associated with inflammatory changes in the surrounding cortical bone, leading to reactive sclerosis and pain due to prostaglandin production.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malignant osteoid production with atypical mitoses: This is a feature of osteosarcoma, a high-grade malignant bone tumor. Osteosarcomas show aggressive growth, cortical destruction, and periosteal reactions, which are not seen in osteoid osteoma.

 

Option C. Multinucleated giant cells surrounding hemorrhagic spaces: Seen in aneurysmal bone cysts, which are expansile lesions with fluid-filled spaces and lack the histological features of woven bone and fibrovascular stroma.

 

Option D. Fibrous tissue with scattered irregular bony trabeculae: This describes fibrous dysplasia, a non-neoplastic condition involving abnormal fibro-osseous tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteoid osteomas are histologically characterized by trabeculae of woven bone surrounded by fibrovascular stroma, and they are associated with reactive cortical changes.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman was prescribed a medication during the first trimester. She delivered a baby with craniofacial anomalies, including microtia, along with congenital heart disease and central nervous system abnormalities. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for these congenital defects?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Isotretinoin

 

  • Isotretinoin is a teratogenic drug commonly associated with congenital defects, particularly craniofacial anomalies (such as microtia and cleft palate), congenital heart disease, and CNS anomalies. 
  • It is absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy and requires stringent contraceptive measures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenytoin: Associated with fetal hydantoin syndrome, which includes facial dysmorphism, limb defects, and cardiac defects but not craniofacial anomalies seen with isotretinoin.

 

Option B. Valproate: Associated with neural tube defects like spina bifida, limb defects, and autism spectrum disorders but not craniofacial anomalies.

 

Option D. Warfarin: Known to cause fetal bleeding and hypoplastic nasal structures but does not result in the specific defects seen with isotretinoin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Isotretinoin is highly teratogenic and contraindicated during pregnancy due to its association with craniofacial, cardiac, and CNS anomalies. 
  • Stringent contraceptive measures must be implemented in women of childbearing age who are prescribed isotretinoin.

questions.text: A hospital administration committee is planning to implement a new protocol for emergency department triage. They wish to involve multiple experts to reach a consensus on the most effective approach. Which of the following methods is most likely to ensure an unbiased, collective agreement among the experts?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Delphi method using structured questionnaires over multiple rounds

 

  • The Delphi method is a systematic, interactive process that uses structured questionnaires to collect input from a group of experts. 
  • It involves multiple rounds, where feedback is aggregated and shared anonymously to reduce bias and encourage consensus. 
  • This is ideal for reaching an agreement on complex topics, such as emergency department triage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Focus group discussions with open-ended debates: Focus group discussions may lead to bias due to dominant voices or peer influence, and do not guarantee consensus.

 

Option C. Randomized controlled trials to validate the protocol: Randomized controlled trials are used to validate interventions but are not designed to achieve consensus.

 

Option D. Individual interviews with each expert to finalize the protocol: Individual interviews are useful for gathering opinions but do not facilitate a consensus-building process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Delphi method is an interactive forecasting tool used to achieve consensus among experts through multiple rounds of structured questionnaires.

choices.text: No duty owed to the patient

questions.text: A patient sues a hospital for malpractice after developing a serious infection post-surgery. The hospital provides evidence that the infection was caused by the patient’s noncompliance with postoperative wound care instructions, including failure to attend follow-up appointments and improper dressing changes. Which defense is most applicable in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Contributory negligence by the patient

 

  • The patient's failure to adhere to postoperative instructions constitutes contributory negligence. 
  • This defense shifts part of the responsibility to the patient for their role in the adverse outcome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Res judicata: Res judicata applies only when a case has been previously decided.

 

Option B. No duty owed to the patient: A doctor-patient relationship was clearly established, so this defense is not applicable.

 

Option D. Therapeutic misadventure: Therapeutic misadventure refers to unexpected complications arising during proper treatment, not patient noncompliance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Noncompliance with medical advice, such as postoperative instructions, can be used as contributory negligence, reducing the liability of healthcare providers in malpractice claims.

Grossly dilated esophagus with distal tapering
Large irregular mass in the lower esophagus

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man, Mr. Aman, presents to the emergency department with dysphagia lasting 3 hours. He experienced a catching sensation in his throat while eating steak, which worsened when he tried drinking beer. He now has difficulty swallowing saliva and a hoarse voice.

 

History:

 

  • Medical conditions: Seasonal allergic rhinitis, asthma, GERD.
  • Medications: Albuterol as needed, OTC omeprazole.
  • Social history: Consumes 5-6 beers daily; no tobacco or drug use.
  • Family history: Mother with atopic dermatitis.

 

Vital Signs:

 

  • Temperature: 37.5°C (99.5°F)
  • Blood pressure: 100/60 mmHg
  • Pulse: 92/min
  • Respirations: 14/min

 

Physical Examination:

 

  • Lethargic young man, drooling, and speaking in broken sentences.
  • No other abnormalities noted.

 

An emergency endoscopy is planned. In addition to a food bolus, what is the most likely endoscopic finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Multiple esophageal rings and furrows

 

  • The presentation is most consistent with eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE), a chronic immune-mediated esophageal disorder.

 

Key Features Supporting EoE:

 

  1. Risk Factors:
    • History of asthma, allergic rhinitis, GERD, and atopy (family history of atopic dermatitis).
  2. Symptoms:
    • Acute dysphagia and food impaction.
    • History of difficulty swallowing specific foods (steak is a common culprit).
  3. Endoscopic Findings in EoE:
    • Multiple esophageal rings (trachealization), furrows, white exudates, and sometimes strictures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abnormal peristaltic waves and a hiatal hernia: Suggestive of achalasia with GERD, but achalasia typically presents with progressive dysphagia for both solids and liquids, not acute food impaction.

 

Option B. Grossly dilated esophagus with distal tapering: Suggestive of advanced achalasia ("bird-beak" appearance), which is unlikely given the acute onset and absence of chronic progressive dysphagia.

 

Option C. Large irregular mass in the lower esophagus: Suggestive of esophageal carcinoma, which typically presents with chronic dysphagia, weight loss, and systemic symptoms, not an acute presentation in a young patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In young patients with a history of atopy, eosinophilic esophagitis should be suspected when they present with acute food impaction. Endoscopy typically reveals esophageal rings and furrows, supporting the diagnosis.

choices.text: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman, Mrs. Anita from Delhi, presents to the emergency department with fever and a skin rash. She was diagnosed with trigeminal neuralgia and started on carbamazepine 3 weeks ago.

 

Clinical Findings:

 

  • Temperature: 38.9°C (102°F)
  • Skin: Diffuse confluent erythema involving 60% of the body.
  • Lymphatic: Palpable generalized lymphadenopathy.
  • Face: Symmetrical facial swelling.
  • Mucosa: No lesions.

 

Laboratory Results:

 

  • Aspartate aminotransferase (AST): 150 U/L
  • Eosinophil count: 800/mm³
  • Serum creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)

 

  • The presentation is consistent with DRESS syndrome, a severe, drug-induced hypersensitivity reaction. It is characterized by:

 

  1. Timing:
    • Occurs 2–8 weeks after starting a new medication (e.g., carbamazepine, phenytoin, allopurinol).
  2. Symptoms:
    • Fever, skin rash (diffuse, confluent erythema), facial swelling, and generalized lymphadenopathy.
  3. Systemic involvement:
    • Elevated AST (liver involvement).
    • Eosinophilia (800/mm³ in this case).
    • Potential kidney involvement (though serum creatinine is normal here).

 

Management:

 

  • Discontinue the offending drug immediately.
  • Initiate systemic corticosteroids in severe cases.
  • Supportive care and monitoring for organ dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drug-induced hypersensitivity vasculitis: Typically limited to the skin, with palpable purpura as the primary lesion. Does not cause systemic symptoms like fever or eosinophilia.

 

Option C. Hypereosinophilic syndrome: Involves persistent eosinophilia (>1,500/mm³) and end-organ damage (e.g., heart, lungs, GI tract), which is not seen here.

 

Option D. Serum sickness-like syndrome: Presents with fever, rash, and polyarthritis, typically 1–2 weeks after exposure to drugs (e.g., antibiotics) or infections. It is not associated with eosinophilia or liver dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • DRESS syndrome should be suspected in patients with fever, rash, facial swelling, lymphadenopathy, eosinophilia, and systemic involvement within weeks of starting a high-risk medication. Prompt discontinuation of the drug is essential.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman employed in a garment factory is entitled to specific benefits under the ESI scheme. Which of the following correctly describes the maternity benefit provision?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Full wages for 26 weeks for pregnancy and childbirth, including a premature delivery

 

  • The maternity benefit under ESI provides full wage compensation for 26 weeks to ensure financial stability during pregnancy and childbirth. 
  • It also includes a 6-week period for miscarriage-related recovery or complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Full wages for 91 days after delivery: This is incorrect; 91 days refers to the sickness benefit period.

 

Option C. 80% of daily wages for 14 days post-tubectomy: Refers to enhanced sickness benefit for sterilization recovery, not maternity.

 

Option D. 90% of wages as a pension for the dependents of the insured person: Refers to dependence benefits in case of the insured person’s death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Maternity Benefit under ESI provides full wage compensation for 26 weeks, including pregnancy, childbirth, and miscarriage recovery.

questions.text: A research team has created a knocked-out mouse model in which the gene for cathepsin K, a proteolytic enzyme in osteoclasts, is inactivated. Which of the following changes is most likely observed in this model?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased hydroxyapatite levels in bone

 

  • Cathepsin K is essential for the breakdown of the organic matrix of bone, particularly collagen. 
  • Its absence impairs bone resorption, leading to the accumulation of hydroxyapatite.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decreased alkaline phosphatase activity in osteoblasts: Osteoblast activity remains unaffected as the gene is specific to osteoclasts.

 

Option C. Increased expression of RANKL in osteoblasts: RANKL expression is not directly linked to cathepsin K activity.

 

Option D. Enhanced formation of secondary ossification centers: This process is unrelated to cathepsin K or osteoclast function.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • The absence of cathepsin K in osteoclasts impairs bone resorption, leading to accumulation of hydroxyapatite.

choices.text: Increased renal reabsorption of glucose and sodium in the proximal convoluted tubule.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the renal physiology alteration caused by dapagliflozin?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased renal threshold for glucose reabsorption, causing glucosuria.

 

  • Dapagliflozin inhibits SGLT2 in the proximal convoluted tubule, reducing the renal threshold for glucose reabsorption and leading to increased glucose excretion in the urine (glucosuria).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased renal reabsorption of glucose and sodium in the proximal convoluted tubule: Incorrect. Dapagliflozin decreases glucose and sodium reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubule.

 

Option C. Increased glucose absorption in the loop of Henle, reducing serum glucose levels: Incorrect. The loop of Henle is not involved in glucose reabsorption.

 

Option D. Decreased sodium-glucose co-transport in the collecting duct: Incorrect. SGLT2 is located in the proximal convoluted tubule, not in the collecting duct.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Understand that dapagliflozin reduces the renal threshold for glucose reabsorption by inhibiting SGLT2, causing glucosuria and a mild diuretic effect.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man, Mr. Ravi from Delhi, presents to the emergency department with profuse hemoptysis, having coughed up nearly 6 ounces of blood. He reports a 3-day history of yellowish sputum production, mild dyspnea on exertion, and blood-streaked sputum that progressed to frank hemoptysis this morning. His medical history includes HIV treated with highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) and tuberculosis (TB) treated 12 years ago. He has a 50-pack-year smoking history and is a former IV drug user. He denies fever, chills, night sweats, or weight loss. On examination, he is anxious, in mild respiratory distress, with dried blood on his lips and diffuse wheezing on auscultation. During evaluation, he coughs up an additional 25 mL of blood. His oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. A CT chest scan is shown below. 

 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aspergilloma

 

  • The combination of significant hemoptysis, a history of treated TB, and CT findings of a fungal ball (aspergilloma) in a pre-existing lung cavity is diagnostic. 
  • Aspergillomas result from Aspergillus colonizing old cavities, typically from TB or other necrotizing infections. 
  • The air crescent sign is a hallmark imaging finding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bronchogenic carcinoma: Likely in smokers, but cavitary lesions in cancer are irregular with thick walls, and there is no fungal ball or air crescent sign.

 

Option C. Reactivation tuberculosis (TB): Reactivation usually presents with systemic symptoms (fever, night sweats, weight loss) and cavitary lesions without fungal balls.

 

Option D. Goodpasture’s syndrome: Presents with hemoptysis and glomerulonephritis (e.g., hematuria, renal dysfunction), absent here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aspergillomas commonly occur in old lung cavities and present with massive hemoptysis.
  • The air crescent sign on imaging is diagnostic. Immediate intervention is often required to manage life-threatening bleeding.

choices.text: Increases the sterilization efficiency of ethylene oxide
Reduces the flammable properties of ethylene oxide
Decreases the operational temperature of the sterilizer
Neutralizes residual ethylene oxide gas post-sterilization

questions.text: A healthcare facility employs ethylene oxide sterilization for medical equipment. Which of the following statements best describes the function of water vapor in this sterilization process?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increases the sterilization efficiency of ethylene oxide

 

  • Water vapor enhances the efficiency of ethylene oxide by aiding in the penetration of the gas into microbial structures, making it more effective against bacteria, spores, and viruses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reduces the flammable properties of ethylene oxide: Carbon dioxide, not water vapor, reduces flammability.

 

Option C. Decreases the operational temperature of the sterilizer: The operational temperature (50-60°C) is not altered by water vapor.

 

Option D. Neutralizes residual ethylene oxide gas post-sterilization: Neutralization of residual gas is achieved through aeration, not water vapor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Water vapor increases the efficiency of ethylene oxide sterilization by improving its antimicrobial action against a broad spectrum of microorganisms.

questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mobile mental health camps are a key strategy under the act to improve rural mental health care.

 

  • The Mental Healthcare Act of 2017 does not include provisions for mobile mental health camps. 
  • Instead, it focuses on reducing stigma, protecting patient rights, and enhancing institutional care and treatment protocols.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Provisions are made for individuals to receive treatment with confidentiality and without discrimination: Correct. The act ensures access to mental health care with confidentiality and non-discrimination.

 

Option B. Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is permitted only with the use of anesthesia: Correct. ECT is permitted only with anesthesia as per the act's provisions.

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Understand that the Mental Healthcare Act of 2017 does not include provisions for mobile mental health camps but emphasizes institutional care and patient rights.

choices.text: Increased dependence on LDL receptor activity for lipid clearance

questions.text: A clinical trial investigates the use of ANGPTL3 inhibitors in lipid metabolism. Which of the following outcomes would be most expected in patients treated with ANGPTL3 inhibitors?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased breakdown of very-low-density lipoproteins (VLDL)

 

  • Inhibition of ANGPTL3 by drugs like evinacumab increases LPL activity, promoting the hydrolysis and clearance of triglycerides and VLDL particles. 
  • This contributes to reduced LDL cholesterol levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased activity of lipoprotein lipase (LPL): ANGPTL3 inhibitors enhance, not decrease, LPL activity.

 

Option C. Reduced absorption of dietary cholesterol: This describes the action of ezetimibe, which blocks intestinal cholesterol absorption.

 

Option D. Increased dependence on LDL receptor activity for lipid clearance: ANGPTL3 inhibition is independent of LDL receptor function, making it effective in conditions like familial hypercholesterolemia.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • ANGPTL3 inhibitors enhance lipoprotein metabolism by increasing LPL activity, leading to the breakdown of triglycerides and VLDL particles.

choices.text: CT pulmonary angiography after pretreatment with glucocorticoids and antihistamines
CT pulmonary angiography using a high-osmolar radiocontrast material
CT pulmonary angiography without specific precautions

questions.text:
A 39-year-old woman, Ms. Kavita from Mumbai, presents to the emergency department with mild shortness of breath and right-sided pleuritic chest pain that began this morning. She underwent a mastectomy for left-sided breast cancer 2 weeks ago. Her medical history is notable for hives after eating seafood.

Vitals:

  • Blood pressure: 148/96 mmHg
  • Pulse: 114/min
  • Respirations: 21/min
  • Oxygen saturation: 91% on room air

Investigations:

  • Chest X-ray: Unremarkable
  • Urine pregnancy test: Negative
  • Creatinine: 0.8 mg/dL

What is the most appropriate diagnostic approach?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CT pulmonary angiography without specific precautions

 

  • This patient has a clinical presentation strongly suggestive of pulmonary embolism (PE) given her recent surgery, pleuritic chest pain, tachycardia, and mild hypoxemia. 
  • CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA) is the gold standard for diagnosing PE in a hemodynamically stable patient.
  • Although she has a history of hives with seafood, this does not directly correlate with iodine or contrast allergy. 
  • Routine precautions are not required unless there is a documented prior reaction to iodinated contrast.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Seafood allergy is unrelated to contrast media hypersensitivity.
  • Patients without a history of prior contrast reactions should undergo CTPA without pretreatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CTPA after pretreatment with glucocorticoids and antihistamines: Not required unless the patient has a prior history of an allergic reaction to contrast media.

 

Option B. CTPA using a high-osmolar radiocontrast material: High-osmolar agents are not preferred due to a higher risk of adverse reactions.

 

Option D. Lower extremity compression ultrasonography: Useful for diagnosing deep vein thrombosis (DVT) but is not a substitute for CTPA when evaluating suspected PE.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • In patients with suspected PE and no prior contrast reaction history, CT pulmonary angiography without specific precautions is the best diagnostic approach. 
  • Concerns about seafood allergy are not a contraindication to iodinated contrast use.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman in her third trimester presents with mild anemia. Her hemoglobin (Hb) level is 9.5 g/dL. According to national guidelines for prenatal screening, how often should Hb levels be checked during pregnancy, and what is the recommended management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hb levels should be checked at registration and every trimester; start oral iron therapy.

 

  • As per national guidelines, hemoglobin levels should be checked at registration and during each trimester. Anemia (Hb <11 g/dL) in pregnancy is commonly treated with oral iron therapy unless contraindicated or poorly tolerated, in which case intravenous iron is considered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hb levels should be checked only once during the first trimester; no further screening is required: Incorrect. Hb monitoring only once in pregnancy is insufficient for anemia detection and management.

 

Option C. Hb levels should be checked only in the second trimester; start intravenous iron therapy: Incorrect. Hb levels should be checked in all trimesters, and intravenous iron is reserved for moderate to severe anemia or intolerance to oral iron.

 

Option D. Hb levels should be checked every month during pregnancy; start folic acid supplementation only: Incorrect. While monthly checks may be done in specific cases, the usual protocol is to check Hb levels once per trimester. Folic acid alone is insufficient to correct anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hemoglobin levels should be monitored at registration and in every trimester to detect and treat anemia early. 
  • Oral iron therapy is the first-line treatment for mild to moderate anemia in pregnancy.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman, Ms. Kavita, presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset nausea and vomiting that started this morning. She has vomited about 10 times and noted blood in the vomitus.

 

History:

 

  • Medical conditions: Menorrhagia and bulimia.
  • Medications: Daily naproxen for chronic low back pain.
  • No history of dysphagia, odynophagia, tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drug use.

 

Vital Signs and Examination:

 

  • Blood pressure: 109/60 mmHg
  • Pulse: 106/min
  • Respirations: 14/min
  • Dry mucous membranes, soft and nontender abdomen, no hepatosplenomegaly.

 

Laboratory Results:

 

  • Hemoglobin: 10.0 g/dL (low)
  • MCV: 78 fL (microcytic anemia)
  • Platelets: 260,000/µL (normal)
  • INR: 1.3 (normal)
  • Stool occult blood: Negative

 

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD)

 

  • The patient’s presentation of hematemesis following multiple episodes of vomiting is strongly suggestive of a Mallory-Weiss tear, a mucosal laceration at the gastroesophageal junction caused by repetitive retching.

 

Key Features Supporting Diagnosis:

 

  1. Sudden onset of nausea, vomiting, and hematemesis.
  2. Risk factors:
    • Repeated retching due to bulimia.
    • Daily NSAID use (naproxen), which can exacerbate mucosal injury.
  3. Laboratory findings:
    • Microcytic anemia suggests chronic blood loss (e.g., menorrhagia).
    • Normal INR and platelets argue against coagulopathy or thrombocytopenia.

 

Why EGD is the next step:

 

  • EGD is the diagnostic and therapeutic modality of choice for upper GI bleeding.
  • It confirms the diagnosis and allows for therapeutic intervention if active bleeding is present (e.g., endoscopic hemostasis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Angiographic arterial embolization: Used for severe, life-threatening GI bleeding not controlled by endoscopy. Not the first-line step here.

 

Option B. Barium swallow: Not useful in evaluating acute upper GI bleeding or mucosal tears.

 

Option D. Fresh frozen plasma: Indicated for coagulopathy with bleeding (e.g., INR >1.5). This patient has a normal INR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with suspected Mallory-Weiss tear, esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) is the gold standard for diagnosis and management. 
  • Prompt evaluation and intervention can prevent further complications.

choices.text: History of rapid growth over several weeks

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with a mass in the upper arm measuring 2 cm. Imaging and Histology slide is shown below. Which of the following clinical or histological features would most strongly exclude a diagnosis of nodular fasciitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Infiltration into surrounding muscle and fat

 

  • Infiltration into surrounding muscle and fat is characteristic of desmoid tumors or other more aggressive fibroblastic proliferations, not nodular fasciitis. 
  • Nodular fasciitis is well-circumscribed and self-limited.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. History of rapid growth over several weeks: Typical of nodular fasciitis and does not exclude the diagnosis.

 

Option B. Cellular arrangement in short fascicles with abundant mitoses: Seen in nodular fasciitis, where mitoses are frequent but without atypia.

 

Option D. Positive immunohistochemical staining for vimentin and smooth muscle actin: Common in both nodular fasciitis and desmoid tumors, so it does not exclude nodular fasciitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nodular fasciitis is a self-limited lesion with no infiltration into surrounding tissues, distinguishing it from desmoid tumors and aggressive fibroblastic proliferations.

choices.text: Replication within the central nervous system

questions.text: A healthcare worker is accidentally exposed to HIV-infected blood. The worker reports the incident immediately, and post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is initiated. Which feature of HIV necessitates the use of a combination antiretroviral therapy (ART) in PEP?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rapid mutation during replication

 

  • HIV rapidly mutates due to the error-prone reverse transcriptase enzyme, leading to genetic variability and potential resistance to antiretroviral drugs. 
  • Combination ART targets different stages of the HIV life cycle, reducing the likelihood of resistance and ensuring effective viral suppression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Resistance to disinfectants like 10% bleach: HIV is inactivated by 10% bleach.

 

Option B. Replication within the central nervous system: While HIV crosses the blood-brain barrier, this is not the reason for combination ART in PEP.

 

Option D. Thermostability at room temperature: HIV is thermolabile, not thermostable, and this is irrelevant to ART selection.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • The rapid mutation of HIV during replication necessitates the use of combination antiretroviral therapy to prevent drug resistance.

choices.text: Use of a shorter inter-electrode distance.
Reduction in the number of voltage-gated sodium channels.

questions.text: Which of the following changes would increase the conduction velocity observed in a biphasic action potential recording?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increase in axon diameter.

 

  • Conduction velocity is directly proportional to the axonal diameter due to reduced resistance to ionic flow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease in extracellular sodium concentration: It would decrease conduction velocity as sodium ions are essential for depolarization.

 

Option C. Use of a shorter inter-electrode distance: It would alter the recorded potential but not the intrinsic conduction velocity.

 

Option D. Reduction in the number of voltage-gated sodium channels: It would reduce sodium influx, slowing depolarization and conduction velocity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Larger axon diameters enhance conduction velocity by decreasing resistance to ionic flow.

questions.text: Calculate the GCS-P score of a patient brought into the ER with history of fall from a motorcycle. He is just making incomprehensible sounds, has a completely flexed posture and only opens his eyes to knuckle pressure. On examination, right pupil is unreactive to light:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6

 

To calculate the GCS-P (Glasgow Coma Scale-Pupils) score for the patient, we will assess the eye, verbal, and motor responses, and then adjust for pupil reactivity.

 

  1. Eye response: The patient opens eyes to knuckle pressure (pain), which scores a 2.
  2. Verbal response: The patient is making incomprehensible sounds, which scores a 2.
  3. Motor response: The patient has a completely flexed posture, which is consistent with decorticate posturing, which scores a 3.

 

Adding these together:

 

Eye Response + Verbal Response + Motor Response=2+2+3=7

 

Now, for the pupillary response:

 

One pupil is unreactive to light, which subtracts 1 from the GCS score.

 

GCS Score−Pupillary Score=7−1=6

 

The final GCS-P score is 6.

 

The correct answer is B. 6.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The Glasgow Coma Scale-Pupils (GCS-P) is an extension of the GCS that includes the assessment of pupillary light response. 
  • It is used to evaluate the severity of brain injuries. 
  • The GCS-P score is derived by subtracting the pupillary score from the GCS score, providing a more comprehensive assessment of the patient's neurological status.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man, Mr. Raj from Pune, presents with a 6-month history of intermittent palpitations. He describes the episodes as sudden-onset fluttering in the chest, lasting 30-40 minutes, and resolving spontaneously or after deep breathing maneuvers. The palpitations occur approximately once a month and are not associated with physical activity, chest pain, dizziness, dyspnea, or syncope.

 

Examination Findings:

 

  • Jugular venous pressure: 4 cm H₂O
  • No cardiac murmurs or additional heart sounds
  • Peripheral pulses: 2+ and symmetrical bilaterally

 

Investigations:

 

ECG is shown below. 

 

 

What is the most likely finding on ECG during an episode of palpitations?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Regular narrow QRS complex tachycardia

 

  • The clinical presentation is consistent with paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT), likely due to atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT).

 

Key features supporting this diagnosis:

 

  • Sudden onset and termination of palpitations: Typical of PSVT.
  • Resolution with vagal maneuvers: Suggests reentrant tachycardia involving the AV node.
  • ECG findings:
    • Short PR interval (100 msec) and wide QRS complex (140 msec) at baseline may indicate preexcitation syndrome (e.g., Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome).

 

During an episode of AVNRT:

 

  • The tachycardia is regular with a narrow QRS complex, as conduction occurs through the normal His-Purkinje system.
  • Heart rates are typically 150-250 beats per minute.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Irregular narrow QRS complex tachycardia: Seen in atrial fibrillation, which is characterized by an irregularly irregular rhythm and does not match this presentation.

 

Option B. Irregular wide QRS complex tachycardia: Seen in atrial fibrillation with aberrant conduction or preexisting bundle branch block, which is not described here.

 

Option C. Junctional escape beats: Junctional escape beats occur when the sinus node fails to generate impulses, usually causing bradycardia. This does not align with the patient's tachycardia symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:


In a young patient with intermittent palpitations and ECG findings suggestive of preexcitation, the most likely arrhythmia during episodes is regular narrow QRS complex tachycardia, typical of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT).

choices.text: P-selectins mediate leukocyte recruitment, while inflammasomes promote cytokine activation.

questions.text: Which of the following best differentiates the role of P-selectins from inflammasomes in the inflammatory response?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) P-selectins mediate leukocyte recruitment, while inflammasomes promote cytokine activation.

 

  • P-selectins facilitate the initial recruitment of leukocytes to sites of inflammation by interacting with glycoproteins on leukocyte surfaces.
  • Inflammasomes, on the other hand, activate cytokines such as IL-1 and induce pyroptosis in infected or necrotic cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. P-selectins recognize DAMPs, while inflammasomes recognize PAMPs: Incorrect; P-selectins do not recognize molecular patterns.

 

Option C. P-selectins generate IL-1, while inflammasomes activate TNF-α: Incorrect roles for both.

 

Option D. P-selectins promote pyroptosis, while inflammasomes promote apoptosis: Incorrect processes for both molecules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • P-selectins mediate leukocyte recruitment, while inflammasomes are responsible for cytokine activation and pyroptosis.

choices.text: Direct bacterial invasion of adrenal cortical cells

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with fever, widespread purpura, and hypotension. Despite aggressive treatment, she dies shortly after admission. An adrenal biopsy is obtained postmortem and reveals the following findings. Which of the following mechanisms is primarily responsible for the observed histological changes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endotoxin-mediated endothelial damage

 

  • The pathogenesis of Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome involves endotoxin-mediated endothelial damage, leading to microvascular injury, hemorrhage, and necrosis of the adrenal glands. 

 

 

The histology shows extensive hemorrhage with cortical necrosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Direct bacterial invasion of adrenal cortical cells: Rarely occurs; bacterial products like endotoxins mediate the damage.

 

Option C. Autoimmune destruction of adrenal tissue: This is the mechanism in autoimmune adrenalitis, not relevant here.

 

Option D. Ischemic necrosis due to thrombosis: While DIC is present, the primary injury is endothelial damage caused by microbial toxins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome results from endotoxin-mediated endothelial damage, leading to adrenal hemorrhage and acute adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: Grade the following finding in a patient with varicose veins, with limb swelling and feeling of limb thickening on palpation, according to the CEAP classification.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) C4b

 

  • The image and clinical finding (limb thickening) shows lipodermatosclerosis with inverted champagne bottle leg, which is C4b of the CEAP classification.

 

For clinical classification:

  • C0: no signs of venous disease.
  • C1: telangiectasia or reticular veins;
  • C2: varicose veins;
  • C3: oedema;
  • C4a: pigmentation or eczema.
  • C4b: Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche.
  • C4c Corona phlebectatica
  • C5: healed venous ulcer.
  • C6: active venous ulcer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C2: This classification corresponds to varicose veins without significant associated complications. The presence of lipodermatosclerosis rules out this grade.

 

Option B. C3: This classification is limited to oedema without skin changes. The described findings go beyond mere oedema, making C3 incorrect.

 

Option C. C4a: C4a includes pigmentation or eczema, which are early skin changes in chronic venous disease. However, the described thickening and lipodermatosclerosis are indicative of more advanced changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lipodermatosclerosis with an inverted champagne bottle appearance is classified as C4b in the CEAP system, reflecting advanced skin and subcutaneous changes in chronic venous disease.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male presents with hypertension and decreased renal function. Laboratory analysis reveals the following:

 

  • GFR = 60 mL/min
  • Renal plasma flow (RPF) = 240 mL/min

 

What is the filtration fraction (FF), and what does it indicate about this patient's renal function?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) FF = 0.25; indicates compensatory hyperfiltration

 

Explanation:

 

Filtration fraction (FF) = GFR/RPF = 60/240 = 0.25 (25%). 

 

In a healthy individual, FF is ~20%. 

 

A filtration fraction of 0.25 suggests compensatory hyperfiltration, a mechanism in which the remaining functional nephrons increase filtration to compensate for nephron loss or reduced filtration capacity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The filtration fraction (FF) is the ratio of GFR to RPF and reflects the efficiency of filtration by the glomeruli. An FF > 0.20 suggests compensatory hyperfiltration, commonly seen in early stages of nephron loss or reduced renal function. Understanding FF helps evaluate renal function and its compensatory mechanisms in diseases such as hypertension or chronic kidney disease.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with worsening dyspnea, increased sputum production, and fever. Sputum culture reveals a DNAse-positive, Gram-negative diplococcus that does not ferment carbohydrates and gives a positive tributyrin hydrolysis test. Which of the following pathogens is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Moraxella catarrhalis

 

  • Moraxella catarrhalis is a DNAse-positive, Gram-negative diplococcus. It is a common cause of COPD exacerbations and is distinguished from Neisseria species by its asaccharolytic nature, positive tributyrin hydrolysis test, and positive DNAse test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neisseria meningitidis: A Gram-negative diplococcus but ferments carbohydrates, unlike Moraxella catarrhalis.

 

Option C. Haemophilus influenzae: A small, pleomorphic Gram-negative coccobacillus, not a diplococcus.

 

Option D. Streptococcus pneumoniae: A Gram-positive diplococcus, not Gram-negative.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Moraxella catarrhalis is a common cause of COPD exacerbations. 
  • It is a DNAse-positive, asaccharolytic, Gram-negative diplococcus.

questions.text: In the box plot comparing hospital stays for diabetic and non-diabetic patients, what is the most likely explanation for the presence of numerous outliers in the non-diabetic group?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-diabetic patients experience more variability in hospitalization reasons.

 

  • The presence of multiple outliers in the non-diabetic group suggests that this population has more heterogeneous reasons for hospitalization, leading to a wider range of lengths of stay. 
  • This could be due to factors unrelated to diabetes, such as trauma or acute conditions, which can result in prolonged stays.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Non-diabetic patients have more comorbidities leading to prolonged stays: The presence of comorbidities may contribute to variability, but it is not necessarily higher in non-diabetic patients.

 

Option B. The study included a smaller sample size for the non-diabetic group: Sample size cannot be inferred directly from the box plot.

 

Option C. Outliers in the non-diabetic group reflect errors in data collection: Outliers are not necessarily indicative of errors but may represent genuine variability in the data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Outliers in box plots often indicate variability in a population and can highlight differences in underlying reasons for an observed outcome.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male farmer presents to the emergency department after suspected exposure to a pesticide. He reports applying a pesticide to his crops 4 days earlier. Since 2 days he started feeling agitated and nervous, followed by tremors which increased gradually. Today he also had a seizure and is bit confused. He has no signs of excessive salivation, diarrhea, or bradycardia. His vital signs (heart rate, blood pressure, respiratory rate) are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Organochlorine poisoning

 

  • This patient's presentation, including agitation, tremors, seizures, and confusion following exposure to a pesticide, suggests a possible neurotoxic effect. 
  • Organochlorines (such as DDT and lindane) affect the nervous system by altering ion transport across cell membranes, leading to increased neuronal excitability. 
  • The patient's symptoms of agitation, tremors, confusion, and seizures following pesticide exposure, without the hallmark cholinergic signs, are more consistent with organochlorine toxicity. 
  • The gradual onset of symptoms over several days also fits the known toxicity profile of organochlorines.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Organophosphate poisoning:

 

  • Common symptoms include cholinergic effects such as excessive salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation, gastrointestinal distress, and bradycardia.
  • However, this patient does not exhibit excessive salivation, diarrhea, or bradycardia, which would be typical signs of organophosphate poisoning. While he has some neurological symptoms (agitation, tremors, seizure, confusion), the lack of the characteristic cholinergic effects makes this less likely.

 

Option C. Carbon monoxide poisoning:

 

  • Carbon monoxide poisoning typically presents with symptoms like headache, dizziness, confusion, nausea, and sometimes seizures.
  • The hallmark of carbon monoxide poisoning is hypoxia due to the binding of CO to hemoglobin, forming carboxyhemoglobin, which reduces oxygen delivery to tissues.
  • This patient's normal vital signs (especially normal respiratory rate) and absence of signs of hypoxia (like cyanosis or low oxygen saturation) make carbon monoxide poisoning less likely.

 

Option D. Carbamate poisoning:

 

  • Like organophosphate poisoning, carbamate poisoning leads to the accumulation of acetylcholine, but carbamates tend to have a shorter duration of action and are generally less toxic than organophosphates.
  • This patient's lack of classic cholinergic symptoms (e.g., salivation, diarrhea) makes carbamate poisoning less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Organochlorine poisoning should be suspected in patients with neurotoxic symptoms such as agitation, tremors, seizures, and confusion following pesticide exposure.
  • The absence of cholinergic signs helps distinguish organochlorine toxicity from organophosphate or carbamate poisoning.
  • The gradual onset of symptoms is also characteristic of organochlorines.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with progressive palmoplantar pigmentation. X-ray of the spine shows calcification of intervertebral discs. Urine analysis reveals a greenish-brown precipitate and blue-black supernatant fluid after adding Benedict's reagent. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alkaptonuria

 

  • Alkaptonuria is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme homogentisate oxidase, which leads to the accumulation of homogentisic acid. 
  • This compound oxidizes upon exposure to air, imparting a black color to urine. Key features include:
  • Pigmentation: Progressive deposition of homogentisic acid in connective tissues causes ochronosis (bluish-black pigmentation), often seen on the palms and soles.
  • Spinal Calcification: Calcification of intervertebral discs is common, visible on X-rays as narrowing and calcified spaces, contributing to joint pain resembling arthritis.
  • Urine Findings: Urine darkens on standing or upon the addition of reagents like Benedict's due to oxidation of homogentisic acid.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenylketonuria: This condition is caused by a deficiency in phenylalanine hydroxylase, leading to elevated levels of phenylalanine. Symptoms include developmental delays, a musty odor, and fair skin but do not involve pigment changes or intervertebral disc calcification.

 

Option C. Tyrosinemia type-2: This disorder is characterized by elevated tyrosine levels due to a deficiency in tyrosine aminotransferase. It primarily presents with corneal ulcers, photophobia, and hyperkeratotic lesions on the palms and soles. The findings of calcified discs and dark urine are absent.

 

Option D. Argininosuccinic aciduria: This urea cycle disorder is due to a deficiency in argininosuccinate lyase. Clinical features include hyperammonemia, vomiting, lethargy, and failure to thrive. Pigmentation changes or calcification of intervertebral discs are not characteristic features.

 

Educational Objective:


Alkaptonuria is a metabolic disorder characterized by homogentisic acid buildup, leading to ochronosis, darkened urine, and calcified intervertebral discs. Diagnosis is supported by urine discoloration with reagents and X-ray findings of spinal calcifications.

When the CD4 count exceeds 350 cells/mm³, and the child has been on ART for at least 6 months.

questions.text: A 7-year-old HIV-positive child with a CD4 count of 320 cells/mm³ and WHO stage 3 clinical status has been initiated on cotrimoxazole prophylaxis. When should prophylaxis be discontinued in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) When the CD4 count exceeds 350 cells/mm³, and the child has been on ART for at least 6 months.

 

  • For children older than 5 years, discontinuation of cotrimoxazole prophylaxis is recommended when their CD4 count exceeds 350 cells/mm³ and they have been stable on ART for at least 6 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. When the child reaches 10 years of age, irrespective of ART adherence: Age is not the sole criterion; CD4 count and ART duration are more critical.

 

Option C. Cotrimoxazole prophylaxis should continue indefinitely for all HIV-positive children: Discontinuation is possible under specific conditions, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Discontinuation should occur only when the child demonstrates undetectable viral loads for over 12 months: Viral load monitoring is essential but not the only criterion for discontinuation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cotrimoxazole prophylaxis in HIV-positive children older than 5 years can be discontinued when the CD4 count is >350 cells/mm³, and ART has been effective for at least 6 months.

choices.text: Failure of sexual development in females at puberty

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of 17-hydroxylase deficiency?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Failure of sexual development in females at puberty

 

  • 17-hydroxylase deficiency leads to a deficiency in cortisol and sex hormones, resulting in:
    • Failure of sexual development in females during puberty.
    • Incomplete virilization or ambiguous genitalia in males (46XY).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased cortisol and aldosterone levels: This is incorrect as cortisol levels are decreased due to the enzyme deficiency, but aldosterone levels are elevated.

 

Option B. Salt wasting and hyperkalemia: Salt retention and hypertension occur due to the increased aldosterone levels, not salt wasting or hyperkalemia.

 

Option D. Increased virilization in males (46XY): Males with this condition are incompletely virilized due to a deficiency in sex hormone synthesis, leading to ambiguous genitalia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • 17-hydroxylase deficiency is characterized by a lack of cortisol and sex hormones, leading to features like salt retention, hypertension, failure of sexual development in females, and incomplete virilization in males. 
  • Elevated aldosterone levels contribute to salt retention and hypertension.

questions.text: At what age is the Measles/MR (2nd dose) vaccine administered in the immunization schedule?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 16-24 months

 

  • The Measles/MR (2nd dose) vaccine is administered at 16-24 months of age as per the immunization schedule. It is given subcutaneously in the right upper arm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 9 months: This is the age for the 1st dose of the Measles/MR vaccine, not the 2nd dose.

 

Option C. 5-6 years: This is the age for other vaccines like DPT booster 2, not MR 2nd dose.

 

Option D. 10 years: This is the age for the Td vaccine, not for the MR 2nd dose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The 2nd dose of Measles/MR vaccine is administered between 16-24 months of age, ensuring effective immunity against measles and rubella. It is delivered subcutaneously in the right upper arm.

choices.text: Subgroup analysis to exclude smaller studies
Sensitivity analysis to explore the impact of excluding studies
The use of the Egger’s regression test to quantify publication bias
Meta-regression to pool only high-powered studies

questions.text: What would be the most appropriate statistical approach to adjust for the bias in a meta-analysis, as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The use of the Egger’s regression test to quantify publication bias

 

  • Egger’s regression test is a statistical method used to detect funnel plot asymmetry and quantify the degree of publication bias in a meta-analysis. 
  • It examines whether the funnel plot asymmetry is statistically significant. 
  • This approach is particularly useful when subjective interpretation of the plot may lead to erroneous conclusions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subgroup analysis to exclude smaller studies: Subgroup analysis does not directly address publication bias and may result in losing important information.

 

Option B. Sensitivity analysis to explore the impact of excluding studies: Sensitivity analysis explores the robustness of results but does not specifically address publication bias.

 

Option D. Meta-regression to pool only high-powered studies: Meta-regression does not correct for publication bias but is used to explore sources of heterogeneity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Quantify publication bias in meta-analyses using statistical tools like Egger’s regression test when funnel plot asymmetry is detected.

choices.text: The base of the appendix is found at the confluence of the three taeniae coli of the caecum.
The appendicular artery is an end artery
Neuroendocrine tumors of the appendix arise from the mucosal cells present at the base of the crypts
Appendix lies in the left abdomen in malrotated gut

questions.text: Which of these is the incorrect statement concerning the anatomy of the appendix?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neuroendocrine tumors of the appendix arise from the mucosal cells present at the base of the crypts 

 

  • Neuro endocrine tumours (NETS’s) arise from the argentaffin cells (Kulchitsky) at the base of the crypts, not mucosal cells. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The base of the appendix is found at the confluence of the three taeniae coli of the caecum: The position of the base of the appendix is constant, being found at the confluence of the three taeniae coli of the caecum, which fuse to form the outer longitudinal muscle coat of the appendix. 

 

Option B. The appendicular artery is an end artery: Appendicular artery is an ‘end-artery’, thrombosis of which results in necrosis of the appendix. 

 

Option D. Appendix lies in the left abdomen in malrotated gut: Appendix lies in the left abdomen in mal-rotated gut

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Neuro endocrine tumours (NETS’s) arise from the argentaffin cells (Kulchitsky cells) and not the mucosal cells which are situated at the base of the crypts.

Reactivation of a latent opportunistic pathogen

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of chronic bronchiectasis presents with worsening headache, fever, and new-onset right-sided weakness. MRI reveals a single ring-enhancing lesion in the left frontal lobe. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hematogenous spread from pulmonary infection

 

  • Patients with chronic pulmonary diseases, such as bronchiectasis, are at increased risk for hematogenous spread of infections to the brain, leading to abscess formation. 
  • The lungs act as a primary reservoir for bacteria that may seed distant sites like the brain through the bloodstream.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Local extension from paranasal sinusitis: Typically causes brain abscesses in adjacent regions, such as the frontal lobe, but is unrelated to chronic pulmonary disease.

 

Option C. Direct implantation of organisms due to trauma: Requires a history of head trauma or neurosurgical procedures, which is absent here.

 

Option D. Reactivation of a latent opportunistic pathogen: This occurs in immunosuppressed patients (e.g., HIV/AIDS) and is not typical of bacterial brain abscesses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hematogenous spread from pulmonary infections, such as bronchiectasis, is a common mechanism for brain abscess development.
