questions.text: A 28-year-old construction worker presented to the emergency department after sustaining a stab wound to the neck during an altercation at his workplace. The knife entrance wound was located on the right side of the neck just lateral to the tip of the greater cornu of the hyoid bone. During the physical examination the patient was asked to protrude his tongue, which deviated to the right. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the physical signs in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Genioglossus originates from the lower genial tubercles of the mandible

 

  • This statement is incorrect. The genioglossus muscle originates from the superior genial tubercles (also called mental spines), located on the posterior aspect of the symphysis menti of the mandible. 
  • The inferior genial tubercles are the site of origin for the geniohyoid muscle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paralysis of the right genioglossus muscle permitted the left genioglossus to pull the tongue forward and turned the tip to the right side: This statement is correct. The genioglossus muscle on each side is responsible for pulling the tongue forward. Paralysis of the right genioglossus results in unopposed action of the left genioglossus, causing the tongue to deviate toward the paralyzed (right) side.

 

Option C. The hypoglossal nerve descends in the neck between the internal carotid artery and the internal jugular vein: This statement is correct. The hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII) descends in this anatomical plane before turning anteriorly near the greater cornu of the hyoid bone.

 

Option D. At about the level of the tip of the greater cornu of the hyoid bone, the hypoglossal nerve turns forward and crosses the internal and external carotid arteries and the lingual artery to enter the tongue: This statement is correct. The hypoglossal nerve takes this path to supply motor innervation to most of the tongue muscles (except the palatoglossus, supplied by the vagus nerve).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The hypoglossal nerve is the primary motor nerve of the tongue, and injury to it results in deviation of the tongue toward the side of the lesion due to unopposed action of the contralateral genioglossus muscle. 
  • The genioglossus muscle originates from the superior genial tubercles of the mandible and functions as the "safety muscle" by preventing the tongue from obstructing the airway.

questions.text: A 29-year-old female presents with recurrent episodes of excessive eating followed by feelings of guilt and self-induced vomiting for the past year. Her BMI is 22 kg/m², and she reports using laxatives frequently. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bulimia nervosa

 

  • Bulimia nervosa is characterized by recurrent episodes of binge eating followed by compensatory behaviors such as self-induced vomiting or laxative abuse. 
  • Normal BMI distinguishes it from anorexia nervosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anorexia nervosa: Involves significantly low body weight and restrictive behaviors, not evident here.

 

Option C. Binge-eating disorder: Includes binge eating without compensatory behaviors.

 

Option D. Body dysmorphic disorder: Involves preoccupation with perceived physical flaws, not binge eating or purging.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Bulimia Nervosa is characterized by recurrent episodes of binge eating followed by inappropriate compensatory behaviors such as self-induced vomiting, misuse of laxatives, fasting, or excessive exercise. 
  • Patients with Bulimia Nervosa often have a normal or above-normal body weight, and physical signs can include dental erosions and calluses on the knuckles from inducing vomiting.

questions.text: During a colonoscopy, which finding is associated with the highest potential for malignancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Multiple sessile polyps

 

  • Sessile polyps, especially multiple ones, carry the highest risk of malignant transformation compared to other types of polyps. Sessile polyps are flat, broad-based lesions that are more difficult to resect completely, increasing the likelihood of residual dysplasia. The risk of malignancy increases significantly with size (e.g., polyps >1 cm or >3 cm in size) and the presence of dysplasia.
  • Multiple sessile polyps also increase the cumulative risk of malignancy. Guidelines recommend follow-up colonoscopy for individuals with multiple premalignant polyps, especially if they include advanced adenomas (≥10 mm in size, high-grade dysplasia, or serrated polyps with dysplasia).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Single sessile polyp: While a single sessile polyp has malignant potential, it poses less risk than multiple sessile polyps. The malignant potential of sessile polyps is size-dependent, and solitary polyps without high-risk features (e.g., size <1 cm) may have a relatively lower risk.

 

Option B. Single pedunculated polyp: Pedunculated polyps are less likely to undergo malignant transformation compared to sessile polyps because their morphology makes complete removal easier. Additionally, pedunculated polyps often lack features associated with high-grade dysplasia.

 

Option D. Multiple pedunculated polyps: Multiple pedunculated polyps have a higher risk compared to a single polyp but remain less concerning than sessile polyps. The ease of removal and lower association with high-grade dysplasia contribute to their relatively lower risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Multiple sessile polyps have the highest potential for malignant transformation among colonic polyps, particularly as their size and number increase. 
  • Surveillance and follow-up colonoscopies are essential for managing patients with multiple or advanced adenomas.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones does not play a role in fetal growth but has a significant role in the postnatal period?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Growth hormone

 

  • Growth hormone does not contribute to fetal growth, even though it is present in high levels during the fetal period. 
  • Its significant role begins in the postnatal period, where it promotes growth and development after birth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insulin: Plays a critical role in fetal growth and development, especially in the late gestational period.

 

Option B. Thyroxine: Necessary for normal growth and development of the fetus during gestation.

 

Option C. Glucocorticoids: Crucial for prepartum maturation of various organs such as the liver, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Growth hormone is not involved in fetal growth but is essential in postnatal growth. In contrast, insulin, thyroxine, and glucocorticoids play critical roles in fetal growth and organ maturation during gestation.

questions.text: On examination on a patient of suspected Peripheral Arterial Disease, the doctor was seen to be performing the test shown in the given image below. Which artery is he likely trying to palpate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior tibial

 

 

Particularly in the lower limbs

 

  • The posterior tibial artery is palpated just posterior to the medial malleolus.
  • In the provided image, the clinician is palpating this specific location, which is consistent with the posterior tibial pulse. Assessment of this pulse is crucial in the evaluation of peripheral arterial disease (PAD), particularly in the lower limbs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior tibial: The anterior tibial artery becomes the dorsalis pedis artery at the ankle and is palpated on the dorsum of the foot between medial and lateral malleoli

 

Option C. Dorsalis pedis: The dorsalis pedis artery lies on the dorsum of the foot lateral to the extensor hallucis longus tendon. It is assessed on the top of the foot, unlike the posterior tibial artery, which is behind the medial malleolus.

 

Option D. Popliteal: The popliteal artery is located behind the knee and is palpated with the knee slightly flexed. This is not the area depicted in the image, ruling it out as the answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior tibial artery, palpated behind the medial malleolus, is a critical site for assessing peripheral arterial disease, particularly in patients with risk factors like diabetes or smoking.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with progressive dyspnea, fatigue, and lower extremity edema. An echocardiogram reveals global hypokinesis and a dilated left ventricle with a reduced ejection fraction of 25%. A myocardial biopsy reveals the histopathology image given below. Which of the following genetic abnormalities is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mutation in the TTN gene

 

  • The TTN gene, which encodes titin, is commonly mutated in dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM). 
  • Truncating mutations lead to a shortened protein, impairing sarcomeric function. 
  • Histologically, myocytes with bizarre, "ninja-star"-like nuclei are characteristic of DCM.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mutation in the FBN1 gene: Associated with Marfan syndrome, leading to aortic aneurysms, not DCM.

 

Option C. Mutation in the LMNA gene: Linked to familial DCM with conduction system abnormalities but less common than TTN mutations.

 

Option D. Mutation in the MYH7 gene: Associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy rather than DCM.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mutations in the TTN gene are the most common genetic cause of dilated cardiomyopathy and are associated with histological findings like bizarre nuclei in myocytes.

questions.text: A severely charred body is found at the site of a house fire. Which of the following is the primary cause of this characteristic posture, as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Protein Coagulation

 

  • The pugilistic attitude, also referred to as the boxer’s posture, is a classic postural change observed in burned bodies. 
  • This posture results from heat stiffening caused by the coagulation of muscle proteins when exposed to temperatures above 65°C. 
  • The heat induces intense contraction of the muscles, leading to shortening of muscle fibers and the characteristic flexion of elbows and knees, along with clenching of fists.

 

Key features of pugilistic attitude:

 

  1. Cause: It occurs due to heat stiffening, not rigor mortis or any metabolic process like lipolysis or lipogenesis.
  2. Intensity: The heat stiffening is more intense than rigor mortis and cannot be reversed by stretching the limbs.
  3. Occurrence: It can occur in both antemortem and postmortem burns.
  4. Exclusion of rigor mortis: If heat stiffening occurs, rigor mortis does not develop in the affected muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lipolysis: Incorrect. Lipolysis is the breakdown of lipids into glycerol and fatty acids, unrelated to heat-induced stiffening of muscles.

 

Option C. Carbohydrate Coagulation: Incorrect. Carbohydrate metabolism does not play a role in the development of the pugilistic posture.

 

Option D. Lipogenesis: Incorrect. Lipogenesis refers to the synthesis of lipids and is not associated with muscle protein contraction or heat stiffening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The pugilistic attitude, a hallmark of heat stiffening, is caused by protein coagulation due to high-temperature exposure (>65°C). 
  • It results in intense contraction of muscles, leading to a characteristic flexed posture. 
  • This phenomenon distinguishes heat stiffening from rigor mortis and can occur in both antemortem and postmortem burns.

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant woman in her second trimester visits the clinic for a routine checkup. She asks about the physiological changes occurring in her urinary system during pregnancy. Which of the following changes does not occur in the urinary system during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased activity of ureters

 

  • During pregnancy, progesterone causes relaxation of smooth muscles, including the ureters. 
  • This leads to reduced ureteral peristalsis and decreased ureteral activity, contributing to hydronephrosis and hydroureter, which are more pronounced on the right side due to uterine dextrorotation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased GFR: The glomerular filtration rate (GFR) increases by approximately 50% during pregnancy to accommodate the increased metabolic and excretory demands of the mother and fetus.

 

Option B. Increased RBF: Renal blood flow (RBF) increases during pregnancy, driven by vasodilation and hormonal changes, which support the elevated GFR.

 

Option C. Hypertrophy of bladder musculature: The bladder musculature undergoes hypertrophy and congestion to adapt to the increased intra-abdominal pressure and changes in urinary storage capacity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In pregnancy, progesterone relaxes smooth muscles, leading to reduced ureteral activity, which can result in hydroureter and hydronephrosis. 
  • Other urinary changes include increased GFR, RBF, and bladder muscle hypertrophy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes in with several painful leg swellings. He has a number of distinct, hard, bony lumps and obvious vascular abnormalities during physical examination. His hands and forearm bones had several enchondromas, according to radiographs. According to his medical history, he has experienced comparable lumps since he was a young child. Which diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mafucci’s Syndrome

 

  • Mafucci’s syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the presence of multiple enchondromas (benign cartilage tumors) and vascular malformations (often seen as abnormal blood vessels, such as hemangiomas).
  • Key features of Mafucci's syndrome:
    • Multiple enchondromas: These are benign tumors that typically affect the bones, especially the hands, forearms, and legs, just as seen in this patient.
    • Vascular malformations: These include hemangiomas and other blood vessel abnormalities that can appear as blue or purple nodules on the skin, matching the "obvious vascular abnormalities" described in the case.
    • The patient’s history of similar lumps since childhood, along with the combination of bony and vascular findings, fits well with Mafucci’s syndrome.
    • There is also an increased risk of malignant transformation of the enchondromas into chondrosarcomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple Hereditary Exostosis (MHE):

 

  • Multiple Hereditary Exostosis (MHE) is a condition characterized by the development of multiple osteochondromas, which are benign bony outgrowths covered by cartilage. These often affect the long bones (such as the femur and tibia) and cause deformity or shortening of the affected bones.
  • Key features of MHE:
    • Osteochondromas rather than enchondromas: MHE involves the growth of exostoses (bony protrusions) rather than enchondromas, which are cartilage-based tumors. This is a crucial distinction.
    • Vascular abnormalities are not a typical feature of MHE, making this diagnosis less likely in this case.
    • The patient has enchondromas, not osteochondromas, so MHE does not fit this clinical presentation.
  • The patient has enchondromas, not osteochondromas, and vascular malformations are not part of the typical presentation of MHE.

 

Option C. Psoriatic Arthritis:

 

  • Psoriatic arthritis (PsA) is an autoimmune inflammatory condition that affects the joints and occurs in individuals with psoriasis (a skin condition).
  • Key features of PsA:
    • PsA typically presents with joint pain, stiffness, and swelling, particularly in the hands, feet, and spine, and may also involve skin lesions typical of psoriasis (such as plaques and scaling).
    • PsA can lead to dactylitis (sausage-like swelling of fingers or toes) and nail pitting but does not involve enchondromas or vascular malformations.
    • The absence of psoriasis and the presence of bony lumps and vascular abnormalities in this case suggest that PsA is unlikely.
  • Psoriatic arthritis is not a good fit because the clinical features (bony lumps and vascular abnormalities) do not align with the typical presentation of PsA.

 

Option D. Epiphyseal Dysplasia:

 

  • Epiphyseal dysplasia refers to a group of conditions that affect the epiphyses (ends of the long bones) during bone growth, leading to abnormal bone growth and potential skeletal deformities.
  • Key features of epiphyseal dysplasia:
    • It can cause short stature, joint deformities, and dysplasia of the hip, knee, or elbow.
    • This condition is often associated with abnormal bone development in the growing child, but it does not typically involve enchondromas or vascular malformations.
    • The absence of growth abnormalities or joint deformities in the patient, as well as the presence of enchondromas and vascular issues, makes this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most likely diagnosis for this patient is Mafucci’s syndrome due to the combination of enchondromas (especially in the hands and forearms) and vascular malformations.

questions.text: A patient experiences significant hair loss after recovering from a prolonged febrile illness. Examination reveals hair with angulated roots and a few with club-shaped ends. Which phase transition is most likely disrupted?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anagen to Catagen

 

Telogen Effluvium - 

  1. Triggering Event: Prolonged illness, stress, surgery, pregnancy, or emotional distress.

  2. Premature Anagen Termination: Stress disrupts normal hair growth, forcing anagen hairs to exit the growth phase early.

  3. Disrupted Anagen-to-Catagen Transition: Instead of progressing normally, anagen hairs abruptly enter the telogen phase.

  4. Rapid Shift to Telogen: A large proportion of hairs prematurely enter the telogen (resting) phase.

  5. Increased Shedding: Within 2-3 months, excessive telogen hairs are shed, leading to diffuse hair loss.

  6. Recovery: Hair regrowth occurs as new anagen hairs emerge once the underlying stressor resolves.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Catagen to Telogen: This is part of the normal cycle, not typically disrupted by febrile illnesses.

 

Option C. Telogen to Anagen: This marks the beginning of a new growth cycle and is unrelated to the described hair loss.

 

Option D. Anagen to Exogen: This transition is not part of the normal cycle as hair is shed after the telogen phase.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Stress and illnesses can precipitate premature transition of hairs from the anagen to the telogen phase, leading to diffuse hair loss (telogen effluvium).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department with complaints of secondary amenorrhea for the past 2 years. She has a history of two dilation and curettage (D&C) procedures following consecutive first-trimester pregnancy losses. Her BMI is 30 kg/m². Despite sequential hormonal therapy with estrogen followed by progesterone, there is no withdrawal bleeding. An HSG is done as below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asherman syndrome

 

  • Asherman syndrome is characterized by intrauterine adhesions (IUA) resulting from uterine trauma, most commonly following procedures such as dilation and curettage, myomectomy, or cesarean section.
  • The hallmark feature is secondary amenorrhea or hypomenorrhea after uterine trauma.
  • The absence of withdrawal bleeding after sequential estrogen-progesterone therapy reflects endometrial scarring and failure, which strongly suggests Asherman syndrome.
  • Diagnostic imaging:
    • Ultrasound: Irregular uterine cavity, punctate echogenic foci, or fluid collections.
    • Hysterosalpingography (HSG): Intrauterine filling defects with a moth-eaten appearance.
    • Hysteroscopy: Gold standard, directly visualizing and confirming adhesions.
  • Treatment: Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis, followed by hormonal therapy and possibly an intrauterine device (IUD) to prevent adhesion reformation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS):

 

  • Secondary amenorrhea is common in PCOS, but the presence of withdrawal bleeding after progestin challenge distinguishes it from conditions like Asherman syndrome.
  • Associated features: obesity, hirsutism, and oligo-ovulation/anovulation. Ultrasound shows multiple peripheral ovarian follicles (string of pearls appearance).

 

Option C. Cervical stenosis:

 

  • Secondary amenorrhea may occur due to mechanical obstruction of menstrual outflow. However, patients typically present with cyclical abdominal pain and hematometra (retention of blood in the uterus).
  • Withdrawal bleeding after hormonal therapy occurs once the obstruction is resolved.

 

Option D. Gonadal dysgenesis:

 

  • Gonadal dysgenesis (e.g., Turner syndrome, Swyer syndrome) causes primary amenorrhea rather than secondary amenorrhea.
  • Features include streak gonads, hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, and absent secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Secondary amenorrhea with no withdrawal bleeding after sequential estrogen-progesterone therapy strongly suggests an end-organ issue like Asherman syndrome. 
  • A history of uterine trauma, abnormal imaging findings, and hysteroscopic confirmation are diagnostic. 
  • Management involves hysteroscopic adhesiolysis and preventive measures to avoid adhesion recurrence.

questions.text: In which trimester is biparietal diameter (BPD) most accurately used to assess gestational age?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Second trimester

 

  • Biparietal Diameter (BPD) is the most accurate parameter for assessing gestational age during the second trimester, with an accuracy of 7–10 days.
  • It is measured in the trans-thalamic view, at the level of the thalamus and cavum septum pellucidum (CSP).
  • The measurement is taken from the outer edge of the skull in the near field to the inner edge in the far field. This provides a reliable and consistent method for dating gestation during this period.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. First trimester:

 

  • In the first trimester, the most accurate parameter to assess gestational age is the Crown-Rump Length (CRL), not BPD.
  • CRL is used up to 13+6 weeks of gestation and is accurate to within 3–5 days.
  • BPD is less reliable in the first trimester due to the smaller fetal size and lack of cranial ossification.

 

Option C. Third trimester:

 

  • In the third trimester, Femur Length (FL) and Abdominal Circumference (AC) are often used for fetal growth monitoring.
  • BPD is less accurate in the third trimester for gestational age estimation because of the variability in fetal head shape due to molding or other factors.

 

Option D. Fourth trimester:

 

  • This option is incorrect as the fourth trimester is a postpartum concept referring to the first 12 weeks after birth, during which maternal and newborn adjustment occurs. BPD has no relevance in this period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The biparietal diameter (BPD) is the most accurate parameter for gestational age estimation during the second trimester, highlighting the importance of trimester-specific tools for assessing fetal growth and development.

questions.text: Where are the lymph nodes of Rouviere located?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retropharyngeal space

 

  • The lymph nodes of Rouviere are located in the retropharyngeal space, which lies posterior to the buccopharyngeal fascia and anterior to the alar fascia. 
  • This space is divided into two halves by a midline fibrous raphe, and each half (space of Gillette) contains these lymph nodes. 
  • They play an important role in draining infections from the pharynx and nasopharynx but are also a route for the spread of infections to deeper structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Submandibular space: The submandibular space contains the submandibular glands and lymph nodes, but it is not associated with the lymph nodes of Rouviere.

 

Option C. Parapharyngeal space: The parapharyngeal space lies lateral to the pharynx and is involved in the spread of infections from the tonsils and pharynx, but it does not contain the lymph nodes of Rouviere.

 

Option D. Submental space: The submental space is located below the chin and contains submental lymph nodes. It does not house the lymph nodes of Rouviere.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The lymph nodes of Rouviere are located in the retropharyngeal space and play a significant role in the drainage and spread of infections from the pharynx and nasopharynx.

questions.text: Identify the helminth based on the given life cycle diagram:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enterobius vermicularis

 

  • The diagram depicts the life cycle of Enterobius vermicularis, also known as pinworm. The following key features from the image confirm the diagnosis:
    1. Eggs on perianal folds (Diagnostic stage): Gravid females migrate to the perianal region to lay eggs at night, leading to intense perianal itching.
    2. Infective embryonated eggs: Eggs are ingested, and larvae hatch in the small intestine.
    3. Adults in the lumen of the cecum: The worms mature and reside primarily in the cecum.
    4. Characteristic migration and reinfection: The image highlights the cycle of re-ingestion of eggs (fecal-oral route) leading to autoinfection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ascaris lumbricoides: Features a more complex life cycle involving larval migration to the lungs before returning to the intestine. Not associated with perianal itching or localized egg-laying.

 

Option C. Strongyloides stercoralis: Has a unique life cycle involving skin penetration by filariform larvae and autoinfection but does not lay eggs on perianal folds.

 

Option D. Trichuris trichiura: Resides in the large intestine but does not have a perianal egg-laying cycle or cause nocturnal pruritus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Enterobius vermicularis is identified by its life cycle involving:
    • Perianal egg-laying (diagnostic stage),
    • Autoinfection through ingestion of embryonated eggs,
    • Localized itching as a hallmark symptom.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old man presents with generalized tonic-clonic seizures and a history of a similar episode a month ago. He emigrated from Mexico several years ago and is HIV-negative.

 

Examination:

 

  • Lethargic but able to move all extremities on command.

 

CT image is shown below: 

 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cysticercosis

 

  • The patient’s presentation and imaging findings are most consistent with neurocysticercosis (NCC), caused by the larval form of Taenia solium (pork tapeworm).

 

Supporting Features for Neurocysticercosis:

 

  1. Epidemiology:
    • Common in individuals from endemic regions such as Mexico, Central and South America, and Southeast Asia.
  2. Seizures:
    • The most common presenting symptom of NCC due to inflammation around the cysts.
  3. Imaging findings:
    • Cystic lesions: Represent live or degenerating cysts.
    • Calcifications: Indicate dead larvae.
    • Typical appearance: "Ring-enhancing lesions with surrounding edema" in the brain parenchyma.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Glioblastoma multiforme: Usually presents as a single mass lesion with significant edema and mass effect, not multiple cystic and calcified lesions.

 

Option C. Metastatic non-seminomatous germ cell tumor: Brain metastases are typically large, solitary, or multiple masses with surrounding edema but rarely exhibit calcifications or cystic appearance. This diagnosis is unlikely without evidence of a primary testicular tumor or other metastases.

 

Option D. Toxoplasmosis: Common in HIV-positive patients with immunosuppression, presenting as multiple ring-enhancing lesions with edema. The patient is HIV-negative, making this less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neurocysticercosis is a common cause of seizures in individuals from endemic regions.
  • CT/MRI findings of cystic and calcified lesions are diagnostic, and treatment includes antiparasitic therapy (e.g., albendazole) and antiepileptic drugs.

questions.text: Which cellular compartment is primarily responsible for the elongation of fatty acids chains, critical in the biosynthesis of specialized lipids in the nervous system?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endoplasmic Reticulum

 

  • The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is the primary cellular compartment responsible for the elongation of fatty acid chains. 
  • The enzymes located in the ER catalyze the addition of two-carbon units to existing fatty acids, extending them into long-chain and very-long-chain fatty acids. 
  • These longer fatty acids are critical components of specialized lipids, such as sphingolipids and phospholipids, which are vital for the structure and function of the nervous system, particularly in the formation of myelin and neural membranes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lysosome: The lysosome is an organelle involved in the degradation and recycling of cellular waste, macromolecules, and pathogens. It contains enzymes that break down lipids, proteins, and carbohydrates, but it is not involved in the elongation of fatty acids or lipid biosynthesis.

 

Option B. Mitochondria: Mitochondria are the site of fatty acid β-oxidation, where fatty acids are broken down to produce energy in the form of ATP. While mitochondria are involved in lipid metabolism, they are not the primary site of fatty acid elongation. Their role is more focused on energy production and metabolism of shorter fatty acids rather than their elongation.

 

Option D. Golgi Apparatus: The Golgi apparatus is mainly involved in the modification, sorting, and packaging of proteins and lipids for secretion or for use within the cell. It plays a role in glycosylation of lipids and proteins but is not primarily involved in the elongation of fatty acids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fatty acid elongation occurs in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum, a process essential for synthesizing long-chain and very-long-chain fatty acids required for specialized lipids in neural tissues. 
  • These lipids play a crucial role in maintaining the integrity and functionality of the nervous system.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman with a history of abdominal surgery 3 days back presented with vomiting and abdominal distention. On percussion, a tympanic note was heard. Auscultation revealed absent bowel sounds. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) X ray abdomen

 

  • The clinical scenario is highly suggestive of paralytic ileus, a condition characterized by bowel paralysis without mechanical obstruction, often occurring after abdominal surgery.
  • Abdominal X-rays are the most appropriate initial diagnostic test for evaluating paralytic ileus.
  • X-ray findings may include dilated bowel loops with air-fluid levels and gas distribution throughout the small and large intestines, which help differentiate it from mechanical obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. USG abdomen: Although ultrasound can help identify certain abdominal abnormalities, it is less useful for detecting bowel dilation or air-fluid levels, which are the hallmark features of paralytic ileus on imaging.

 

Option C. CECT abdomen: Contrast-enhanced CT scan is typically reserved for cases where the diagnosis is unclear, or if mechanical obstruction, perforation, or another serious intra-abdominal pathology is suspected. It is not the first-line investigation for suspected paralytic ileus.

 

Option D. Laparotomy: Surgical intervention is not required in paralytic ileus unless there is a clear suspicion of mechanical obstruction, ischemia, or perforation. Most cases of paralytic ileus resolve with conservative management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Paralytic ileus is characterized by the absence of bowel sounds, abdominal distention, and tympanic percussion in the absence of mechanical obstruction, often following surgery or opioid use.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with fever, weight loss, and shortness of breath. A chest X-ray shows diffuse nodular infiltrates. Bronchoalveolar lavage finding is shown in the image below. Biopsy from a liver lesion shows similar findings. Which of the following is the primary route of transmission of the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inhalation of fungal spores

 

  • Histoplasmosis is caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, a dimorphic fungus that grows as mold in the environment and as yeast within macrophages in the host. 
  • The primary mode of transmission is through inhalation of fungal microconidia from soil contaminated with bird or bat droppings. 
  • The microconidia are phagocytosed by alveolar macrophages, where they convert to yeast forms and disseminate to the reticuloendothelial system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ingestion of contaminated water: Ingestion is not a recognized route of transmission for Histoplasma capsulatum.

 

Option C. Direct contact with infected animals: Direct contact with animals is not a mode of transmission; instead, environmental exposure to contaminated soil or guano is key.

 

Option D. Percutaneous exposure: Percutaneous exposure does not play a role in the acquisition of histoplasmosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Histoplasma capsulatum is transmitted by inhalation of fungal spores, primarily from environments rich in bird or bat droppings.

questions.text: Fenthion, a broad-spectrum insecticide, is used in vector control programs due to its multiple mechanisms of action. Which of the following best describes its role in mosquito control?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acts as a contact poison and larvicide

 

  • Fenthion is an organophosphate insecticide with broad-spectrum activity. It acts as a contact poison and is effective as a larvicide in mosquito control programs. 
  • Its dual mechanism makes it highly effective in reducing vector populations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acts only as a repellent: Fenthion is not a repellent; DEET is commonly used as a repellent.

 

Option C. Used exclusively as a residual spray: While fenthion is used as a residual spray, its primary function extends to being a larvicide and contact poison.

 

Option D. Acts by disrupting mosquito oviposition: Fenthion does not interfere with mosquito oviposition but targets larvae and adult mosquitoes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Fenthion is a broad-spectrum insecticide acting as a contact poison and larvicide, used in vector control programs.

choices.text: Leuprolide acts as a selective GnRH receptor modulator, changing its effect based on estrogen levels.
Leuprolide’s effect is dose-dependent, with high doses suppressing and low doses stimulating the pituitary.
The effect of leuprolide depends on its administration schedule, pulsatile or continuous.
Leuprolide directly affects ovarian cells to either promote or inhibit follicle maturation.

questions.text: A clinician is comparing different ovulation-inducing medications for a patient with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Which of the following statements best explains why leuprolide has the unique ability to both stimulate and suppress ovulation depending on dosing?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The effect of leuprolide depends on its administration schedule, pulsatile or continuous.

 

  • Leuprolide can stimulate ovulation when administered in a pulsatile fashion by mimicking natural GnRH pulses, leading to LH and FSH release. 
  • In contrast, continuous administration downregulates GnRH receptors, suppressing LH and FSH production and inhibiting ovulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leuprolide acts as a selective GnRH receptor modulator, changing its effect based on estrogen levels: Incorrect; leuprolide’s effect is not estrogen-dependent.

 

Option B. Leuprolide’s effect is dose-dependent, with high doses suppressing and low doses stimulating the pituitary: It is the administration schedule, not the dose, that determines its action.

 

Option D. Leuprolide directly affects ovarian cells to either promote or inhibit follicle maturation: Leuprolide works via the hypothalamic-pituitary axis, not directly on the ovaries.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Leuprolide’s ability to either stimulate or suppress ovulation is determined by its mode of administration—pulsatile or continuous.

questions.text: A patient presents with a foreign body in the right cornea. Which would be the topical anesthetic of choice to remove it?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Proparacaine

 

  • Proparacaine eye drops are the preferred topical anesthetic in ophthalmology for procedures such as removal of corneal foreign bodies. 
  • It is effective, safe, and causes minimal corneal irritation compared to other agents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tetracaine: Tetracaine is another topical anesthetic commonly used in ophthalmology; however, it is associated with more corneal irritation than proparacaine, making it a less favourable choice.

 

Option B. Cocaine: Cocaine can be used for ocular anesthesia, especially for its vasoconstrictive properties, but it is rarely chosen due to its potential for systemic effects and limited availability.

 

Option C. Bupivacaine: Bupivacaine is a long-acting local anesthetic primarily used in regional anesthesia and is not suitable for topical use in the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Proparacaine is the preferred topical anesthetic for ocular procedures, offering rapid onset, minimal irritation, and excellent safety for the removal of foreign bodies from the cornea.

The swivelling of the foot to the medial and lateral directions.
The twisting of the wrist while the elbow is held motionless.
The rotation at the shoulder that causes the arm to describe a cone shape.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the movements known as pronation and supination?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The twisting of the wrist while the elbow is held motionless

 

  • Pronation refers to the movement of the radius from a position parallel to the ulna (palm-up or supinated position) to a position where the radius crosses over the ulna (palm-down position).
  • Supination is the reverse motion, returning the palm to the upward-facing position.
  • These movements occur at the proximal and distal radioulnar joints, involving the twisting motion of the forearm while the elbow remains stationary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The flexing of the arm with respect to the forearm around the elbow: This describes flexion at the elbow joint and does not involve pronation or supination.

 

Option B. The swivelling of the foot to the medial and lateral directions: This describes inversion (medial movement) and eversion (lateral movement) of the foot, movements occurring at the subtalar joint.

 

Option D. The rotation at the shoulder that causes the arm to describe a cone shape: This describes circumduction, a combination of flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction at the shoulder joint, not pronation or supination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pronation and supination are movements of the forearm occurring at the radioulnar joints, allowing the hand to rotate from palm-up to palm-down positions. 
  • These movements are critical for activities involving wrist rotation, such as turning a doorknob or handling tools.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents to the gynecology outpatient clinic with complaints of foul-smelling, blood-tinged vaginal discharge persisting for the last three weeks. She also reports lower abdominal discomfort. On examination, a necrotizing growth is visualized in the cervix with evidence of lateral parametrium involvement. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chemoradiation

 

  • Lateral parametrium involvement indicates Stage 2B cervical cancer, as per FIGO staging. 
  • Stage 2B signifies that the cancer has extended beyond the cervix and has invaded the parametrium but has not reached the pelvic wall or the lower third of the vagina. 
  • For Stage 2B cervical cancer, the treatment of choice is chemoradiation, which combines external beam radiotherapy with concurrent chemotherapy (typically cisplatin-based) to maximize tumor control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy alone is not sufficient for treating Stage 2B cervical cancer. It is primarily used as part of concurrent chemoradiation or for palliative treatment in advanced/metastatic cases (Stage 4B). Hence, this is incorrect in this scenario.

 

Option B. Brachytherapy: Brachytherapy, a form of localized radiotherapy, is a component of the overall radiation treatment plan but is not used as a standalone therapy for Stage 2B cervical cancer. It is typically combined with external beam radiotherapy in later stages.

 

Option D. Surgery: Radical surgery is generally reserved for early stages (e.g., Stage 1 and select cases of Stage 2A1). Surgery is not suitable for Stage 2B, where parametrium involvement makes the tumor unresectable without causing significant complications. Hence, this option is inappropriate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lateral parametrium involvement (Stage 2B) mandates the use of chemoradiation as the standard treatment modality to optimize tumor control and survival outcomes.
